Content:
Leader of the House in Parliament, Richard Chimwendo Banda has told the House that the country is on course of rising again from the pangs of cyclone Freddy that has caused unprecedented misery to Malawians.
Chimwendo was speaking in Parliament on Monday, March 27, 2023 during deliberations of 2023/2024 National Budget meeting.
He told the August House that amidst the challenges that have hit the global economy and not sparing Malawi’s own economy, the country still is “set for the rise” through the budget, Minister of Finance Sosten Gwengwe presented in the House which has several developmental projects that have been lined up to benefit the local masses.

President Peter Mutharika is this morning set to hold a press briefing at the Kamuzu Palace in Lilongwe at 10 am. State House has not indicated the issues the President plans to address during the briefing. The briefing comes barely a day after Parliament passed the contentious electoral reform bills, clearing the way for a rerun on May 19 this year.

Title: Veep Usi sets ball rolling
Content:
Vise – President Michael Usi has set the ball rolling with an engagement with creative sector players. 
Yesterday, Usi had a 99- minute closed door meeting with musicians and theatre players at Amaryllis Hotel in Blantyre. 
Speaking in an interview later, the vise- president said the engagement himself an accomplished actor, sought to remind the artist of their role in an era marred by so much misinformation. 
He said; “Firstly, we are looking at Malawi as our country and we should seek what we need to do for it to develop by offering hope to the people, 
“We are living in a world where a lot are said especially on social media which leave people into despair. Artists know how to use their talent to inform people about reality.” 
Usi urged artist to show love to the country and the same should be true for every Malawian. 
The Veep said artists are strategecilly placed to inform the citizenry what is going on around them. 
He said there is more to art than just entertainment touting its element of education as one crucial component of the trade. 
“This does not mean that they should not voice out their concerns or peoples expectations. That is part of their role, and it will be respected. They should help build, construct and consolidate hope among the people,” he said. 
The Vice – president said the development of arts is not a one – man job, but something which will require the involvement of partner. 
He said; "We will have to sit down and look at the Acts and policies guiding the industry. It is not incumbent upon me to dictate that we change this and that. It will be an interactive process.” Usi also used the opportunity to pay tribute to music icon Lucious Banda who died in South Africa on Sunday. He described his death as tragedy. Seasoned musician Overtone Chimombo said the meeting with the veep gave them an opportunity to discuss pertinent issues affecting the sector. The establishment of Arts council remains key for the industry. We need to have council in place to ensure that the sector jerked into action,” said.

Title: THE FUTURE BELONGS TO MALAWI - CHAKWERA
Content:
Malawi President His Excellency Dr Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera presented his speech at UN general assembly in New York USA. Chakwera stressed on the need of mitigating climate change and fostering equality amongst UN member states.
Chakwera also challenged UN member states to consider giving two permanent seats to African Countries in UN security council if the world is to make progress. Chakwera hinted importance of inclusivity among member states.
At the summit many African countries are presenting their speech with almost empty hall including Malawi's speech. Experts have criticized UN member states for shunning poor countries at UN assembly.

Title: GOVT FAULTS APM CRITICISM OF ECONOMY
Content:
The Government has said common sense would say that an institution that messed up the economy of the country could not be engaged on issues of how to develop a sound economy. Minister of Information and Digitization Gospel Kazako was reacting to Democratic Progressive Progressive Party (DPP) leader Peter Mutharika, who accused the Tonse Alliance administration of running down the country's 
Economy. Mutharika, who governed Malawi from 2014 to June 2020, said at a news conference in Mangochi on Friday that President Lazarus Chakwera and his Tonse Alliance haw destroyed all foundations his administration put in place. He further said the President has plunged the country into fuel crisis. forex shortages, sky rocketing food prices and messed up Affordable Inputs Programme (AIP) and Admarc. But Kazako, who is also official government spokesperson, said yesterday the Chakwera administration was clearing the economic mess the previous DPP government left. He said. "On claims that we have failed Malawians, Malawians have suffered for a very long time, including the time he was president. This country has been economically down to the extent that the citizens had to lower their standards to submit. We still see poverty all over. "Various reports have confirmed Malawians have been poor for many years, including the years DPP was in government. We hope they are not living in the illusion of the Singapore they promised Malawians." Kazako said low quality logic indicates that one cannot solve a problem by involving the same people that created it in the first place. 
He said the goverment cannot solve problems in this country with the same gang that destroved this country. The former president also blasted the Tonse Alliance for failing Malawians by falling to uplift uplift their lives economically. Answering questions on reports that the Anti-Corruption Bureau may arrest and prosecute him, his wife Gertrude and son Tadikira over abuse of his Tpin when he was president, he said: "I do not understand it because Malawi Revenue Authority and the bureau already interviewed me on the issue here in my house."

Title: APM BLAMES CHAKWERA ON POWER BLACKOUTS
Content: Immediate past president Mutharika weighed in on the prevailing energy crisis in the country by blaming President Lazarus Chakwera-led Tonse Alliance government decision to cancel the Aggreko Contract. In a press statement release yesterday and signed by his spokesperson shadrick namalomba, the former president faulted both minster of information and digitization, Gospel Kazako and minister of energy, Ibrahim Matola for fingering his Democratic Progressive Party Administration as the main cause of the current government power blackouts. He said the two ministers missed an opportunity to tell Malawians the truth about the blackouts, saying that they are a direct result of the cancellation of the only lifeline contract with Aggreko.  Reads the statment in part: Government has deliberately departed from the truth about the ongoing and endless electricity blackouts. President Chakwera cancelled the only lifeline contract with Aggreko which was providing an additional 78 Megawatts.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Vice President for the Central region, Alfred Gangata, has launched a scathing attack on President Dr. Lazarus Chakwera’s economic policies, citing skyrocketing debt, youth unemployment, and deepening corruption.
“President Chakwera promised Malawians a host of things but none has materialized apart from corruption which he is championing,” Gangata said at a rally in Kasungu district’s Chithiba ground.
“Malawi has lost enviable ground to other countries due to lack of investment and dedicated policy toward economic transformation and growth.”
Gangata criticized Chakwera’s leadership, stating, “Apart from kissing the sky with his family, what else can you point at Chakwera that he has done for poor Malawians?”

Title: DPP LEGISLATORS DEMAND CONVENTION FOR PARTY TO ELECT LEADRES
Content:
Some Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators have faulted endorsements of former president Peter Mutharika to lead the party in the 2025 Tripartite Elections as unconstitutional and have since said: "A regional governor or vice-president of the party carry one vote each. But we have regional, district and constituency members who bring more votes. I am not moved. I will challenge them at the convention, and they will be surprised. He said the party needs to call for a convention by July 18 and not later than July 28 as per the constitution. But Chiradzulu South legislator Joseph Mwanamvekha, who is also vying for the DPP presidency, sounded cautious, saying, the matter was internal, and he will wait for Mutharika to make formal communication. "Smooth discussions are supposed to take place within the party. In any case, if indeed our president wants to stand, he will communicate to us internally. We will wait for him to pronounce his stand," he said. Former Reserve Bank of Malawi governor Dalitso Kabambe, DPP vice-president for the Eastern Region Bright Msaka and United States-based space scientist Cedrick Ngalande are the other presidential hopefuls Commenting on the developments, University of Malawi associate professor of political science Boniface Dulani urged other candidates not to back down, wondering why some members were insisting on Mutharika who Malawians rejected during the 2020 fresh presidential polls. He said: "This just shows inability to groom leadership. Mutharika served this country and at his age, you would think they would go for someone to take over. They need to learn from Malawi Congress Party because it suffered a lot due to infighting. 

But Mutharika's spokesperson Shadric Namalomba, while saying the former Malawi leader was still consulting. challenged other contestants to get endorsements if they can. 
He said: "People go to the convention to affirm their endorsements. They should not pressurize Mutharika to come out now, they don't have any moral standing to ask for that. 

"That said, these endorsements are coming because they see Mutharika as the only hope for the country," he said. 

positions expire in July. Reads the articles in part: 

"Members of the National Governing Council shall be elected at the National Political Conference of the party for a period of five years and shall continue to hold office for a term up to the election of new office bearers, notwithstanding the expiry of their term of office. 

Meanwhile, some DPP presidential hopefuls have vowed to challenge Mutharika during the party's convention while others have asked him to come out clearly and communicate his intentions on the matter. 
On the other hand, political pundits feel that while Mutharika has the right to contest during any election, and those endorsing him too have such rights, they warn that Malawians are likely not to vote for him, and urge other candidates not to give up. 

In an interview yesterday, Nankhumwa said he was ready to face whoever decides to compete at the convention. 

He said: "At some point they stopped people from making endorsements. but today their people are doing the same. Endorsement is not a legal way of doing things, a party has a constitution, and a convention must be held, we need it to take place at all cost. 

"I have said this several times, regardless of whoever stands. I will be there, I will contest, that's it. 

Another DPP hopeful Paul Gadama said he will also contest during the polls. 

He said DPP has over 2.000 delegates, who are way too many than the few individuals making endorsements.

Title: JB PUSHES FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION IN ZOMBA
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has emphasized that Malawians need to put much effort on restoring the environment. She said this on Tuesday at Domasi in Zomba District when she launched a tree-planting exercise at the newly constructed houses for Cyclone Freddy survivors. Banda said environmental conservation initiatives are crucial for ensuring a more sustainable future. "Through reforestation, Malawi can mitigate environmental shocks such as erratic rains and dry spells which are chocking agriculture," she said.  Banda, who also distributed foodstuffs such as maize and porridge flour to the communities, said Malawians should develop the spirit of sharing basic things to ensure that no one dies of hunger in the country.  "The elderly, children and those suffering from chronic diseases need supplementary food support to be healthy," she said. Florida Mtunduwatha, a widow of five children from Kundecha Village in Senior Chief Malemia, who benefited from the relief maize, said she was in need of maize seed and fertilizer to invest in winter cropping.  She said the maize she planted was heat due to the district. scorched by dry spells for winter cropping, but I need farm inputs," said Mtunduwatha Group village head Mtogolo agreed with Mtunduwatha that communities need support of farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer as well as water pumps to invest in winter cropping . "We need sustainable agricultural technologies to be food secure," he said.  The former president is a Cyclone Freddy goodwill ambassador alongside former president Bakili Muluzi.

Peter Mutharika, HRDC in verbal spat. While the majority of citizens are in a merry mood sending each other messages of hope and wishes for a better life in the New Year, there is still no love lost between President Peter Mutharika and the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC)

As I pen this letter, my heart bleeds for the innocent civil servants who have been subjected to unimaginable humiliation and abuse by MCP officials. The reports of forced kneeling for 2 hours have left me shaken, and I implore you to take immediate action.
How can a government that promises to serve and protect its citizens resort to such dehumanizing tactics? What message does this send to the world about our nation’s values? The very thought of our dedicated public servants, who work tirelessly to build our nation, being reduced to kneeling before power-drunk officials is nothing short of heartbreaking.
These are not just statistics or nameless faces; they are mothers, fathers, brothers, and sisters who deserve dignity and respect. They are the backbone of our nation, working tirelessly to provide essential services. Must they be punished for serving their country?
Mr. President Show commitment, Investigate these heinous acts, Hold perpetrators accountable, Protect civil servants’ rights and dignity
We elected you to lead our nation with compassion, justice, and integrity. The world watches as Malawi’s reputation hangs in the balance.
History will judge your actions. Will you stand for justice or turn a blind eye?
Sincerely,

Title: Online gender-based violence an emerging concept-minister
Content:
Minister of Information and Digitisation Gospel Kazako says online gender-based violence which has not received attention is an emerging concept in Malawi and the rest of the southern Africa.
The minister said this in Lilongwe on Tuesday during the launch of the Southern Africa report on online gender-based violence titled Understanding Online Gender-based Violence in Southern Africa.
The report provides regional evidence on the prevalence of digitally enabled gender-based violence as well as the policy and practice frameworks in response to the emerging phenomenon.
Kazako said this new phenomenon has not received much attention, especially in policy-related interventions compared to physical violence.
"We have formulated the National Cyber Security Strategy (2019-2024), which is aimed at providing a national framework for ensuring secure, safe and resilient cyberspace as well as fostering trust and confidence in cyberspace," he said.
Kazako said the Malawi Government will ensure that all constitutional provisions that protect the rights of women and girls are  further strengthened through various regulatory interventions.
Ministry of Gender, Community Development and Social Welfare principal gender and development officer Japhet Chirwa said government has shown commitment to responding and tackling online gender-based violence by developing the Electronic Transactions and Cyber Security Act of 2016.
Gender activist Barbara Banda said there is need to ensure that women and young girls are aware of online gender-based violence and the policies available for redress.
Gender Justice Unit executive director Sarai Chisala-Tempelhoff called for multi-stakeholder response to the vice.
The study focused on eight countries, namely Botswana, Malawi, Angola, South Africa, Zambia, Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe.

Title: Atupele says still in presidential race
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi has assured his party supporters that he is not withdrawing from the presidential race in the May 21 2019 Tripartite Elections. Muluzi, who is serving as Minister of health in President Peter Mutharika’s Cabinet, gave the assurance in Zomba on Wednesday when he addressed whistle – stop rallies at KKatete, Namisinga and Chinamwali in Zomba Changalume, Zomba Likangala and Zomba Central costituencies, respectively. His sentiments come amid speculation that he was set to withdraw his candidacy and endorse his current boss - Mutharika of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Speculation about Muluzi’s possible withdrawal from the race was heightened by the pill out of former president Joyce Banda, as presidential candidate for peoples’s party (PP), who endorsed Lazarus Chkwera of Malawi Congress Party (MCP). In his address, Muluzi, who alongside Vice –President Saulos Chilima are Mutharika’s Cabinet members challenging their boss in the presidential race, said a day does not past without critics hitting at him that he has sold the party, and he is a desperate leader withdrawing from the race. He said he had chosen to remain silent because in his 15 – year political career, his great enemy is poverty and not detractors. Muluzi said; “Therefore, make informed decisions on the polling say by voting back UDF into power if people are to have a leader who has their welfare at heart.” He said many local and international partners entrust him with various portfolios because he delivers. On the campaign, he said UDF has not been active since the launch of the campaign period but challenged that in 30 days the party will run a vigorous campaign until it bounces back into the government. Said Muluzi; “UDF has a clean history of ending poverty by investing in people, ensuring that they have money and food for their livelihood. We are committed to reversing the current challenges the country is facing when voted back into power. In their remarks, shadow parliamentarian in the constituencies – Chikumbutso Likandawe, hashhem Banda and Loveness Mulombe – expressed optimism to win and lead their constituent from poverty to prosperity. Zomba has 10 constituencies and in the 20 2014 Tripartite Elections, UDF won three, independents won two and Peoples’s Party (PP) won five. In the 2009 General Elections, UDF also failed to win any seat while DPP swept seven and independents too, three. UDF, then led by Atupele’s Father Bakili Muluzi, formed the first post – independence Multiparty administration in 1994 and led the country up to 2005 when Muluzi’s successor, Bingu wa Mutharika, ditched the Party to form DPP. Since 1994, UDF’s influence in Parliament has waned. In 1994, UDF won 85 seats out of 177 while in 1999 – when the number of seats was increased to 193 – UDF won 93 before dropping to 49 in 2004, 17 in 2009 and 14 in 2014.

Title: Atupele  confirms political interest
Content:
Former United Democratic Front president Atupele Muluzi yesterday said he is ready to bounce back into active politics to serve Malawians. 
He gave a hint during a rally to cerebrate 30 years of UDF’s existence at Nyambadwe Primary School groung inBlantyre , about a year after announcing his retirement from active politics to focus on business. 
Atupele's position follows calls by some UDF members who are asking him to be the former governing party’s torchbearer in the 2025 presidential elections. 
In an interview yesterday after adressing party followers at Nyambadwe Primary School ground in Ndirande Township in Blantyre as part of the party’s 30 anniversary cerebration, he said he has positively considered the calls by the party members to be ready to serve Malawi. 
Atupele, who is son of UDF co – founder and the country’s first multiparty president Bakili Muluzi, said ‘ “I want to make it clear, if the people want me to serve them , i am ready to serve them in whatever capacity they wish me to serve. We have heard from Blantyre and we need to go to other places to hear what other people have to say. 
“I have to listen to the people, l have made it clear that l am here to serve the people.” 
Earlier during the rally, UDF regional governor for the south Dorothy Masinga all UDF members in the Southern Region have agreed to endorse Atupele as the party’s torchbearer in the 2025 elections and that they will vote for him at the party’s convention. 
“Last week, party members issued a petition asking honourable Atupele Muluzi to bounce back and be our leader. They say he had good leadership skills and experience. So, we have agreed that Muluzi will be the party’s right candidate,” she said. 
Her statement comes a week after some UDF members in Mangochi asked Atupele to rejoied the party and become the leader. 
Before making speech, he called for a minute of silence in honour of the people who died due to the impact of Tropical Cyclone Freddy in the country. 
Atupele asked government to consider conducting mass national identity card registration, saying most Cyclone Freddy survivors lost their cards. 
He also asked all former members of UDF, saying this is the right time to join before the party returns to power after the 2025 elections. 
Speaaking during the rally, one of the campaigners of multiparty democracy and UDF founding member Ziliro Chirambo, who was also the country’s current economic status is not what they fought for. 
He urged the UDF leadership to carefully choose a political party to partner with as no single entity can amass the 50 percent – plus – one vote threshold in the presidential election. 
Other notable faces at the rally include Haphman Makande and Peter Fachi who served as the party in various positions. UDF acting president Lilian Patel was not present as she was reported to be in Scotland for Parliamentary business.

In a surprise reversal, Aisha Adams, Second Deputy Speaker of Parliament, has rescinded her decision to resign as United Democratic Front (UDF) convention chairperson.
Adams had initially stepped down citing internal divisions and divergent views on the party’s direction.
However, in an interview with Capital FM, Adams revealed that the reasons for her resignation have been resolved amicably, prompting her return.
A key factor in her decision was the agreement to exclude the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) from the UDF convention to avoid conflicts with UDF supporters.
“We have agreed that MCP should not come to our convention to avoid problems with our supporters,” Adams stated.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has stated that greed among its officials contributed to their loss in the presidential elections. DPP director of elections Ben Phiri, who also serves as Minister of Local Government and Rural Development, made these comments on Tuesday in Mangochi during the elevation of three Traditional Authorities to Senior Chiefs. Phiri acknowledged that some supporters are disappointed with the Constitutional Court's nullification of the presidential election results but asserted that the DPP will campaign vigorously to reclaim the presidency. He attributed the DPP's failure to secure a landslide victory in the May elections to greed, which hindered the Eastern and Southern regions from uniting effectively.

Title: Atupele delivers public lecture of Bunda
Content:
United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi on Friday delivered a public lecture at Bunda College, a Constituent College of Lilongwe University of Agriculture and Natural Resources (Luanar). 
He assured students of a good learning environment if UDF wins the 20 May Tripartite Elections. Muluzi, who was accompanied by his running mate Godfrey Chapola, said it is said that the youth are not contributing to the development of the country. “It is unfortunate that many secondary and university graduates have nothing to do in our country. Considering that youths are in majority, there is need for government to create a conductive environment for them. Therefore, UDF government will invest in youths through creation of jobs,” he said. Muluzi said Malawi can only move forward if it educates its majority youths. “Let our education be the foundation of wealth creation so that Malawi should move forward economically,” he said. Muluzi is the second presidential candidate to deliver a public lecture at Bunda after Malawi Congress Party (MCP) presidential candidate Lazarus Chakwera only this year.

Title: YOU QUIT, APM TELLS CHAKWERA
Content:
Former president Peter Mutharika alongside some opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials yesterday asked President Lazarus Chakwera to resigns for allegedly falling to govern the country amid a worsening economic situation. But Minister of information and Digitization Gospel Kazako who is the official government’s spokesperson, laughed off the calls, saying Chakwera and Tonse Alliance are not moving an inch out of Capital Hill.  Speaking during a news conference at his beachside home in Mangochi, Mutharika, who turns 82 today, said his successor has failed to show decisive leadership which he promised Malawians. He said since Chakwera promised to resign after two years if he failed to govern, the DPP holds the view that he has failed, as such, should step aside. Said Mutharika: "There are analysts who always blame the DPP for the current challenges being faced in this country. They analysts] also say the DPP is weak for falling to provide an oversight but that is riot the case. "That if there is anyone to blame, it must be the Tonse Alliance because it has failed to live by its campaign promises and not the DPP Chakwera has failed, he must resign," Mutharika further said Malawi has lost direction under the nine-party Tonse Alliance administration Chakwera leads. He cited the rise in the cost of living that continues to affect citizenry as one area his successor was failing, He dismissed assertions that the economic impact of Covid-19 and Russia's worsened the situation, arguing that countries such as Tanzania, Zambia and Mozambique were pushing forward despite being haunted by similar challenges. The former president blamed the Chakwera administration for victimizing officials from former DPP government and specifically those from the Southern Region. While dismissing allegations of his alleged involvement in the killing of persons with albinism, Mutharika said the allegations are aimed diverting attention from real issues affecting the country. He said his dream to turn Malawi into Singapore would have come to fruition and that his administration had already sourced funds to transform the lives of Malawians.  "Malawi would have become Singapore. We actually found money to tum around the situation by having good infrastructure such as roads," said the former president, The DPP leader went on to condemn arrests of members of his party, describing such moves as a contravention of the rule of law saying most of the arrests seem to have lost direction in the course of investigations. Mutharika has since asked Chakwera to stop politicizing public projects that were initiated under the DPP administration, saying that the President must give credit where its due.Taking his turn, Mutharika's spokesperson Shadric Namalomba said Malawians are facing challenges emanating from poor leadership. 

He said: "The economy is worsening. We are victims of a failed leadership. President Chakwera doesn't know anything about the economy and how to alleviate poverty among the people." 

Namalomba, who is also Mangochi Southwest legislator, said when the DPP left power through the court-sanctioned Fresh Presidential Election on June 23 2020, inflation had averaged 8.63 percent unlike in the current administration which went over 14 percent as of May 2022. 

On his part, DPP director of legal affairs Charles Mhango said Chakwera has done nothing during his two-year tenure. 

He said Chakwera has failed to promote the rule of law or trim his powers and has instead focused on persecuting innocent Malawians. 

But Kazako laughed off the sentiments by Mutharika and his DPP colleagues, saying: "These are politically bereaved people. All they can do is to try to be relevant and take advantage of global economic trends. 

"We are not moved an inch. We are moving forward. We are building a new Malawi." 

Reacting to suggestions that disunity in DPP was unhealthy for an opposition party that is supposed to provide checks and balances to the government, Mutharika yesterday said the party is in a rebuilding process and expressed confidence that it will win the 2025 general elections.

Title: Atupele promises hospital in Phalombe
Content:
The united Democratic Front (UDF) says once voted into government in the May 20 Tripartite Elections it will build a district hospital in Phalombe, which despite being upgraded to a district status over 15 years ago. UDF presidential hopeful Atupele Muluzi said this on Saturday when he conducted whistle – stop tour in Phalombe North East and Phalombe East constituencies. Atupele said access to good health facilities for Malawians is one of his priorities and as the country will be celebrating 50 years of independence, the people of Phalombe deserve better just as other people other districts in the country. “It is saddening to note that after 50 years of self-rule, Phalombe has never had a district hospital. Health is a priority, and every person has a right to good health. It is high time Phalombe had a district hospital just as its neighbour, Chiradzulu,” He said. Atupele also said he will remove the coupon system and bring universal fertiliser subsidy so that everyone is able purchase farm inputs. Speaking at Nambazo Health Centre groung in Phalombe North East Constituency, Group Village Head (GVH) Nambazo commented Atupele for his initiative to reach the people of the area irresponsible of the bad roads. 
Nambazo commended plans to bring a district hospital to the area and pleaded with him to include a cellphone network tower to the area in his plans for easy communication. Phalomba hospital construction has been a bone of contention since 2010/2011 budget allocation, where over K300 million was reportedly spent on the project, yet there is nothing on the ground. Last year, Phalombe community members presented a six – point petition to the district commissioner’s office over lack of adquate medical facilities due to the absence of a district hospital in their district.

Freedom Party President Khumbo Kachali declares that Chakwera is the only one who can resolve the country’s problems, saying, “We have a history that it is only the Malawi Congress Party that solves our problems.”

Title: MSUNGAMA FOR MORE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS
Content:
Member of Parliament for Lilongwe South East Constituency Ulemu Msungama has pledged to drive more developmental projects in his area.
Speaking in an interview on Tuesday, Msungama said besides initiating new development projects, he is working hard to finalise some of the projects he started in a quest for greater development to the community.
“We have several projects that are already in the pipeline and we want to make sure that they continue under the dynamic leadership of president of the country Dr Lazarus Macarthur Chakwera,” he said.
Commenting on how residents in Lilongwe South East Constituency have for years struggled with deplorable roads, Msungama has assured people that government is set to begin construction of Chipasula, Don Bosco and Gologota-Benito roads and other projects.

Title: BCC facelift’s delay irks VP
Content:
Vice –President Michael Usi has expressed anger at the ‘snail’ pace of Blantyre Cultural Centers (BCC) renovation works, saying the delay is contributing to immoral behaviour among youth in the city.  
In an interview yesterday after touring the once mighty entertainment venue in Blantyre, Usi said it was worrisome that the construction works keep on delaying a development he said is affecting artists and entertainment enthusiasts. 
He condemned the lazy attitude in most government ministries, departments and agencies(MDAs) which he described as ‘ we will do it tomorrow attitude,’ saying it is affecting the progress of some of the country's developmental projects.  

Said Usi “it is disappointing that this facility has taken this long for completion. This attitude must stop. These projects are for Malawians , look at the youth in Blantyre, where do they go on weekends for entertainment? This forces some people to be in alcohol abused. 

“When they have challenges, they [contractors] can reach out to my office because we are a team. 

He then asked Opco Limited managing director Akhar Qureshi to give a timeframe to complete the rehabilitation work. 

In his response Qureshi assured Usi to complete the work within four months. 

“So today is 23rd July and l want to see Blantyre Cultural Centre opened in November. So, we would like to see this thing move fast,” said Usi.  

He then signed an agreement with Ministry of Transport and Public works director of buildings Sam Ngoma to ensure that the facility be opened by November.  

In 2022 government awarded a K150 million contract to Opco Limited to rehabilitate the facility.

Title: 4 DEAD, 12 INJURED IN NTCHEU
Content: Four people have died in Ntcheu District following an accident that occurred at the district center yesterday. The four were hit by a vehicle following chaos that erupted as the convoy carrying the body of departed Vice-Preside Saulos Klaus Chilima was enroute from Lilongwe to Nsipe, in Ntcheu for burial today. The incident happened when hundreds of people lined up along the M1 and some stoned vehicles on the convoy. During a visit to Ntcheu District Hospital at around 8pm, we found about 30 people at the entrance mourning the departed. A hospital official, who opted for anonymity, confirmed that two people were brought in dead while the other two died while receiving treatment. The official said 12 were injured. He said: "One women who was brought in already dead is a pregnant woman."
Author: Bobby Kabango

Content:
A staggering 93% of Malawians believe President Lazarus Chakwera is the most corrupt leader in the country’s history, according to a recent survey conducted by the Institute of Public Opinion and Research (Ipor) in March 2024.
Chakwera’s presidency has been plagued by corruption scandals, including the Sattar corruption scandal, fertilizer scandal, Bridgin Foundation scandal, and Nocma fuel importation deal.
Despite evidence, no action has been taken against his associates.
Investigator Magazine exposed MK 1.4 trillion in fraudulent fertilizer and fuel deals, implicating Chakwera’s head of civil service, Colleen Zamba, and transport minister, Jacob Hara.
Critics argue Chakwera’s inaction fuels corruption, eroding public trust.
Malawi ranks 115th out of 180 countries with a score of 30 in 2023.
The country’s corruption fight has weakened over the past 10 years, dropping from 37 points in 2012 to 34 points in 2023.
Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu dismissed the survey findings, citing corruption’s complexity.

Title: Atupele dismisses al-Bashir, Sata links
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential hopeful Atupele Muluzi has dismissed allegations that his campaign is being financed by International Criminal Court (ICC) indicted President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan . Over the past week, social media has been awash with stories claiming that Atupeles’ campaign is being bankrolled by al-Bashir. In an interview yesterday, Atupele not only denied the allegations, but called those spreading them “detractors” He said; “There is no truth, that’s sensationalism and they are trying to divert attention from the real issue. It is quite unfortunate and not true.” Political analyst Blessings Chinsinga, despite saying that there is nothing wrong for any presidential candidate to grt funds from anywhere, Malawi needs to have  a legal framework to prevent such instances as a country’s foreign policies and relations could be compromised by such an image. “Well, this has not been proven to be true and even it were there, there is nothing wrong as Malawi does not have a legislative framework on this,” he said. Omar al-Bashir is currently wanted by the ICC for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide. In 2012, President Joyce Banda shifted the African Union (AU) venue, when it was announced that the Sudanese President would visit the country. However, former president the late Bingu wa Mutharika hosted al-Bashir and the ICC referred Malawi to the United Nations (UN) security council.

Title: APM SNEAKS OUT FOR PRIVATE TRIP
Content: Former president Peter Mutharika left the country last week through Chileka International Airport in Blantyre for a private trip, it has emerged Office of the President and Cabinet (OPC) spokesperson Robert Kalindiza confirmed in an Interview yesterday that Mutharika has travelled abroad. But he could not provide more details regarding the destination, when he is expected to return home and whether the trip is a holiday one as per former presidents' benefits. Said Kalindita "Indeed Professor Peter Mutharika is a public figure but should also know that he is also a man with a private life to live. So, he has travelled on a private trip. “As a former president, OPC was informed of the trip, and we are aware of it. If need be, the public will be informed on when he is expected to return. Further, the trip is privately sponsored. Democratic Progressive Purty (DPP) and Mutharika's spokesperson Shadric Namalomba said the former president has travelled to several countries for private engagements. He said: "I can confirm that the former president together with the former first lady Madame Gertrude Mutharika have travelled to a number of countries on a private and confidential visit. "You will appreciate that for security reasons, I will not share with the public his date of coming back, the countries he is visiting and people he is meeting. DPP sources confided that Mutharika left through Chileka a day before he was expected to attend the Chiwanja Cha Ayao cultural festival in Mangochi District. Said the source: "He is destined for Dubai in the United Arab Emirates where he will proceed to other countries.  "Their tickets were bought in the United States, and they will return on November 4 this year." As a former president, he and his spouse are each entitled under the Presidents (Salaries and Benefits) Act, to one first tial class return air ticket to any destination abroad that each year However, since his loss in the court-sanctioned Fresh Presidential Election in June 2020, he has spent most of his time at his beachside residence in Mangochi. He has also been taking short trips to Blantyre, with the longest known trip to Enukweni in Mzimba District to attend the burial of former minister of Finance and personal friend Goodall Gondwe. Speaking at Mulhako wa Alhomwe on October 8, 2023, Mutharika vowed to run for the country's president in 2025 to dislodge incumbent Lazarus Chakwera and address economic challenges the country is facing under the Tonse Alliance.

Title: Chakwera excites Parliament
Content:
Members of Parliament yesterday looked astonished and excited when leader of Opposition in Parliament and Malawi Congress Party (MCP) Lazarus Chakwera appeared on the order paper to ask the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology on issues concerning his constituency.

Some members started clapping hands while one was heard murmuring: "Oh, oh, does he also have to ask questions; we thought he is a president?" Msowoya responded to the murmurs by saying since Chakwera is also an MP, he also has the right to ask question Said the Speaker: "I don't see anything that members should be excited about here. The honorable member has a constituency and people he represents. It is normal for him to ask questions."
Chakwera asked the ministry to upgrade a community day secondary school (CDSS) in this constituency to a full secondary school. 
He asked, "Would the ministry consider Kasiya CDSS to a full conventional secondary school, and also providing facilities to Kapudzama and Malembo CDSS, particularly for girls, taking into account the size of constituency geography as well as population?"
popuistion? In response, Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Emmanuel Fabiano, who was answering on behalf of the responsible minister, said the request was noted and that when funds are available, things will improve.

Title: ACB grills Atupele, he maintains innocence
Content: Fromer minister of Lands Atupele Muluzi has said he as summoned to the Anti – Corruption Bureau (ACB) as a witness in an investigation into allocation of two plots in Lilongwe. He said this yersteday after spending two and a half hours at ACB Headquarters in where he was questioned about allocation of plots Numbers Bwaila 13/127 and 13/128 in Lilongwe. After the questioning, Muluzi appeared calm and spoke to the crowd that had escorted him. He said; “You very well know that l follow the law and l am a firm believer of the rule of law. So, l availed myself to meet ACB officials so that l could answer some questions as a witness. “ACB should not used to victimise innocent people. That is the message that these [ supporters ] people are sending. But for me, as Atupele, l walk freely because l did not do anything wrong, or something suspicious.” However, his appearance at ACB  offices was not without controversy, as the supporters, some clad in United Democratic Front attire, tried to block him from entering the bureau’s premises. When he arrived at around 1.55 pm for the 2pm scheduled meeting, his supporters blocked him while chanting and shouting that Atupele, son to the former president Bakili Muluzi, will not enter the ACB offices. Rights activist Bon Kalindo seized the moment to rally the supporters not to allow their leader to pass through the gate.  He said; “Atupele Muluzi is not a thief. We know who thieves are in the government. We will not allow him to go there untill real thieves who mess up the Affordable Inputs Programme [API] by spending K170 million on a dubious fertiliser supplier are called here.” After some time, Atupele reappeared from his Toyota Land Cruiser Prado which was sandwiched between Land cruiser Prado and a Toyota Fortuner, to calm the situation. He went into the ACB office at around 2.25pm and shortly, thereafter, a group pf Police Mobile force arrived on the scene to bring order. They waited until Muluzi come out of the meeting.  Catholic University of Malawi head political studies Chimwemwe Kandodo deplored the behaviour of Atupele’s supporters, saying people need to know that institutions like the ACB are guided by the law and must left to do their job. She said; “We should not smile on this, it is bad. After all, the ACB simply invites people to question them on what they suspect. Let the full process of the law take its course. “If they are clean, they will be let to go, if not, the law will follow them. Politicians have to be in the forefront telling their supporters that such a process is legal.” Centre for social Accountability and Transparency executive director Willy Kambwandira agreed that such incidents are regrettable. “We want to end corruption, but we are using politics to uphold the vice – Malawians doing this should be ashamed of themselves,” he said. The plots ACB summoned Atupele for appear on the list of properties that the agency placed under a restriction order on December 23 2021 in connection with investigations linked to United Kingdom based businessperson Zuneth Satter. In its December 23 2021 restriction notice. ABC stopped the Ministry of Lands from dealing with properties which it believed Satter, who is under probe over some procurement contract with Malawi Government, has beneficial interest. On December 31, 2021, another former minister of Lands Kezzie Msukwa was arrested alongside Sattar associate Ashok Nair in connection with similar land issues, but the duo is challenging the arrest. The matter is with the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court is expected to determine the admissibly of foreign obtained evidence.
The second respondent is ordered to cover the costs incurred by the petitioners in this case.

Title: POET, JB COLLABORATE ON WOMEN’S DAY PROJECT
Content:
Former president Joyce Handa has collaborated with poet Tendai Shaba on a poetry project as part of commemorating this year's International Women's Day . In a joint statement announcing the project, the two said it was important for them to work together to balance the act of addressing gender gaps that exist in the country. "The audiovisual of the poem will be released on March 17003, reads the statement in part. Titled “No One Left Behind” the poem features Banda emphasizing, the importance of addressing gender gaps while Shabe recites the entire poem. She said "Special efforts are still required for us to see meaningful change There are still critical gaps in equality that have left millions of women and girls behind. In an interview yesterday, Shaba said it is important to close any gender gaps in our society. Dr Banda and I have a beautiful working relationship. She is flexible with new ideas. She reaches out whenever she's working on her projects for my creative input," he said. The former president opens the poem with a narration addressing gender gaps. He said working with Banda is always memorable. 
"She has so much wisdom to share and she's a down-to earth person. She always has something to say and speaks her mind. She demands excellence, and so do 1, which makes our working relationship easy. "It's important to use artistic talent to advocate form and educate your audience on global societal issues," said Shaba 
The poem will be made available for download and streaming next month.

Title: PPPC takes stock of digital skills projects
Content:
The Public Private Partnership Commission (PPPC) has said the digital Skills and Innovation Initiative under the Malawi Digital project is making a positive impact towards improving digital skills ad creation of jobs. 
PPPC chief executive officer Patrick Kabambe said this on Friday in Blantyre during and engagement with tech hubs which got $250000(K259 million) grants to train youths and women in digital skills and entrepreneurship as a component under the Malawi Digital Project.
He through six tech hubs, namely Dziko Africa Organisation, Growth Africa, Mhub, Mzuzu E-Hub, Techno Lab and Ntha Foundation, the project, which seeks to digitally.


 Trepine Private has said the Digital Skills and Innovation Initiative under the Malawi Digital Project is making a positive impact towards improving digital skills and creation of jobs. PPPC chief executive officer Patrick Kabambe said this on Friday in Blantyre during an engagement with tech hubs which got $250 000 (K259 million) grants to train youths and women in digital skills and entrepreneurship as a component under the Malawi Digital Project. He said through six tech hubs, namely Dzuka Africa Organisation, Growth Africa, mHub, Mzuzu E-hub, Techno Lab and Ntha Foundation, the project, which seeks to digitally empower youth in the country, has made positive strides. Said Kabambe: “One of the components of the Digital Malawi Project was providing support to tech hubs to provide digital skills to the youth and women in rural areas.
”What we have seen through the engagement with the tech hubs and beneficiaries is that the project is making a huge impact on job creation and helping the youth in rural areas to be self-reliant.” He said the youth in rural areas are now using digital skills to market their products and create their own employment. “We hope these will go a long way not only in creating jobs, but creating a self-reliant nation”, said Kabambe. He said commission will now undertake a survey to see exact jobs that have been creates, adding that they will be implementing the second phase of the digital skills grants at an estimated budget of $1.25 million(about K1.2 billion) to train extra 3000 youths and women at the end of the program. Dzuka Africa Organisation managing director Dineo Mkwezalamba, whose firm is one of the beneficiary tech hubs, said the project grant has helped to create self-reliant youths and women as well as growing their businesses. He said: “We have to validate 885 youths in seven districts.”
“We have recruited people that have never touched the computer, but are willing to change their lives and start businesses. We have since trained 269 in entrepreneurship and 469 in digital skills training.” Mkwzalamba said they had three-year penetration strategy which has helped them to go into districts. “We have also received 30 computers from the program which have helped us to train the youths,”she said.
The Digital Malawi Project is a $74 million (about K77 billion) World Bank-funded project whose aim is to contribute to a digital transformation. The project, which is being implemented by PPPC also seeks to extend and improve access to critical information and communication technology(ICT) infrastructure for the public and private sectors, improve access to government services and reduce infrastructure costs by providing reliable, fast and adaptive government digital systems that will facilitate provision of e-services, thereby enhancing public service delivery.

Title: JB TELLS GIRLS TO SPEAK UP
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has challenged girls to rise up and speak on issues affecting them. She said this yesterday at the launch of the State of the World Girls report by Plan International Malawi in Lilongwe. Banda said girls in the country are overwhelmed with various challenges, hence, the need for the nation to listen to them and work together in dealing with the challenges. She shared her journey to activism, inspired by her childhood friend who dropped out of school despite her intellect. "That is why I became an activist. To fight for my friend who couldn't complete her education, Banda said. In her remarks, Plan Malawi country director Mwape Mulumbi said it was exciting toe girls engaging in activism more than the past and that Malawi has a conducive environment for girl activists. The launch was held under the theme Girls' Activism and Resourcing.

Title: Atupele blends youth, experience in UDF ticket
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presumptive presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi yesterday picked 65 – year old agriculturalist Dr Godfrey Chapola as his running mate, bending youths with the wisdom that presumably comes with age and experience.  Despite being a political unknown, Chapola was announced as Atupele’s running mate for the May 20 Tripartite Elections at a press briefingn held in Lilongwe yesterday.  While the choice of a number two who comes from the Centra Region could be a strategy to pick some votes under the nose of Malawi Congress Party (MCP) since Chapola comes from Lilongwe, the move could help favourably project Atupele as serious about governing effectively. But given that Dr. Lazarus Chakwera, the presumptive nominee of MCP – traditionally string in the Centre – also comes from Lilongwe, it remains unclear how such a face – off would pan out. Chapola's lack of name recognition outside elites of the tobacco and Agri – business industries may also be a minus. Atupele said the choice of Chapola was made after rigorous consultations within the party using several criteria,among them commitment and visionary. However, membership in the party was not one of the criteria as Chapola has no known history as a UDF cadre, which the UDF leader brushed aside as inconsequential. “There was a shortlist of people which the National Executive committee [NEC] considered and developed a consensus . This was a collective decision by the [NEC],” Atupele said. He said in Chipola, UDF has found an individual who would help in running government, harnessing the collective good of the nation and who  is committed to the public service. Commenting on the choice of Chapola as a son of T/A Kalumbu, Lilongwe, Muluzi said the party was looking to build a team that could deliver to Malawians irrespective of regions. Chapola's age 65 to Muluzi’s 35, it is a “fusion of the young and the wise” according to Atupele. He believes it will be an exciting combination in the run – up to the election. “The older generation brings in a lot of wisdom and experience while the younger generation understands the future,” Atupele said of his running mate. Chapola is the general manager of Rumark, an agricultural organisation working to expand agro dealership in Malawi. The married father pf four holds a PhD obtained from Florida, United States. He has previously served as general manager pf Tobacco Control Commission (TCC), deputy director of Aret and general manager of Tobacco Research Institute of Malawi before that.

Title: APM, JB in Verbal Tirade
Content: Former president Joyce Banda and her predecessor Petet Muthaka continue to engage in a verbal war over their alleged past flaws. This time around, the "fight" began after Mutharika, who defeated Bande in the 2014 Presidential Election, during public rally in Mangochi on Saturday called his predecessor Abiti Cash gate, implying that she was at the center of the plunder of public resources at Capital Hill 2013. He further accused her of ruining Malawi's economy. He said: "Monge mukudziwa 2014, tinamuchotsa m'boma chuma chinali chovunda kwambiri koma ife tinachikonza. (You will recall that in 2014, we took over government after kicking out Abiti Cash gate, the economy was very bad, but we fixed it) Meanwhile, Mutharika's remarks have riled People's Party (PP) which through its spokesperson Ackson Kalaile Banda yesterday described him as "a clueless, incompetent and untruthful leader. He accused Mutharika of engaging in corruption with a local businessperson to corruptly influence business links. In apparent reference to a case currently in court on alleged abuse of Mutharika's duty free import privileges through importation of K5 bin worth of cement, Banda said PP will resist the temptation to brand him ‘Mr. Cement.’ He said: "We will continue to resist the temptation to call him Mr. Cement. He must quickly accept the reality that Malawians booted him out of power because of such. He should, therefore, not mark his return to the political podium with the same pedestrian strategy that cost him the presidency in 2020.”  Banda said PP has learnt with disdain repeated provocation by Mutharika, who allegedly makes unsubstantiated scathing remarks towards its leader. He said issues surrounding Cashgate have and continue to be dealt with by law enforcement agencies and Malawi’s trusted legal frameworks, adding that Joyce Banda was cleared of any involvement in the scandal. Banda said : “Nine years down the line, suspects have been arrested and prosecuted, some have been convicted while others have been acquitted following a due court process. The Baker Tilly independent investigative audit, which her excellency’s government commissioned, found no single evidence of her involvement in Cashgate.”  “Muntharika may wish to be reminded that during his reign, the ACB (Anti-Corruption Bureau) exonerated Dr. Joyce Banda from any involvement in Cashgate, despite his government’s ill intentions to exact mob justice on her.” When contacted, Muntharika’s spokesperson Shadric Namalomba said he did not want to comment on “mediocrity”. “Our president did not mention any name. He did not mention Joyce Banda. She wants to be relevant. She wants to be a giant by picking on a president who is a performer. I don’t think I should comment on that,” he said.
Author: Precious Kumbani

Content: UN, UK to fund fresh elections Malawi now can heave a sigh of relief as the United Nations (UN) and the United Kingdom (UK) have indicated that they are ready to fund May 19 2020 fresh presidential elections.

Title: ELDRERLY, CHILD NUTRITION MATTER
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has emphasized that Malawians need to put much effort in elderly people and children's nutrition securities, she made the sentiments last Tuesday at Domasi in Zomba when she provided nutritious porridge flour to community-based childcare centers (CBCCs) as well as maize to the elderly people headed families. Banda said Malawians should develop the spirit of boosting nutrition status of others amidst hunger in the country saying healthy people are the pillars of development. "The elderly, children and other people suffering from various chronic diseases need supplementary food to be nutritious," she said. Florida Mtunduwatha, a mother whose children benefited from the exercise sais lack of sufficient and nutritious foods may lead to malnutrition among the children. She observed that apart from giving them continued food relief, they should also be supported with farm inputs like maize seed and fertilizer for winter cropping. "This will help us to produce enough food for our own consumption and sell the excess," she said. Group village head Mtogolo said Malawi needs sustainable agricultural technologies to be food secured. "Winter-cropping stimulates food and financial freedom," he said.

Title: I WILL WIN IN 2025 – APM
Content:
Former President Peter Mutharika Yesterday declared his intentions to make another shot at his presidency at saying he will contest on September 16, 2025, General Elections and will win to save Malawians from Economic hardships. In his address during a rally dubbed blue Sunday held under the theme “Making Malawi Better Again” he said a Party (DPP) supporters and others that the Tomae Alliance, which oasted him in the June 23 2020 -perudnial election, has gives Malawi raw deal. He said her wald fix the economy within the first two Mutharika said her had takes clove to a year to decide on calls by DPP enters for huntocenestar the convention because be monded to consult his family and others He said "Following the consultations and advice, I will contest at the DPP convention, and I will be on the presidential ballot.  In 2025 and I will win again! I want to tell Malawians that they should not feel discouraged because God has not abandoned us. We think that if we can come back to the government, we can resolve the problems Malawians ar facing in two years." Mutharika cited increased cost of washing slow and weak interventions to food insecurity during lean anon, what he called "economic mismanagement and selective justice in fighting corruption as some of the failures of the Tonse Alliance administration led by President Lazarus Chakwera. Ironically, the Tonse Alliance also rude on the platform of discrediting Mutharika's administration on almost the same shortfalls, including corruption to boot him out.  The 83-year-old said the current administration was arresting OPP members whale Malawi Congress Party (MCP) politicians linked to alleged corrupt acts are left scot-free.  Mutharika vowed that once in power in 20025, he will take action against those looting State coffers but are not being prosecuted.  On nepotism which his administration was equally faulted for, he said "The current administration is only applying people from the Central Region and loans under National Economic Empowerment Fund [Neef) are only being given to people from the Central Region. "We want a better Malawi for all people in the country, not just one family, region or tribe,". But Minister of information and Digitization Moses Kunkuyu, who is also the official government spokesperson, said Mutharika sounded bitter, and his tone reminded Malawians of how absent he was when he was in office. "When he mentioned nepotism, he only reminded us of a whole government set up from one region, when he talked about corruption, he only helped us remember the cement gate, escom and many others," he said.  

The rally was attended by a horde of DPP members of Parliament (MPs) as well as Mzimba North legislator Yeremia.

Title: K394bn needed for digital education
Content:
Ministry of Education says it needs K394 billion to fully implement digitisation to expand access to education nationwide. Speaking yesterday at Mponela in Dowa where Civil Society  Education Coalition (Csec), in partnership with other civil society organisations, held a budget engagement meeting with members of Parliament (MPs), the ministry's director of Science, Technology and Innovation Chomora Mikeka said government planned to scale up digital education so that it covers all schools and benefits more learners. He said Malawi needs to catch up with what other countries are doing in the use of technology in the education sector. Mikeka said: "It is important to do so because we want to have expanded access to education so that everyone else is being reached out to have opportunity for education.
"This will be useful even  in the times of pandemics as we have seen, but also climatic tragedies as we are seeing with Tropical Storm Ana, Damuco and Gombe." He said digital laboratories and libraries would be set up and that equipment  such as computers, smartphones, tablets and others would also be bought to enable learners use digital platforms. Government is promoting the education technology (Ed-Tech) as one of the measures to expand access to education, improve its quality and promote use of technology in the country. The process started in 2021 and is being implemented in phases. Mikeka said to fully implement the programme, Malawi Government would need K394 billion. He admitted that raising the amount would not be easy and that there will be need for joint efforts to meet the target. "To kick-start the plans, the ministry needs K2 billion, but government has only allocated K581 million. The program is planned to be implemented in phases and it was rolled out in 2021," he said. Parliamentary Committee on Education chairperson Brainax Kaise said digital education was key to promoting quality education Malawi; hence, the need to promote it. He said the committee would help lobby for  funding to ensure that  digital education is implemented. Csec program manager Kisa Kumwenda hailed MPs for showing  commitment to lobby for  funding for the project.  "Education is key to development and must be supported," he said.

Content:
Former United Democratic Front (UDF) president Bakili Muluzi has strongly backed the party’s decision to invite the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) to its convention, currently underway at comesa Hall in Blantyre.
Muluzi expressed dismay over divisions within the party due to the decision, emphasizing that UDF’s policy since its formation has been to invite registered political parties to its conventions.
“As a democratically constituted political party, udf should not be a source of hatred or divisions,” he stressed.
Days prior, organizing committee chairperson Aisha Adams resigned but later reversed her decision after the party agreed not to invite MCP.

Title: Atupele under fire
Content:
Public affair committee (PAC) and political analyst have faulted United Democratic Front (UDF) leader Atupele Muluzi for using religion and tribe to discredit other candidates in the campaign ahead of July 2 presidential election. But UDF spokesperson Ken Ndanga has defended Muluzi, saying he did nothing wrong. 
During a whistle – stop campaign tour in Chiradzulu kast week, Muluzi, who is also running mate to President Petet Mutharika in the governing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and UDF Alliance, claimed that the late Malawi Police Service Superintendent Usumani Imedi was killed during protests at Msundwe last year because we was a Muslim from Mangochi. Said Mulizi; “Ngati akupanga zimenezi ali kotsutsa, nanga atatenga boma zitha kukhala bwanji? Zikhoza kudzachitika chani  muno m’malawi? Ine amayi ndi abambo ndine Msilamu. Panali wa police, Imedi, sergeant Imedi, amagwira ntchito yake bwinobwion. Anangopeza kuti ooh Msilamu, wa ku Mangochi, kumupha mopanda chisoni . Izi zakhala zikuchitika miyezi 10 yapitayi.” [If they are committing these atrocities while in opposition, what more if they get into the government? What will happened in Malawi? Ladies and gentlemen, l am a Muslim. There was a police officer Imedi, he was discharging his duties professionally. But when they discovered that he was a Muslim from Mangochi, they killed him. These things have been happening in the last 10 months]. A video clip of the message has also gone viral on social, PAC has since demanded that Muluzi must apologise to the nation for remarks, branding them unfortunate and divisive. In an interview yesterday spokesperson for the quasi – religious group Bishop Gilford Matonga said Muluzi’s remarks are not only worrisome, coming from someone who is seeking the high office of State vice – president.  He said; “We condemn greatly whoever uses religion for campaign. By saying that, Muluzi is bringing the country into conflict. “If he was to be the country’s vice – president, is he going just to be VP for Chiradzulu and Mangochi only? Such kind of cheap and dirty politics must be condemned.” Matonga also called on politicians to focus on issue – based campaign and avoid cheap politics which will not develop Malawi but only bring chaos. Political and administrative studies lecturer at University of Malawi’s Chancellor College Mustafa Hussein, in a separate interview said Muluzi’s conduct is surprising as he has been advocating for an issue – based campaign. He said; “ we did not expect this from the young Muluzi. Some countries like Rwanda and Burundi have had wars because of ethnic differences and it is unfortunate that Muluzi is using such dirty tricks to campaign. He must be condemned.” Another Chancellor College – based political analyst Ernest Thindwa said Muluzi’s calling on people to rise against each other based on tribal and religious differences, which is not expected from someone seeking a high office. He said; “This is someone vying for a big office, and you expect him to rise above regional, ethnic or religious inclination. He has to be a national builder. These are not the kind of political leaders Malawi needs.” Adding his voice to Muluzi’s conduct, journalist Mallick Mnella, a Muslim, said it was disappointing to hear Muluzi single out the death of one Muslim brother when he could have raised several names. He observed; “I recall Issa Njauji who was killed while working for the Anti -Corruption Bureau. He was of immense contribution to Islam. Would Mr. Muluzi, a politician, mentioned Njauju’s death? My heart is too heavy to write about Kalonga Stambuli. He, too, was a Muslim.” Meanwhile, UDF’s Ndanga has defended Muluzi’s actions, saying only those who took part in the killing of Imedi must be worried. He said; “Anybody who feels bitter with that statement must take himself or herself as a culprit. “For example, l am a Christian and l have killed anybody, why should l be worried?” Imedi. Who came from Mawuni Village, Traditional Authority (T/A) Makanjira in Mangochi, was stoned to death by an irate mob oblivious of his faith while on duty at Msundwe on the outskirt of Lilongwe City along Lilongwe – Mchinji Road, where police were deployed to quell violence.

Title: Atupele promises wealth creation
Content: United Democratic Front presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi says he will ensure that Malawians are economically independent if he wins in the May 20 Tripartite Elections. Muluzi said this on Sunday at a rally he held at Dickson Trading Centre in Lilongwe. Muluzi, who was accompanied by his running mate Godfrey Chapola and party vice – president Iqbar Omar, said most Malawians have no money for basic needs, “Despite living in an independent nation, many Malawians are not financially independent. Few Malawians are enjoying wealth in this nation while the rest of Malawians are financially struggling. My government will come up with deliberate ways to enable people to have money and develop their lives,” he said.

Title: Chakwera wants transformational politics
Content:
Malawi congress party (MCP) president Lazarus Chakwera says the Partys followers can help in restoring the pride the country used to have in sustaining food security and inclusive development.
Chakwera said this during a whistle stop tour MCP had in Zomba city, Chingale, Jali, Liwonde and during a public lecture at Chancellor College.
He said MCP is ready to take Malawians to another level because it has in the pipeline a national development plan which can be ascribed to by everyone.
‘’We know that the country has plans on paper, but everyone else only emphasizes on what they think is right for them.
‘’So, I am talking about how we can make agriculture such a big business by ensuring that everyone across the board has access to farm inputs.
‘’This will put to rest the habit of perpetual hunger being experienced time and again,’’ he said.
On the other hand, Chakwera said there is need to recapitalize the education system by building on the existing infrastructures and institutions with the provision of resources that have a broad spectrum of services for the youth.
In his hour-long address Chakwera said certain things in the education sector needed to be restructured so as to have young people who can be trained in various competence and make them a driving force of the economic development.
‘’Let us invest education in the youth and l have people who can make decisions based on knowledge so that they are not oppressed or deliberately put in the dark those that do not know anything,’’ he said.
He added that since the days of the former president the late Hastings Kamuzu Banda, the University of Malawi (Unima) has never been recapitalized, arguing government cannot go business as usual without strengthening the systems that were already laid down.
‘’We do not want a university graduate that would look for somebody to employ him or her. We can ger partners for you because a university degree is not just good for the capital Hill only,’’ said Chakwera.
Author: Joy Kakhona

Title: Atupele says 2014 elections game changer
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi yesterday electrified the hype for the May 20 elections when his party literally painted Blantyre City yellow as he presented nomination papers to the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC). Atupels arrived at the Comesa Hall in a fleet of yellow Hummer vehicles mobbed by a sea of thousands of UDF supporters clad in the party’s colour who virtually closed the Masauko Chioembere Highway stretch Between the Polytechnic and Kamuzu Stadiuma Roundabout. Atupele submission of the presidential nomination papers was followed by Aaron Davis Katsonga of Chipani cha Pfuko (CCP) whose supporters dressed in green T-shirts. Kasonga’s supporters, the smallest group so far, mobbed him as he made his way into the hall. MEC chairperson Maxon Mbendera, who is a Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal judge, explained to the respective candidates that despite presenting them with candidency certificates, the commission shall proceed to scrutinise their papers and “we shall declare you duly nominated or otherwise seven days after the receipt of the last nomination papers.” After the processes. Atupele said the May 20 elections signify a milestone for Malawi. He described the elections as a game changer. “Malawians go to the polls with a lot of expectations. These elections are a game changer. Malawians should speak through the ballot,” said Atupele, attracting a chorus of whistling and ululating from his supporters. “The United Democratic Front’s agenda for change is well aligned with what Malawians want. We are in a position to shape our position and this should be done now,” Katsonga in an interview said it is a relief that his party submitted the nomination papers and looked forward to the elections. Inside the hall, Katsonga expressed fears that there are plans to rig the elections. He reiterated his stand in an interview, saying; “We can’t take chances, rigging does take place.” Ironically, Katsonga’s brother, Mark Katsonga Phiri of People’s Progressive Movement (PPM) also presented his nomination papers on Tuesday. The duo’s father, the Christian Liberation Party which contested and lost the country’s pre – independency general elections in 1961 to the Malawi Congress Party (MCP). The official campaign for the May 20 election starts on March 21.

Title: JB URGES WOMEN TO  WORK HARD
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has urged women in the country to work hard and find means to generate their own income instead of depending on their spouses. She made the call on Monday in Mangochi where Ar-terreequate Quadriyya Sunni(Aqua) handed over 80 sewing machines to 80 women who compeleted a six-month training. The only way we can movee forward as a nation is to find other ways of generating money. I urge you to be focused on tailoring other than continuing to depend on your spouses to provide for everything," said Banda. The former president also hailed Aqsa for introducing the tailoring program saving it was a step in the right direction towards women's economic empowerment Banda appealed to public and private instituitions to provide the women with an opportunity to supply tailored material to instituitions Aqsa national coordinator Sheskik Fahad Zahid Muhammad asked district councils to facilitate the creation of women's groups to get loans for business. The sewing machines should not be turned into Tables in your homes but use them for the inteded purpose, said Muhammed A trainee. Memory Frank said she has always wanted to economically independent, and the sewing machine will help her realise the dream.

The independent public inquiry into the plane crash is not just a matter of accountability; it is a necessity for healing. Families affected by this tragedy deserve answers and reassurance that their loved ones did not perish in vain.
Additionally, the allegations surrounding the Malawi Energy Regulatory Authority (MERA) involving a staggering one trillion kwacha debt demand immediate attention. Such claims, if substantiated, could have dire implications for the nation’s economy and public trust in governance.
An open dialogue about these matters will not only illuminate the truth but also help restore faith in leadership.
Moreover, the alleged sale of Likoma Island and the controversial procurement deal at NOCMA raise further questions about transparency and integrity within the government.
Citizens must be assured that their resources are handled with the utmost care and accountability.
President Chakwera has an opportunity to use this moment to reinforce his commitment to good governance by engaging with the public, transparently addressing these allegations, and outlining concrete steps towards reform.
It is time for leadership to step forward, confront these issues head-on, and demonstrate that the voices of the people are heard and valued. Our nation deserves a leader who prioritizes integrity, transparency, and justice for all.

Title: Ministry for increased Internet access
Content:
Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu says his ministry is geared to see enhanced Internet access in the country.
He said it is proven globally that countries that have developed their economies, have done so on the strength of advanced Information and communications technology (ICTs) that provide a fertile ground for social economic development.
Kunkuyu said this on Thursday after meeting officials from Open Connect Limited (OCL), who paid a courtesy call to brief him on their operations in the counton
He said: "Information and communications technology have great promise to reduce poverty, increase productivity, boost economic growth, and improve accountability and governance.”
 The minister further said improving access to the internet will, among others, help the country with facts and figures, information and knowledge for personal, social and economic development.
 He disclosed that through ICT projects such as Last Mile Rural Connectivity, enhancement and Digital Malawi, access to fast and affordable Internet will be realized.
 OCL chief executive officer Sandile Dhlomo said they are constructing a tier three data Centre in Malawi, a primary data Centre in Lilongwe and a secondary data Centre in Blantyre.
OCL is an open access wholesale telecommunications company, offering carrier that services telecommunication companies, ISPs, broadcasters and government with over 5000 kilometers of fibre spread across 24 districts in the country.
According to 2023 State of Digital Access in Malawi Report 24.4 percent of Malawi’s population has access to the Internet, leaving out close to 75.6 percent unconnected.
