Title: LIKOMA ISLAND NOT ONLY FOR CASINO BUT ALSO MINING
Content:
Ministry of Tourism through the press release has admitted the intention of developing Likoma Island to an iconic Tourism Center. An official release signed by the Principal Secretary Mr Chauncy Simwaka has clarified several issues concerning the Likoma sale.
Among other things the Ministry has stressed that the island is not yet sold as it was previously speculated. The ministry has assured the general public that it will do all necessary public consultation before coming up with the way forward.
According to the press release one of potential investors is interested to transform the island into a Casino, mine precious unmentioned mineral deposits and agriculture. The investor needs a land lease for 99 years years among others.

High Court Judge Justice Dorothy Nyakaunda Kamanga, has called for an interpate hearing on Thom Mpinganjira's Zomba file at 2 pm today. Zomba Magistrate, Ben Chitsakamire, cancelled Mpinganjira's warrant of arrest obtained by the Anti Corruption Bureau at the Lilongwe Magistrates Court, an order which Judiciary Registrar Agnes Patemba described as irregular. Mpinganjira was arrested last week for allegedly being part of the team which planned to bribe judges hearing the elections case. Patemba has confirmed the meeting saying it will be held in the chamber.
Author: Jameson Chauluka

Title: PAC reminds Chakwera of promises
Content:
Public Affairs Committee (PAC) yesterday faulted president Lazarus Chakwera for not living up to his promise to appoint a lean Cabinet.
The quasi-religious body has since challenged Chakwera to revisit the Cabinet by Trimming it to 20 or less as per his earlier promise.
PAC chairperson Patrick Thawale made the remarks during a closed-door meeting PAC members held with Chakwera at Kamuzu Palace in Lilongwe yesterday.
But Chakwera said the promise was made in the context 2014 and 2019 elections when he was contesting alone.
Last month, Chakwera appointed his first full Cabinet comprising 23 full ministers and eight deputies drawn from the Tonse Alliance membership which comprises his Malawi Congress Party, UTM Party and seven others parties.
According to a statement shared by PAC of Thawale speech, the chairperson reminded the president that in 2014 and 2019, PAC shared with him 19 issues, including cabinet size and composition for which Chakwera gave an assurance of a lean Cabinet membership of between 14 and 20.
He said: ‘’While we appreciate that there are several parties operating under Tonse Alliance, PAC suggest that you revisit the size of the Cabinet. Your approach to appointment of Cabinet members may have left a dent in your administration.’’
In a telephone interview, State House director of information and executive assistant to the president Sean Kampondeni said Chakwera’s response to the concern was that the June 23 presidential election affected some MCP promise as this around, the President went to the polls in partnership with eight others parties.
He said: ‘’One of the implications of operating under a alliance is the amendment of governance blueprint to bring the strength of multiple players.’’
Earlier, Chakwera also acknowledged public grievances over his Cabinet selection and pledged to review it after five months.
However, PAC commended Chakwera for regular updates on efforts the government is making to fight Covid-19 and to deal with corruption.
Other issues discussed during the meeting included public sector, electoral and constitutional reforms and religious tolerance.
Author: NTCHINDI MEKI

Title: Embrace  digitalization in all sectors -Kunkunyu
Content: Ministry of Information and Digitization Moses Kunkuyu says Malawi needs to embrace digitalization as a tool to measure the way government is performing in various sectors. He said this on Thursday during the launch of the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) Inclusive Digital Economy Scorecard, a strategic tool to measure and track the level of development of an inclusive digital economy. Said Kunkuyu: "As government, we need to see such we agricultural heath and education, among others through such a tool.” UNCDF digital finance country specialist Iris Kissit said in the wake of a digital transformation across the globe, everyone should embrace digitalization. She said:"Malawi is scoring high in infrastructure policy but what needs to happen is to revert digital retail and place infrastructure in place to encourage and innovate skills within the population.” The UNCDF is the UnitedNations flagship catalytic financing entity for the world's 46 least developed countries (LDCs). Its purpose is to invest and catalyse capital to LDCs sustainable growth.

Title: Faith leaders engaged on cyber security
Content: Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu has urged religious leaders in the country to support government in protecting communities from cyberattacks that are becoming common on social media platforms. He said this during a faith leader's conference organised by Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority (Macra) in Mangochi on Tuesday. "As you know, there are many good things associated with social media platforms. However, there are also fraud activities taking place online where people make phone calls pretending to be from banks and from service providers when they are ordinary people who intend to dupe others." Macra director of broadcasting Zadziko Mankhambo said a lot of Malawians are losing millions of money to cybercrime. He, however, said the authority is acquiring equipment to help identify people involved in the malpractice.
Author: Bishop Witmos

Title: KUMPOTO NDI KU CHIPINDA CHA DPP | MUTHALIKA
Content:
Mtsogoleri wa chipani cha DPP Prof Peter Muthalika wati iye wafika mchigawo Cha ku mpoto kuzacheza osati kuzapanga ndale. Mtsogoleriyu wati chipani cha DPP sichikufunika kupanga campaign mchigawochi chifukwa akuziwa kuti mavoti onse ndi a DPP.
Mtsogoleriyu anakumbutsa anthu omwe anali pa roundabout ya ShopRite kuti mchaka Cha 2009 anapeza ma MP 28 ndipo Chaka chino apeza ma MP onse 38 mchigawochi. Iye wati wauza akuluakulu achipanichi a Hon Mzemera Ngwira komanso Hon Jappie Mhango kuti agwire ntchito imeneyi.
Paliso kusamvana pakati chipani cha DPP komanso MCP pomwe chipani cha DPP chikufuna chipani Cha MCP chitayimitsa msonkhano wake omwe uchitikile ma kilometer okwana 10 kuchoka pamalo omwe DPP ichitisire.
 Hon Jappie Mhango anapempha chipani Cha MCP kuti asinthe tsiku la msonkhano popewa ziwawa. Koma Mneneri wachipani cha MCP wati ngati chipani sanalandire Chikalata Cha dandaulo kotero msonkhano upitilira.

The Catholic Church has urged Malawians to respect whatever ruling the constitutional court will make on the presidential elections case. Mzuzu Diocese Bishop, John Ryan, said it is imperative for the country’s citizens to abide by the rule of law at all times, which is essential in the consolidation of democratic principles and good governance.
Author: Feston Malekezo

Title: Schools to reopen early September-Chakwera
Content:
President Lazarus Chakwera has said schools that will meet set covid-19 requirements will open early September. In his national address monitored on local radio stations last night, the president said he was thankful to God that despite  the number of people found with covid-19 virus passing the 5 000 mark, only percent have been serious cases that required hospitalisation. 
‘’Even among the 389 health workers who have contracted the Virus, we have lost only one and the rest are in recovery. I thank God for this.
‘’Secondly, I thank our health workers for continuing to defend us from the virus with  their expertise in matters of prevention and treatment. Because of their efforts, over 37 000 have now been tested,’’ said Chakwera. 
The president also thanked members of the presidential Task Force on covid-19 for their work of coordinating and spearheading efforts to fight against the spread.
Author: FRANK NAMANGALE

Title: MACRA WARNS AGAINST SHARING GRAPHIC MATERIAL
Content: The Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority (Macra) has warned the public against sharing of graphic material related to the plane crash that led to the death of Vice-President Saulos Chilima and eight others. Macra director general Daud Suleman said in a statement yesterday that the circulation of sensitive material is deeply concerning and can cause further distress to the families of the victims. He said: "This is a devastating time for the nation, and we must honor the memory of the victims with the utmost dignity and respect," Macra is mandated under Section 97 of the Electronic Transactions and Cybersecurity Act to promote public education on safe and responsible online behavior, including cyber hygiene, Chilima and eight others were found dead on Tuesday in Mzimba after their plane went missing on Monday on its way to Mzuzu.
Author: The Nation

Content: Lawyer Lusungu Gondwe of Ritz Attorneys obtained the court order from a Zomba magistrate, releasing businessman Thom Mpinganjira from police custody and cancelling the ACB's warrant of arrest. It was not lawyer Frank Mbeta, as originally reported. According to ACB Director General Reyneck Matemba, the confusion occurred after Police Inspector General Duncan Mwapasa mistakenly mentioned Mbeta when informing him about the Zomba court's order. Matemba has now confirmed that the order was obtained by Ritz Attorneys, represented by Lusungu Gondwe. We apologize for the error.
Former President Joyce Banda stated that the People’s Party is ready to collaborate with MCP President Lazarus Chakwera to improve the lives of Malawians.

Content: The anti-MEC demonstrations in Mangochi have concluded, with Human Rights Defenders Coalition representatives presenting their grievances to town council officials. HRDC Mangochi representative, Sheikh Allie Time, expresses satisfaction with the peaceful manner of the demonstrations. After a slow start, attendance increased significantly, although there were concerns about individuals trying to disrupt the demonstrations. Time mentions that protests will continue until MEC officials resign. Both town council officials and the police officer in charge of Mangochi, Joseph Muthupa, commend the demonstrators for their peaceful approach.
Author: Yohane Symon

Content:
Former Malawi President Bakili Muluzi made a surprise declaration of interest in competing for the United Democratic Front (UDF) presidency at the party’s elective convention, but quickly retreated, citing his age and the “sharp” young leaders.
Speaking at Comesa Hall in Blantyre on Wednesday, Muluzi said, “I called the secretary-general yesterday telling him that I want to compete as president for UDF at the convention… but I realize that this fresh blood will boot me out easily, I can’t compete with the young ones, they are sharp.”

Title: Muluzi donated K3 million to referral hospitals
Content:
United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi has called on politicians, businesspeople and other stakeholders to raise money towards running of referral hospitals in Malawi, arguing government has failed to run the hospitals. 
Muluzi made the call on Sunday in Mzuzu when he launched UDF manifesto and campaign in the Northern Region, He bemoaned shortage of drugs and other medical equipment being experienced in central hospitals. Muluzi, therefore, donated K3 million to Kamuzu, Queen Elizabeth and Mzuzu central hospitals from his campaign budget and called on other politicians to do the same. “I will have to cancel two or three rallies to help the hospitals. To lead by example, l am giving K1 million to Mzuzu Central Hospital, K1 million to Kamuzu Central Hospital and K1 million to Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. “We cannot be on road all the time and it is sad to see people travelling, wasting fuel when our hospitals are in a bad state. Let us contribute the little we have to help others,” said Muluzi. He added thatg he was shocked to hear that doctors are contributing money to buy drugs for patients when people in the country pay tax. Speaking about his party’s vision, Muluzi promised to promote good governance and ensure developments once he gets into power. He promised enactment of Access to Information Bill and a law that will see Malawians own 20 to 30 percent shares in investments by foreigners.

Title: Former State House ICT chief freed
Content:
The Lilongwe Chief Resident Magistrate's Court yesterday discharged a case in which former head of information, communications and technology (ICT) at State House, Chancy Chingwalungwalu, was being accused of cyber harassment. In the Civil Cause Number 65 of 2023, the State accused him of authoring of an online story which alleged that President Lazarus Chover Me prai ding nep is sapport gain interview yesterday, his lawyer Madalitso Kausi said the case has been discharged because the State failed to provide evidence since his arrest in February this year.
This becomes the second time that a case is discharged for Chingwalungwalu after he was also discharged on April 4 2022 alongside former head of National Intelligence Service (NIS), Kenam Kalirani. In that case, the two were accused of stealing equipment belonging to NIS. It was discharged because the State also failed to provide evidence.
Author: The Nation

Title: JB LOBBIES FOR ADOPTION OF NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT POLICY
Content: Former president Joyce Banda, who is also Peoples Party (PP) torchbearer in the May 21 Tripartite Elections says government needs a national development policy to ensure continuity of development projects despite Changes in governing parties. Speaking at a rally in Nazumbe Primary School Ground in Phalombe, Banda sited an example of the Mudzi Transformation Trust which she said was helping poor people. She said it is worrisome to note that most of the projects left during my time have been abandoned.  We need to take responsibility for our development agenda regardless of political affiliations. In his remarks, Vice-president for the South Ephraim Chibvunde hailed party followers in the area for being loyal to the party saying during her tenure. Banda has demonstrated that she is a visionary leader.

Content:
Former President Professor Peter Mutharika has urged President Lazarus Chakwera’s administration to stop interfering with Lhomwe Chiefs, accusing the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) of forcing them to support the current administration for promotion.
Speaking at Mulhakho Wa Alhomwe’s annual festival in Chonde, Mulanje, Mutharika condemned MCP’s alleged tactics, saying, “Stop forcing chiefs to dance at your political rallies.”
He emphasized that Lhomwe chiefs should be allowed to perform their duties without political pressure.

Title: Usi still UTM leader
Content:
Duties but took a swipe at the veep, hinting that only those present at the rally are the true UTM members. She further stressed that they exited Tonse Alliance becaue they wanted to to influence change, saying UTM could not grow if it is remained in the alliance . Kaliati also said she has information that over one million undeeage children have been registered to vote in the 2025 General Elections. 
She said; UTM party manifesto is what placed the current administration in power. But the Malawi Congress Party had already ended the alliance through their public pronouncements.” 
Seemingly making reference to Usi, UTM party publicity secretary Felix Njawala said a good mother does not look on as her children are being preyed on. 
Political pundit Wonderful  Mkhutche said a section of the party is not convicted with Usi’s leadership. 
“Therefore, he will need more claim to retain the leadership. Some UTM supporters think Dr. Usi has titled towards MCP and UTM enough. His fate is around this. 
“As of now, UTM is now divided into camps. Each camp already has its own way and there is no turning back. But the party should make sure that convention happens credibly to settle the leadership question. Whoever wins there, let him lead the party,” he said. 
On his part, an expert in elective politics Ernest Thindwa said the UTM party top hierarchy has neither endorsed Usi as  the party’s leader nor approved his appointment as State –Vice President. 
“The party needed to have a meeting immediately after the mourning period for the late SKC was concluded with the view to chart the way forward. The fact that the party is yet to meet for such purpose reveals the magnitude of the leadership crisis and divisions for the party is experiencing. 
“The party has been by the  demise of the SKC. The least the party can do is a further weaken the party by contesting the status of the leadership position which can only succeed in the deepening division,” he said . 
Faced with some pockets of resistance, Usi said recently that he is the bonafide UTM Party president following the death of his predecessor Chilima in a military plane crash on June.

Title: Digital entity moves towards self-sustenance
Content:
Malawi Digital Broadcasting Network Limited (MDBNL) chief executive officer Dennis Chirwa says they are working towards becoming financially-independent to reduce government support and operate more effectively.
Speaking in Lilongwe yesterday when Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu toured MDBNL offices, Chirwa said while government is providing financial support to the organisation, this may not be sustainable; hence, pushing for more revenue generation streams.
He said there are plans to facilitate the desired growth for the institution. Said Chirwa: "We have plans to increase our viewership from 64 percent to 80 percent by October this year. We are also working on having some of our channels online so that people can watch on digital platforms. "That way, we should be able to make more returns from traffic that may be on our digital platforms. Such funds will automatically add onto what we already are realizing through other streams and help in our operations” The minister’s tour comes after MDBNL equipment was gutted by fire in January of 2020, incurring a K2 billion loss of equipment.
In his remarks, Kunkuyu acknowledged that MDBNL is experiencing challenges that may require government intervention, especially on policy direction.  He however, said the institution plays a critical role in ensuring that citizens are more informed. “In terms of policy direction as well as financing , we as government will come in as soon as we can in order to help them operate ably,” said Kunyuku. MDBNL is a public entity mandated to provide signal distribution services to licensed broadcasters. It was registered under the Companions Act in February 2014 but started its operations in July 2015. There are 18 channels on the MDBNL platform, eight of which are already being tested on online streaming platforms.
Author: Jacob Nankhonya

Title: MARY CHILIMA URGES MUSLIM WOMEN TO BE PRAYERFUL
Content:
Madame Mary Chilima, spouse to the Vice-President Saulos Chilima, has advised women in the country to embrace prayer if they are to succeed in life. Speaking at prayers organized by At-Tariqatul Qadiria Sunn Association (Aqsa) Women Dawa Group at Kaliyeka School Ground in Lilongwe on Saturday, she said prayer is critical in the life of women Said Chilima: "Prayer is important in a woman as such, I encourage women to continue praying." She said women should also help their children to grow in a Godly way as many children nowadays are exposed to evil things because of technological advancement. 
Aqsa Women Dawa Group president Alhajja Sakina Pongolani Nanyumba thanked the country's second lady for attending the Dawa prayers. She said Muslim women will take it their responsibility to lead by example.

Title: APM CHEERS MUSLIMS
Content: Former president Peter Mutharika and former first lady Gertrude Mutharika on Thursday attended prayers at Nkali Mosque in Mangochi as the Muslims concluded the Holy Month of Ramadhan. In his Facebook post, Mutharika who lives in his retirement home in Mangochi said he "spared time and visited neighboring Muslim brothers and sisters" where he donated food items for use when celebrating their Eid El Fitr to mark the end of fasting in the month of Ramadhan. "We take this opportunity to wish you our Muslim brothers and sisters in the country all the best as you celebrate Eid El Fitr. We appeal to all Malawians to unite as a sign of solidarity with our Muslim friends," reads the statement on his Facebook page. In the picture, the former first couple makes a symbolic presentation of the donation to representatives of Nkali Mosque.
Author: Andrew Mtupanyama

Title: Chakwera outline vision for Malawi
Content:
Newly elected Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president the Reverend Lazarus Kakwera has said his vision is to restore malawis lost dignity that has for years reduced the country to a begging nation due to lack of strategic direction.
Addressing his first rally at Nchalachala in Kasungu yesterday barely a week after succeeding former party president John Temba, Chakwera challenged Malawians that for this country to develop and move forward with Malawians themselves.
He also said developing Malawi is not about praising party leaders through songs but that all praises should go to the political parties and Malawi as a nation.
Said Chakwera: ‘’The new vision and direction is transforming Malawian lives in all sectors. It is sad that even in the Sadc region, we are the least developed country, but we want by 2020 this country should be able to create a middle-income society.’’
Chakwera was accompanied to the rally by Tembo and four of the other losing presidential aspirants during the party’s convention last week. The losing aspirants present included Former Chief Justice Lovemore Munlo, Former Farmers Union of Malawi President Felix Jumbe, member of parliament Watson Makala Ngozo and Former cabinet minister Jodder Kanjere.
He stressed that his leadership is set to bring both the MCP and Malawi as a nation back on track to realize its dreams and vision.
He said in the last years, Malawi has had brilliant plans such as the Vision 2020 and the millennium Development Goals (MDGs), but all these have failed to bear fruits because of lack of visionally leadership and proper direction.
Chakwera also said the other major problem with the country development path is that each administration comes with its own programmes and pans instead of having a national development plan that could be followed by each administration.
He said Malawi needs a common national vision and agenda if it is to move forward and develop.
‘’it is now fifty years since independence but nothing much has been done in terms fo development. At times we have signs that things are moving only to realise that we are back from where we started.
Why is that the case? This is the question that all of us have to answer,’’ said Chakwera.
He said one of his visions is to transform agriculture to make it into business and enhance agri- based exports, brings equity to the education sector so that both girls and boys as well as people in rural and urban areas have equal access to education, revamp the health a sector and that people should be able to freely do business that can bring them money.
On his party leadership, Chakwera said the new MCP offers hope to the people that have been looking for leadership that is selfless and that would be servant leadership.
He said, We would not want to portray that we are leaders who can ready to provide services and direction so that everyone knows where we are going and where we would want to be.
Author: Bright Sonani

Title: PLANNING COMMISSION AWARDS APM, SPEAKER, OTHERS
Content: The National Planning Commission has awarded Speaker of Parliament Catherine Gotani-Hara, former presidents; Peter Mutharika and his deceased brother Bingu, for playing a key role in the country's development. The commission's board chairperson Professor Richard Mkandawire said the awards are in line with the Malawi 2063 (MW2063) to recognize people who have made significant who have made significant contributions to the country. Speaking when she received the Malawi 2063 Champions Certificate of her office in Tuesday Lilongwe, Gotani Hara said Parliament has a key role to play in the realization of the Malawi 2063, including providing oversight in its implementation. She said "It is a few years now since the vision was launched and it is high time implementers started accounting for what they have done this far We don't want Malawi 2063 to flop like Vision 2020. On Thursday, Mkandawire handed over the Malawi 2063 Champions Certificate to Mutharika at his house in Mangochi. He hailed the two Mutharika brothers, saying they deserve such an honor because they made remarkable contributions to the country.  Said Mkandawire; “Presidents come and go, and development continues and must continue.  What we saw from the two brothers was visionary leadership. "Let me acknowledge late Bingu's credible development initiatives. He was indeed an economist per excellence who made a stellar performance and was part of the genesis of what we call MW2063 today, hence this award, he said.mReceiving the awards Mutharika thanked the commission for recognizing him and his brother. "I am falling to believe it because I was not expecting that one day we would be recognized after running the country. What these awards mean is an indication to us that we performed well, he said. The commission also awarded the Chief Justice Regine Mzikamanda on Friday and founding president Kamuzu Banda on Monday.
Author: Ayamba Kandodo

Title: Chakwera firm on trimming powers
Content:
President Lazarus Chakwera in his radio national address last night reaffirmed his commitment to reducing presidential powers.
Chakwera asked for support from several stakeholders to realise the goal he has set.
Said the president in his radio address statement: ‘’But I think you know by now that I do not say something unless I mean to do it. But to get this done, I need your support. The reduction of presidential powers is a collective efforts.
‘’As such, it is important that we all understand what these powers are. In summary, the presidency has four kinds of powers. The first category of powers a President has is positional.’’
The president said in his jurisdiction, there are certain positions and offers that are reserved for the president alone such as the positions of head of state, Head of Government, and commander.
Author: FRANK NAMANGALE

Title: Take interest in technology, women told
Content:
Salima district commissioner Grace Chirwa Kanyimbiri has encouraged women to take interest in technology because the world has gone digital.
She said this on Monday
during the district's commemoration of the International Women's Day in Kamzimbe Village in Senior Chief Kalonga's
area.
Kanyimbiri said a paradigm shift is needed to harness the potential of technology and innovation to accelerate progress.
"There is a gender gap in digital access. This gap keeps women from unlocking their full potential,” she said.
Kanyimbiri admitted that some women in rural areas have a perception that using digital gadgets comes with a cost, but she said these days even small gadgets have access to the Internet.
JCM Power gender specialists Grace Kaonga, whose company funded the event, said there was a gap in access to technology between men and women 
She said they commemorated the day in their catchment area to appreciate the commendable job that women do in the development of the area.
“We organized the event with the help of the community because the understand this year’s theme that going digital is the only way for Salima District to develop,” said Kaonga.
Senior Chief Kalonga said his area will benefit the projects that provide tele-centers, adding that having such facilities will improve digital access to women.
he said he will encourage women to embrace technology. The event was spiced up with drama performance and a Salima Police Station.
Author: Fostina Mkandawire

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Vice President for the Central region, Alfred Gangata, has launched a scathing attack on President Dr. Lazarus Chakwera’s economic policies, citing skyrocketing debt, youth unemployment, and deepening corruption.
“President Chakwera promised Malawians a host of things but none has materialized apart from corruption which he is championing,” Gangata said at a rally in Kasungu district’s Chithiba ground.
“Malawi has lost enviable ground to other countries due to lack of investment and dedicated policy toward economic transformation and growth.”
Gangata criticized Chakwera’s leadership, stating, “Apart from kissing the sky with his family, what else can you point at Chakwera that he has done for poor Malawians?”

Title: USI REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR CHAKWERA
Content: Days after the UTM Party central committee abandoned. the governing Tonse Alliance. Vice-President Michael Usi says he will work with President Lazarus Chakwera to ensure the late Saulos Chilima's policies are implemented. Speaking at Kameza Roundabout in Blantyre yesterday on arrival from Lilongwe, he said the President has urged him to address issues of provision of maize and business loans to people. Said Usi: "Dr. Chilima wanted people to be having three meals per day and that they should receive loans, these things need to be implemented and when I and the President about them, be told me to go for He also said he has already asked the National Economic Empowerment Fund (Neef) to disburse loans to people in the country and provide him a report in August. During his address to the audience, which included women clad in UTM Party cloth with Chilima's portrait emblazoned on it. Usi did not comment on the status of the alliance, but he said his focus is on developing the country. However, in a thinly veiled reaction to the withdrawal from the alliance penciled by Chakwera and Chilima on Much 20 2020 ahead of the 123 2020 court-sanctioned fresh presidential election, he said he was in control and preparing a dish. He said like a woman who endures the heat while cooking, he won't succumb to pressure. Commenting on the matter, political analyst Wonderful Mkhutche said it was understandable that Usi avoided the issue of the alliance as he is still in suspense regarding his hold on the UTM Party as well as support for his position as the country's Vice-President He, however, sand Usi will still have to face the reality and decide which direction will go. President Chakwera appointed Usi as Vice President on June 20, 2024, following the death of Chilima in the plane crash along with eight others on June 10, 2024. In the nullified 2019 presidential election, Chilima picked Usi as his running mate and, based on the UTM Paty constitution effectively became the party’s vice president.

Title: GOVT MOVES TO IMPROVE DIGITAL LANDSCAPE
Content:
Minister of Information and DigitisationGospelKazakosays government isworking towards bringing down some taxes and formalising the information communication technology (ICT) sector.
The Minister made the remarks yesterday during a business breakfast organised by the ICTAssociation of Malawi (Ictam) to share notes on how to improve the country's digital landscape. Kazako said government wants to ensure that policies and implementation of programs speak to each other and that the private sector is engaged in the melisation of the digital economy. said: "We intend to create te the Malawi Information ology Authority [Mita] to ensure  good coordination in government.
"As we stand, a lot of money is lost because there is no centrality in the way we operate. This will help us know what we have and do not have in the sector. All this is meant to spur uptake of digital services."
Kazako also admitted that some taxes in the sector are a cause for concern and a limiting factor to digitisation, saying government is reviewing these and others to promote the use of digital tools.
Currently, available data indicate that only 13.8 percent of the Malawian population uses the internes. This is despite numerous developments in the sector, including extension of fibre- optic backbone and cross-border interconnections, the launch of 4G, the establishment of the Universal Service Fund whose overall goal was to have the country’s Internet connectivity improve and charges remarkably drop. Despite the initiatives, Malawi still lags behind on Internet connectivity characterized by high charges, low penetration rates and poor service provision, contributing to high  cost of doing business, limited innovation and poor information flow. On his part, Ictam president Bram Fudzulani said the association is keen to assist on the digitisation agenda by focusing on delivering reliable and affordable digital services in the country. “We have agreed to formalize ourselves and form a task force that plays a voluntary advisory role to the ministry on what we think are the best practices that need to be done and policies that need to be implemented so that we create a conducive environment for industry players and that the same tie protect consumers.”
Fudzulani also observed that formulation of Mita will bring in order and will help accelerate the adoption of ICTin the country. Previous studies indicated that taxation, market, and regulatory structures that do not encourage competition also slow down efforts for price reductions in mobile data packages and extension of broadband coverage.
Meanwhile, government is targeting to increase network access for internet usage to 80 percent of the population and broadband coverage to 95 percent of the population by 2026 from the current 13.8 percent.
Author: Orama Chipwanya

Title: UTM YOUTHS IN CANDLELIGHT MEMORIAL IN PHALOMBE
Content: UTM Party youths in Phalombe District have organized prayers and candlelight memorial tomorrow at Phalombe Secondary School from 5pm to 7pm. The event is in honor of the late Saulos Chilima, who until his death on June 10 in a plane crash in Viphya Highlands in Mzimba was the country's vice-president and UTM Party president. In an interview on Wednesday, one of the organizers of Phalombe Priscilla Moniwa confirmed that the event was to honor "a generational hero”. UTM Party secretary moral Patricia Kalliati is expected to be the guest of honor at the event.

Title: ATUPELE PROMISES HOSPITAL IN PHALOMBE
Content: The United Democratic Front (UDF) says once voted into the May 20 Tripartite Elections it will build a district hospital in Phalombe, which despite being upgraded to a district status over 15 years ago.  UDF presidential hopeful Atupele Muluz said this on Saturday when he conducted whistle-stop tours in Phalombe Northeast and Phalombe East constituencies. Atupele said access to good health facilities for Malawians is one of his main priorities and as the country will be celebrating 50 years of independence, the people of Phalombe deserve better just as other people other districts in the country.  "It is saddening to note that after 50 years of self-rule, Phalombe has never had a district hospital. Health is a priority, and every person has a right to good health. It is high time Phalombe had a district hospital as its Neighbour, Chiradzulu," he said  Atupele also said he will remove the coupon system and bring several fertilizer subsidies so that everybody is able to purchase farm inputs.Speaking ar Nambeso Centre ground in Phalombe Northeast Constituency, Group Village Head (GVH) Nambazo commended Atupele for his initiative to mach to the people of the area irrespective of the bad roads. Nambazo commended plans to bring a district hospital to the area and pleaded with him to include a cellphone network tower to the area in his plans for easy communication. Phalombe hospital construction has been a bone of contention since 2010/2011 budget allocation, where over K300 million was reportedly spent on the project, yet there is nothing on the ground.Last year, Phalombe community members presented a six-point petition to the district commissioner's office over lack of adequate medical facilities day to the absence of a district hospital in their district.

ACB Director Reyneck Matemba was seen at the High Court in Blantyre to file an appeal to nullify the order issued by the Zomba Magistrate Court, which cancelled Thom Mpinganjira's arrest warrant. Matemba expressed surprise at the Zomba order, issued by Principal Resident Magistrate Ben Chitsakamile, as both parties had initially agreed to present Mpinganjira in court today, where he could apply for bail.
Author: Jameson Chauluka

Title: USI TAKES OFF THE GLOVES
Content:
Faced with some pockets of resistance, Vice President Michael Usi says he is the Bonafide UTM Party President following the death of his predecessor Saulos Chilima in a military plane crash on June 10. 
His public declaration comes after the party’s hierarchy, led by secretary general Patricia kaliati, earlier announced the withdrawal of UTM party from the governing Tonse Alliance whose pact president Lazarus Chakwera and Chilima publicly signed on March 20, 2020. 
Speaking when he visited his home village Golden in Traditional Authority Chikumbu in Mulanje on Sunday afternoon. Usi said following Chilima’s death he automatically ascended to the party’s higher position. 
He said he will soon meet Kaliati to discuss the dates to call for the national executive committee (NEC) meeting. 
Said Usi "Let me say this, some are saying l am the acting president of UTM,no. l am the president of UTM and that's the constitution says. 
“ I am not going  to fight anybody . So, l have to meet the secretary general to come up with the agenda as she is the one who needs to communicate [on the NEC meeting].”   
He said he had noted that there were some UTM Party members who are not happy with his position, but he will not fight back. 
“what l am saying to all UTM Party members who are castigating me and are not happy with me is that l just ask Giod to forgive them,” said Usi. 
Article 13(3) of the UTM Party states that “the vise – president shall assist the president and shall, in the case of delegation by, or absence, resignation, incapacity or death of, the president, exercise the powers and functions conferred on the president by this constitution.”  
The Article 13 (14) further provides that “in the event of resignation, incapacity or death of the president and the vise- president, the national executive committee shall, as soon as it practicable, but no later than ninety days from the event, appoint an acting president until such time as the National Delegates Conference shall convene and until such appointment is made.” 
But when contacted yesterday on Usi’s sentiment, Kaliati said it was difficult for her to comment because she was just hearing about the position from The Nation. 
She  said : “When SKC [ Saulos Klaus Chilima] was alive, i was not communicated to through the  media . Therefore, the official response will be a problem. If he (Usi) decides to say that to the media, it will be difficult for me to respond,” 
Commenting on the development, political analyst Ernest Thindwa observed that Usi’s declaration and Kaliati’s response indicate divisions in UTM. 
He noted that the absence of the party’s top hierarchy during Usi’s swearing – in ceremony as Vise – President in Lilongwe on June 21 corroborates his observation. 
Said Thindwa; “that is the indication that there is disunity in the UTM, but this is very unfortunate. This party needed tp demonstrate that it is united in the absence of Dr. Chilima. But this is an indication that the party is slowly dying after the former vise president’s death.” 
Chakwera appointed Usi as the country’s Vice-President, replacing Chilima who was also the UTM party president. 
Chilima alongside eight others died in a military plane crash on June 10. 
In the nullified 2019 presidential election. Chilima had picked Usi as his running mate, effectively becoming the party’s vice president as per constitution.

Member of Parliament for Neno South, Mark Katsonga, had asked the chief whip for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for clarification as to why members on the government side have boycotted the Friday afternoon meeting. As discussions continued, there was an electricity blackout which has led to an early break.
MEC Chairperson Justice Dr. Jane Ansah finally takes her seat in the inquiry room.
Author: Taonga Sabola

Content: In Mangochi, participation in anti-MEC demonstrations has started to rise after a slow start.
Author: Yohane Symon

Content: The government bench has defeated a constitutional amendment to have a provision for a run-off in a presidential election in case a candidate fails to get a majority of votes according to the Constitution. The bill failed to get 2/3 of the votes in the house. The house has also rejected having fresh elections in May. The Constitutional Court on February 3 nullified the results of last year’s presidential polls and ordered Parliament to create an enabling environment for the implementation of the 50+1 system of determining the majority winner during the presidential race.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Content: ACB Director General Reyneck Matemba, on bribery attempts of Constitutional Court judges, stated: "The letter by the Chief Justice did not mention any political party, nor did it mention any politician."

Title: VP secures funding  for Nasolo Bridge rehab
Content:
Vise-president Michael Usi has secured funds for rehabilitation of Nosolo Bridge in Ndirande Township in Blantyre , about four days after residents expressed concerns on the dilapidated status of the structure. The Veep first visited Ndirande on Monday , but speaking when returned to township on Friday, he said he followed up the matter and found a donor who has assumed to start the rehabilitation works instantly . He identified the donor as Borron. 
In an interview after his second visit , Usi said the rehabilitation of the bridge that connects Ndirande Market and Chimseu could have been completed by now , but expressed concern that some people who he didn't mention , sabotaged the rehabilitation works. 
“so l have brought the representatives of  the development partners so that the can inspect the bridge  together. 
“we need  bridge that is fit for the purpose and we should move as quackly as possible so that before the rains starts , the bridge should be completed ,” he said. 
Usi noted that some people may not be happy with his tours, but said “i am ready to make enemies as long as i am making those enemies when i am saving the people of this country better”. 
In his remarks, Blantyre City deputy mayor Isaac Jomo Osman noted that the southern Region is being sidelined in terms of development projects. 
Said Osman “most of the roads here are in a dilapidated state. On Thursday, residents held demonstrations protesting the poor road network. But you should remember that politics begins in Ndirande . So, please help us with good roads” 
According to sources ,Nasolo bridge rehabilitation stalled about a year and half ago following disagreements between the donor and some Blantyre City Council (BCC) officials. 
The sources said the donor wanted the rehabilitation works to be done without BCC’s involvement, but the council officials refused.

Title: UDF’S MULUZI URGES PEOPLE TO VOTE
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi has allayed fears of elections rigging, saying the party has confidence that Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) will handle the process in a credible manner. President Peter Mutharika has been claiming that he has information that some people want to rig the elections. UTM Party president Sauloa Chilima has also said he has information that DPP wants to rig but Malawians should go and vote in numbers as the rigging plans will not succeed. Speaking in an interview at the weekend in Mzuzu during his tour of the Nothem Region, Muluzi stressed that UDF has confidence in MEC's ability to manage the elections  He said MEC is handling its work professionally and there is need to let the body handle the Flections in the best way possible Muluzi urged Malawians to ignore claims of rigging vote in large numbers on May 21.  He said "We want to encourage Malawians not to worry about these claims. People should go and vote and stop worrying shout what is being spread. We have confidence that MBC has put in place proper mechanisms and that we will have credible elections" Malawi Congress Party president Lazarus Chakwera also urged people at Ekwendeni in Mzimba to go and vote in large numbers, stressing the elections will not be rigged. In an interview yesterday, international elections observer Moses Mkandawire concurred with Muluzi that people should not be distracted by the rigging claims. He said making such claims has the potential to lead to voter apathy.
MCP Vice President Sidik Mia commends the people of Msundwe, stating, “They have shown Malawians that they can fight for their rights.”
Author: MacDonald Thom

Title: ICT adoption should ensure security, says Minister
Content:
Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu says the promotion and adoption of information and communications technology (IC]) should ensure users' safety and overall security of the technologies.
He said this on Monday in Lilongwe when he opened the International Telecommunications Union(ITU) Regional cyber Drill for Africa.
he said Malawi undertook a Cybersecurity Maturity Model Assessment from which five dimensions are being pursued to address security threats in the cyber space.
“The dimensions include the development and implementation of cyber culture and society, cyber security education, training and skills, strengthening of legal and regulatory frameworks and the development of cybersecurity standards.” Said Kunkuyu.
Speaking during the meeting, Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority board chairperson Stanley Khalid said Africa needs to shift away from the national boundary mindset and take the modern approach of collaboration on cybersecurity. 
“Without collaboration, cyber security can and will belong to the attackers,”he said.
ITU regional director for Africa Racheal Inne said in 2022, Africa experienced 1845 cyber-attacks.
Malawi is hosting the meeting in partnership with Malawi Computer Emergency Response Team, United Nations Office of Counter Terrorism and Forum for Incidence Response Security Team.
Author: Tiyanjane Mambucha

Title: Atupele trashes opinion polls
Content: Opposition United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi has described as bogus, opinion polls that have come out ahead of the May 20 Tripartite Elections. Atupele, who has been rated as a rank outsider on position four in two recent opinion polls, said at a news conference in Blantyre yesterday the surveys are aimed at distracting other candidates and their followers.  He claimed that some pollsters have ever approached him and offered their services to tip the opinion polls in his favour, but he refused. Said Atupele; “I have said no to this [sponsoring opinion polls]. People have made this business. But l want to assure Malawians that UDF is determined and focused to make the next government on May 20. These opinion polls are not credible.” Asked why he did not want to name and shame people that contacted him and offered to cook up an opinion poll in his favour, Atupele said Malawians know what is on the ground. He said; “The nation knows what is happening. This is propaganda in Zambia, there wre opinion polls that favoured Rupiah Banda [who was incumbent president] and placed Michael Sata far, but Sata won the elections.” The UDF torchbearer, who called for the news conference to outlined what his government would do should Malawians vote his party into power next Tuesday, said the scenario was the same in Kenya where opinion polls ruled out Uhuru Kenyatta, but he went on to win the presidency. He said UDF was not losing sleep over the opinion polls, challenging that his party has done a lot on the ground and was ready to govern and transform Malawi. An opinion poll released on Friday by the US – based Afrobarometer placed the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Peter Mutharika as a frontrunner with 27 percent of the vote followed by Lazarus Chakwera of Malawi Congress Party (MCP) and incumbent President Joyce Banda of People’s Party (PP) at 21 and 19 percent respectively. The Afrobarometer opinion poll, conducted between March 23 and April 7, 2014, with a sample sized of 2400, placed Atupele on fourth position with 14 percent. Another earlier and most controversial opinion poll by Research Tech Consultants favoured Banda to win the forthcoming elections, followed by Chakwera, Mutharika and Atupele in that order.  During yesterday’s news conference, Atupele pledged that if voted into power, he would appoint a credible and professional Cabinet that will live within its means and comprise honest and accountable leaders that have Malawi’s best interest. Said Atupele; “[My administration will within 100 days] establish a permanent planning commission to oversee coherent policy planning and implementation.” Atupele said within 100 days, his government would set out a robust budget that clearly outlines hard choices within competing priorities and efforts to grow and stabilise Malawi through priority sector.  Atupele later in the afternoon lined up nine campaign rallies within Blantyre.

Title: Chakwera Deliver Public Lecture in Bunda
Content:
Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president Lazarus Chakwera on Thursday delivered a public lecture to Bunda College students.
In his lecture. Chakwera emphasized on student’s role in developing the country.
Chakwera said: ‘’This county relies on you for it to develop. Therefore, you would have a vision and take part in making a bright future for this county to come true’’.
He said Bunda students are vital for the economy of the country because agriculture is the backbone of Malawi’s economy.
‘’It is a shame for Malawi to be classified as a least developed county 50 years after independence. Bunda is graduating hundreds of students every year, but we will face foo shortage in this country.
‘’There is nothing wrong with this county but our mindset. My advice to you is that when you graduate from here don’t aim at being employed at some body’s farm. Instead, think of opening your own farm. In this way, Malawi will easily develop,’’ said Chakwera
He repeated words by former US President John F Kennedy: Don’t ask what your county can do for you. Ask what you can do for your country.’’
Chakwera said if elected his government would priorities researched in universities to solve local problems.
Speaking on behalf of students, Bunda students Union President Apatsa Kadelukak told the MCP leader that if he wins the presidency next year, he should not forget Bunda students.
‘’We lack enough books classrooms and hostels here.
‘’Therefore, if you win elections, help us with these resources so that we can adequately learn to help develop our count,’’ said Kadeluka.
In his response, Chakwera agreed with the students that infrastructural development has been a problem at Bunda Campus.
Author: Dyson Nthawanji

Content: UDF Publicity Secretary, Ken Ndanga, says the political union means both parties believe in dialoging. He says Malawi cannot develop if they don’t adopt the importance of unity.
Author: Sharon Chirwa

Title: AFORD NDI DPP ADYERA CHIKHO CHIMODZI
Atupele Muluzi quits active politics
Content:
United Democratic Front (UDF) president Atupele Muluzi has quit politics. 
In a letter announcing his decision addressed to the party’s secretary general Kandi Padambo dated May 28 2022, Muluzi said he is “going into business for the development and progress of Malawi” Reads the letter in part; “In view of this decision and pursuant with the party constitution, I appoint Honourable Lilian Estella Patel, party vice – president Earsten Region to lead the party as acting president until the next national convention where my success will be elected. “I am truly grateful to the entire UDF family for the amazing confidence  and support given to me over the 18 years i have served in politics.” However, attemps to seek his f resh comment on the matter before we went to print at 9am proved futile as our calls to his mobile phone number went unanswered despite several attempts. But Padambo corfimed the news, saying he discussed the matter with Muluzi earlier in the day yesterday. “Yes, i can confirm that the letter is authentic. I met and discussed with him. He is of the view that he should help in developing the country by pursuing other avenues other than active politics,” he said. UDF treasurer general Ned Phoya, who is also the party’s leader in the House, confirmed that Muluzi has quit active politics. “What l know is that he wants to concentrate on his businesses. As a party, we do not have more information than the one on the statement.” Commenting on the issue, University of Malawi political analyst  Mustaphaahaussein described the news of Muluzi’s resignation as a sad development, He said’ “That is his choice . He is entitled to what he wants. However, this is a great loss to the nation. Honourable Muluzi has great potential. He is young and had a future in politics. At his age, he is accumulated vast experience and benefitted a lot from mentorship from his father [Bakili Muluzi] who once served the country as president . “Many people are reluctant to join active politics, but Honourable Muluzi sacrificed himself to serve the country in many portfolios. His contribution will be greatly missed. We hope in future he might come back into active politics,” In his remarks, CCAP Livingstonia Synod Church and Society executive director Moses Mkandawire wondered why Muluzi chose his successor. “UDF is repeating the mistake they made in 2003 when Bakili Muluzi just handpicked Bingu wa Mutharika as the party’s presidential candidate. “That is not good for democracy where the majority have to rule. I have not seen UDF constitution, but l wonder if it allow that.” He said Muluzi should have allowed the party’s convention to choose his successor. Muluzi paired Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) president Peter Mutharika during the June 23 2020 court – sanctioned Fresh Presidential Elections but lost to incumbent Malawi leader Lazarus Chakwera and Vice – President Saulos Chilima. Meanwhile, following succession wrangles in DPP, some gurus in the former governing party suggested that Muluzi could pair Mutharika in the 2025 Presidential Election.

No date has been set for the Constitutional Court ruling on the presidential election results case. Judiciary spokesperson Agnes Patemba says the court will adhere to the 45-day timeframe set for the ruling. She refuted reports circulating on social media that the ruling would be delivered on January 27, 2020. Patemba clarified that such information is fake, stressing that the judges will deliver their ruling within the set timeframe.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Title: 8 000 public schools to go digital
Content:
Ministry of Education has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Open Connect Limited (OCL) to digitise 8 000 public schools to address the problem of insufficient teaching and learning materials as well as increasing access to education.
After signing the MoU in Lilongwe yesterday, Secretary for Education Chikondano Mussa said the agreement mandates OCL to connect the 8 000 schools and provide digital libraries and hubs for easy learning.
She said: "Besides enhancing the working relationship between different directorates, public schools and OCL, this MoU will promote e-learning services, data sharing, learning hubs and access to digital libraries” Mussa said the MoU will ensure connectivity of all learning institutions such as study circles, remote areas, teacher communities of practice, open and distance learning and all institutions of higher learning such as teacher training colleges.
“This will ensure that all learning institutions are connected and are able to share information easily,” she said.
OCL chief executive officer Sandile Dholmo said through the project, students will be able to access books and other learning materials online, thereby removing the barrier of pupil: book ratio. He said it will also enable learners to access lessons online and at the places of their convenience as long as their schools are in the program. So far, OCL has already connected Mulunguzi Secondary School in the South, Nkhotakota Secondary School in the Central and Chitipa Secondary School in the North, with the other schools to be connected in phases.
Author: Steven Pembamoyo

Content: The court emphasizes that substantial changes should not have occurred if the results were free and fair. There is no provision in the law allowing the MEC to use results from constituency tally centers. They must refer to the complete results from tally centers and district tally centers, as constituency tally centers are not recognized. The court was informed that this arrangement was agreed upon to prevent issues that arose in the 2014 elections.
Author: Sharon Chirwa

Title: JB PUNCHES HOLES IN  FISP
Content: People's Party (PP) President Joyce Banda has added her voice to criticism of the Farm Input Subsidy Programme (Fisp), saying it is not fully benefitting the poor. Speaking during a political rally she addressed Nandumbo in Traditional Authority (T/A) Kalembo in Balaka on Saturday, Banda, who governed Malawi from 2012 to 2014, said the country's economy is worse now than it was when she was President of the country. She said: "Poor people are being registered for subsidy fertiliser without being helped to access the farm inputs. During my time, subsidy fertiliser vas at K500 and when 1 come back as President I will reintroduce the K500 subsidy fertiliser to enable the poor afford farm input" Malawi introduced Fapur 2005 to enable smallholder farming households access hybrid maize, legume seeds and fertiliser to boost national and household food security. Currently, Fisp beneficiaries pay K3,500 for each bag of fertilizer whose market price is about K21 000.  However, Fisp critics have pushed for an exit strategy, noting that government invests billions of kwacha in the programme only to spend more to feed millions of hungry mouths after poor harvests. Former president said she is open to coalitions in the May 21 Tripartite Elections only if the partners share PP's vision of uplifting the economic and social status of poor Malawians. PP Eastern Region provincial chairperson Ibrahim Matola urged people in Nandumbo to vote for Banda because it was her government that connected the area to electricity.
Daud Suleman states, “In the forthcoming elections, all Msundwe residents will be monitors. We have reached this stage because of the support we had from you.”
Author: MacDonald Thom

Title: VP for mindset change on technology use
Content:
Vice-President Saulos Chilma says this is need for mindset change in the context of how technology can effectively and efficiently contribute to the job creation process in the country.
The Veep said this in response to a question from Zoe Marks, a public policy lecturer at the Harvard Kennedy School in the United States of America, who asked him to comment on technology and entrepreneurship opportunities during a Fireside Chat webinar organised by the Africa Policy Journal yesterday.
Chilima said apart from looking at the negative side of technology and its effects on the job market, people should understand that technology can also lead to the creation of more jobs that can help uplift the economy. He said: "Broadly speaking, technology should  be helping us create jobs and smarter employees to be able to produce stronger and produce better.
"My own view is that we should be investing in allowing technical change or technology to translate into more jobs and smarter
jobs."
Chilima said with  favorable policies in place, technology offers a wide range of opportunities; hence, it is important that people start embracing technology in the context of job creation. it the Vice-President, who is also heading the Public Sector Reforms drive, said institutions should also have the capacity to analyze if they have the capability to train employees in understanding new technologies.
He said this was one crucial area that needs to be highlighted stressing that analysis of such can lead to the understanding of how technology can lead to smart and better working patterns.
Further, Chilima said it is also in the interest of government that many people should be able to access technology and that nobody should be left behind. He described technology as one of the key enablers of Malawi 2063(MW2063). On her part, Marks underscored the importance of embracing technology, pointing out that there are numerous opportunities, especially on job creation. In her remarks, Harvard Kennedy School Africa Policy Journal editor-in-chief Adaobi Aezeokoli hailed Chilima’s participation in the webinar to share some insights on technology.
Author: Lloyd Chitsulo

Content: A lorry belonging to Chitakale Plantations Company Limited arriving with DPP supporters in Mzuzu.

Title: ATUPELE PROMISES WEALTH CREATION
Content: United Democratic Front president Atupele Muluzi says he will ensure that Malawians are economically independent if he wins in the May 20 Tripartite Elections. Muluzi said this on Sunday at all he held at Dickson Trading Center in Lilongwe. Muluzi who was accompanied by his running mate Godfrey Chapoia and party vice-president Igbar Omar, said many Malawians have to money for public needs.  Despite Iiving in an independent nation, many Malawians are not financially independent. Few Malawians are enjoying wealth in this nation while the rest of Malawians financially struggling. My government will come up with deliberate ways to enable people to have money and develop their lives," he said.

UTM and MCP supporters in Zomba held a parade to celebrate the court's decision for fresh presidential elections. Ramsey Khan, MCP Director of Youth in the Eastern Region, stated that the court ruling signifies a new era in the country's democracy. The parade commenced at Chinamwali town and proceeded up to 3 miles.
Author: Tiyese Monjeza

Content: In response to Attorney General Kaphale's ongoing representation of MEC, Judge Madise clarifies that this was a directive, not just a comment.
Heavy security presence is noted at Kamuzu Upper Stadium in Blantyre as protesters begin gathering for the anti-Jane Ansah demonstrations.
Author: Jameson Chauluka

Content: The MEC did not comply with Section 119 of the Election Act, as there was a blatant failure to account for a vast majority of record books. This occurred despite their claim to the court that all election materials had been deposited with the Clerk of Parliament.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Content: High Court Judge Justice Dorothy Nyakaunda Kamanga, has called for an interpate hearing on Thom Mpinganjira's Zomba file at 2 pm today. Zomba Magistrate, Ben Chitsakamire, cancelled Mpinganjira's warrant of arrest obtained by the Anti Corruption Bureau at the Lilongwe Magistrates Court, an order which Judiciary Registrar Agnes Patemba described as irregular. Mpinganjira was arrested last week for allegedly being part of the team which planned to bribe judges hearing the elections case. Patemba has confirmed the meeting saying it will be held in the chamber.
Author: Jameson Chauluka

Title: Govt throws away Atupele’s cheques
Content: Government has rejected three cheques United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi gave to three referral hospitals in the country claiming it was advised by Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) to pend the donation, an assertion MEC has denied. Muluzi on Sunday donated K3 million to Mzuzu, Kamuzu and Queen Elizabeth centra hospitals to ease problems the hospitals are facing. However, when Reverend Overton Mazunda went to handover the cheque to Mzuzu Centra Hospital (MCH) yesterday, MCH director Rose Nyirenda and principal administrator Timothy Soko rejected the cheque, claiming MEC advised them to receive the cheques after May 20 elections. Nyirenda claimed Ministry of Health principal secretary (PS) Chris Kang’ombe gave the directive after consulting MEC. “The order is coming from above and it is beyond the Ministry because the PS was told by MEC that the cheques have to be given after May 20,” said Nyirenda. Mazunda condemned the hospital’s decision, wondering why Muluzi’s money was being rejected when President Joyce Banda has procured 10 ambulances for health centers. MEC chief elections officer Willie Kalonga disputed claims that MEC advise the to put on the donations, adding MEC never discussed with the PS or any official from Ministry of Health regarding the cheques. He said there is also no provision that bars peoples from donating to hospitals during campaign period. He asked the ministry not to drag MEC into unnecessary conflicts. Kang’ombe could not respond to questions saying he was caught up in a meeting.

Commissioner Bishop Mary Nkosi states that the Commission signed for the presidential results on the day President Peter Mutharika was sworn in, unlike the official announcement of Peter Dimba's victory in the Lilongwe South polls, where the Commission signed agreement forms before the announcement.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Title: Chakwera changes civil service head title
Content: President Lazarus Chakwera has reverted to the title of Secretary to the president and Cabinet (SPC) from Chief secretary to the Government which  former president Bingu wa Muntharika changed. Published in the Malawi Government Gazette 3 555 volume LVII number 34 and issued on July 31 2020, the restoration is effective august 1 2020 reads the notice: ‘’In exercise of the powers conferred by section 33 of the General Interpretation Act, I, Dr. Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera, president of the republic of  Malawi, hereby order that the title of the office of the Chief Secretary to the Government should revert to Secretary to the president and Cabinet with effect from the 1st day of August, 2020.;; the incumbent SPC is Zanga-Zanga Chikhosi. Muntharika changed the title to chief secretary to the government after he abolished the position of the chief secretary for public services following criticism from law experts.
Author: JONATHAN PASUNGWI

Content: The People's Party (PP) has expressed disappointment with the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) for failing to reveal the names of individuals who attempted to bribe judges hearing the presidential election results case. A statement released on Wednesday, signed by the party's spokesperson Ackson Kalaile Banda, says PP and all Malawians of goodwill were reassured that the press briefing held by the ACB would address the issue and reveal the names. “To the shock of the People’s Party and those who wish Malawi well, the press conference was but a mockery. Mr. Matemba further dragged the former president of Malawi, Dr. Joyce Banda, into the matter, claiming she was responsible for his appointment as ACB Deputy Director, though we all know it was President Peter Mutharika who appointed Matemba as Director General,” reads part of the statement. The PP feels aggrieved by ACB's assertions, given Matemba's appointment process involved approval by Parliament.

Title: JB PLEDGES 3 MILLION JOBS
Content:
Former president and People's Party (PP) leader Joyce Banda has promised to put three million jobless Malawians on employment if her party is ushered back into government in May this year. 
Banda, who governed the country between 2012 and 2014, assured Malawians that it was possible to create these million jobs in three years, translating to one million jobs a year. Her promise comes at a time Malawians are already debating Vice-President Saulos Chilima's pledge to create one million jobs within the first year of his administration should his UTM Party win the May 2019 Tripartite Elections. But Banda challenged her critics during a political rally star held at Lirangwe in Blantyre yesterday that her government would focus on wealth creation through job creation and loans provisions. I launched the Kabaza [bicycle taxi) business right here at Lirangwe and today it employs one million people. So, why should anyone doubt that in three years we can create three million jobs? It is possible," she said tally, Banda explained that her plan was to establish an Entrepreneurs Development Initiative (EDI) to provide training and credit." The PP leader also reiterated that she will create a K10 billion revolving fund to provide youths and women with business low Speaking earlier, PP vice president and provincial chairperson for the South Ephraim Chibvunde and Isaac Nyakamera, respectively, urged Malawians to vote for Banda and her party, saying she is only one with a vision to spur the country's growth.
How they voted on the 28-day waiver issue to accommodate the Electoral Commission Act amendment motion adopted on Wednesday: Yes = 91 votes No = 82 votes Absent = 15 Abstain = 2

Title: CHILIMA PLANE CRASH WAS A PURE ACCIDENT | JOSHUA MBELE
Content:
A business mogul Joshua Chisa Mbele says Chakwera's government performed badly in a rescue and recovery mission on the plane crash which claimed people's vice president Late Dr Saulos Klaus Chilima and 8 others.
MCP affiliated UTM member Joshua Mbele said without withholding the truth the government could have done much better. Mbele also observed that despite speculations of foul play; the accident was a pure natural accident.
Mbele have called for UTM Leadership to revoke Dr Dalitso Kabambe from contesting for the UTM Presidential seat. Mbele have described Kabambe's action as a move to humiliate party's incumbent leader Dr Michael Bizwick Usi who was entirely entrusted by the late Dr Chilima.
Lately, Kabambe echoed the late Dr Saulos Chilima's wife Mary Chilima call for commission of enquiry in the plane crash. Kabambe through an official letter to the party's president who is also country's vice leader Dr Usi asked him to take an action on Chilima's death enquiry.

Regarding the letter sent to the committee requesting an extension of time before appearing, Commissioner Mary Nkosi argues that the reasoning is flawed since MEC has appealed to the Supreme Court using the judgment. She clarifies that she was not part of the decision that permitted the Commission to appeal the Constitutional Court judgment.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Title: APM CENSURED OVER BINGU POISONING CLAIMS
Content: Legal and political experts in the country have censured former president Peter Mutharika, fondly known as APM, over his remarks that his brother the late Bingu was poisoned in 2012. Speaking on Sunday during a press briefing he held at his retirement home in Mangochi, Mutharika alleged that Malawi's former president "Bingu was poisoned, and something was put in his wine juice at 8am and at 10 he had died. "It is the fact, and I know the people, but let us leave it here," he said. But his comments contradict the 2013 findings of the Commission of Inquiry into the circumstances that led to the death of Bingu wa Mutharika which show that he died on April 5 2012 on the way to Kamuzu Central Hospital (KCH) in Lilongwe. Reads part of the inquiry "On the issue of cause of death, the commission has concluded from the evidence before it that the president died of cardiac arrest due to cardiac arrhythmia (irregular beating of the heart). However, in an interview yesterday, private practice lawyer John-Gitt Mwakhwawa, who also heads the Law Faculty at the Catholic University of Malawi, said the remarks have the potential to incite violence. He said: "If that is the claim, it has legal implications. "First, it was possibly a treasonous act because Bingu was a head of State. Therefore, you may be investigating issues surrounding treason." Mwakhwawa called on law enforcement agencies such as the police to investigate Mutharika's claims. "When did he know about that the poisoning)? What did he do about it and if he didn't do anything, himself being at one point head of State. "If the claims are baseless the country will look at him as someone who is trying to incite contempt and violence." University of Malawi's law professor Garton Kamchedzera said Mutharika was simply trying to use his brother's death for political advantage. He said: "It is important to understand the former president not just as a person who lost a brother, but also as a politician. When speaking about this, I don't think he thought about the law and its implications. "What he said has legal and political implications in that it will boomerang on him in terms of his credibility". Kamchedzera wondered why Mutharika, who claimed to have known that his brother died at 10am, allowed the body to be flown to South Africa for further treatment. "Mutharika had an opportunity to testify before the commission, and did he commit perjury?" he asked a Blantyre-based political analyst. Ernest Thindwa wiwd Mutharika was looking for public sympathy. "Bingu died as head of State and the nation has an interest in the security of a sitting president and security agencies should engage Mutharika on the claims to tell the nation what he knows," he said.

Title: Alleged Atupele attackers arrested
Content: Police in Lilongwe have arrested three men suspected to have robbed Minister of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining Atupele Muluzi’s private residence in Area 9 in Lilongwe. Lilongwe Police Station spokesperson Kingsely Dandaula confirmed the arrests. But police could not disclose names of the three suspects for fear of jeopardising investigations. However, Dandaula said the three were arrested after a tip–off from the public on the whereabouts of the suspects. He said; “We followed the lead and eventually found the three suspects walking freely in the streets of Lilongwe where we managed to arrest them.” The suspects are expected to appear in court at a later date. Some police investigators are currently in Mozambique where the stolen items were allegedly sold. On Friday last week, a gang of 12 broke into the minister’s house through a hole they drilled in the perimeter fence in the backyard and made their way into the house. They also broke into the minister’s bedroom where they demanded cash and took away electronic gadgets and other valuables.
The committee decides to adopt a lenient stance toward Kunje, instructing her to answer questions as they arise.

Title: Group decries low usage of e-sources
Content:
Malawi Library and Information Consortium (Malico) has expressed concern over the low usage of electronic-resources (e-resources)
by Malawian researchers. The consortium's outgoing chairperson Hambani Gausi made the remarks on Thursday during the 2023 Annual General Meeting at Sunbird Nkopola Lodge in Mangochi, which was held under the theme 'Facilitating access electronic information resources’. He said the theme is crucial because the consortium is trying to entice people to utilise e-resources so they can get the value for money. Gausi said the consortium pays $50 000 to $60 000 to offer the e-resources on its other platform and $30 000 to keep their myloft platform running. He said: "The consortium has over 30 institutions, including universities and other research institutions, but very few access the information that we offer through e-resources. "This is unfortunate because we have thousands of subscribers and it raises questions as to where our researchers get their information from.” One of the participants, Martin Namacheka cited information overload and lack of awareness as the major challenges to access e-resources offered by the consortium. "There is information overload, such that people choose to get information from other sources such as  Google and ignore Malico e-resources," he said.
Author: Ayamba Kandondo

Content: Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) leadership has hit back at President Peter Mutharika, who yesterday accused rights activists and opposition political leaders of trying to sow chaos and confusion in the country. In their statement, signed by HRDC chairperson and vice chairperson Timothy Mtambo, the grouping says it will not allow itself to be distracted from the path it has taken to fight for justice for women who are said to have been raped by police officers in M’bwatalika, Mpingu, and Msundwe. When opening the Agricultural Commercialisation Project in Lilongwe on Friday, Mutharika had no kind words for the opposition and rights activists, further insinuating that the fire which broke out at Delamere House in Blantyre might have been attempts by the two sides to sabotage his administration.
Author: Stephen Dakalira

He is speaking at UDF convention where he has been invited.

Content: Parliament sets May 19 for fresh presidential polls Parliament has managed to set a date for fresh elections through the amendment of Parliamentary and Presidential Act which says the elections will be held on May 19, 2020. This amid protest from Government and Democratic Progressive Party. The amendment has also allowed a run-off presidential election to be held after 30 days if no candidate gets half or more of the valid votes.

Content: Malawi Congress Party (MCP) Vice President, Sidik Mia, has urged Malawians to use the forthcoming fresh elections as an opportunity to change the country's leadership and end current challenges. Mia expressed this in Chikwawa on Saturday during a celebration party he hosted to celebrate MCP's victory in the election case at the Constitutional Court. He emphasized that this is an opportunity to usher the party into power, as its leadership has good intentions for all Malawians, regardless of regional boundaries.
