Malawi Congress Party (MCP) has given its president Lazarus Chakwera the mandate to pursue negotiations with UTM for possible electoral alliance. This has been confirmed by MCP publicity secretary Maurice Munthali, who added that at a National Executive Committee meeting yesterday, the party empowered Chakwera to institute a committee that will help with the negotiations. This comes days after UTM publicity secretary Joseph Chidanti Malunga admitted that UTM has sanctioned a committee to explore possible alliance with MCP.

Title: VP CHILIMA IN SOUTH KOREA FOR SUMMIT
Content: Vice-President Saulos Chilima yesterday arrived in Seoul, Republic of Korea for the 2024 Korea-Africa Summit. In a Facebook, post yesterday, he said the summit, where he is representing President Lazarus Chakwera, presents a unique opportunity for Malawi to strengthen ties with South Korea and foster cooperation on global issues. Said Chillima: "In the next few days, we expect meaningful discussions on trade, investment and infrastructure development, leading to tangible tong outcomes that benefit our citizens. We further look forward to exploring innovative solutions for climate change, energy security and health care, aligning our efforts towards a prosperous and sustainable future. "The summit will be held from June 4 to June 5, 2024, under the theme "The future we make together, Shared growth, sustainability and solidarity, Chilima left Malawi on Saturday and is expected to return on June 72024, In the picture, Chilima and his wife Mary on arrival in South Korea.

Title: Atupele robbed, abandons home
Content: Unidentified panga – wielding thugs at dawn on Friday raided the residence of Minister of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining Atupele Muluzi in Lilongwe’s Area 9, it has been confirmed. Sources said the thugs, who reportedly overpowered the security detail, including police officers, went away with several electronic gadgets and cash snatched from the minister and his wife after the assailants made way into Atupele’s bedroom. In an interview with The Nation yesterday, Chief secretary to the Government Goerge Mkondiwa confirmed the attack at the minister’s home. Said Mkondiwa; “Yes, i can confirm the minister was attacked at his house in Area 9. He [the minister] come to my office and he explained the ordeal.” But Mkondiwa could not confirm whether the minister will continue living in the home as agents have immediately put it up for new tenants. The minister has since left the house and is staying at an undisclosed location. During a visit to the house yesterday, The Nation crew saw a notice outside the gate advertising that the house’s owner was looking for a new tenant. Lilongwe Police Station spokesperson Kingsley Dandaula confirmed receiving a report on the incident. In an interview yesterday, Dandaula said he could not give more details due to on – going investigations but confirmed that police have in custody two security guards in connection with the attack. The raid Atupele’s residence comes against a background of concerns about rising cases of insecurity in the country. Two months ago, thieves broke into Mudi House in Blantyre, the official residence of Vice – president Saulos Chilima, and went away with assorted items, including bottles of wine. Yesterday, police sources told The Nation that the people who attacked Atupele’s residence had broken into the minister’s house searching for valuable items before storming the major bedroom where they demanded K500 000 cash. The sources said the unknown assailants camped in the house for 45 minutes before the minister and his wife Angella could get help. The couple had their phones snatched and the house’s internal security alert dismantled by the gang. Said one of the sources; “They went away with the ministers’s wallet and money amounting not more than K35 000. They, however, went away with i-pads, smartphones and other valuables from his personal assistant [a Mr. Mkozomba].” The thieves are said to have accessed the minister’s compound through a hole they had dug at the backyard. Atupele  is son to Malawi’s second president Bakili Muluzi. We could not reach him for comment yesterday.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Malawi (Icam) has imposed fines on international audit firm BDO for contraventions related to the nullified May 21 presidential election. According to a letter we have seen, Icam has ordered BDO to pay K1 million for failing to stop the transmission of electoral results despite having noticed irregularities. BDO has been ordered to pay another K1 million as a penalty for engaging junior auditors in the country without obtaining their reference, considering the gravity of the job they were tasking them with. This comes after BDO had appeared before Icam’s disciplinary committee following complaints from the Malawi Congress Party and a concerned citizen.
MEC Commissioner Moffat Banda states that he was only part of any resolutions passed by the commission during the meetings he attended.

Author: Faith Kadzanja

Title: From Manganya to Vice
Content:
Until his appointment as the country’s as the country’s new Vice – President, Michael Usi was saving as the Minister of Natural Resources and Climate Change in the Tonse Alliance administration. 
Usi, a senior member of UTM Party founded by the former Vice – President the late Saulos Klaus Chilima, who died in a plane crash on June 1o, joined active politics in 2018, after many years of working as an administrator. He was country director of Adventist Development and Relief agency (Adra). 
Born on december 6 1968 in Mulanje, he attended his primary and secondary schools in the same district before joining Malamulo Colllege of Health sciences in Thyolo. He graduated in 1991 with a diploma in Clinical medicine. He later obtained his bachelor’s degree international development from Andrew’s University in the United States of America. 
However, after working as a healthcare worker for some time, Usi Joined Adra where he championed number of relief and humanitarian projects. 
But in 2018, Usi surprised many when he declared that he was joining active politics. His intention was to contest for parliamentary seat for Mulanje Centra constituency. 
By then, he had been running a movement Odya Zake Alibe Mlandu, a political philosophy that sought to empower marginalized people. 
On February 6 2019, Malawians got another surprise when they saw Usi standing alongside Chilima as the letter’s running mate in May 2019 presidential Elections. 
Again, not for the first or second time, last night’s appointment was perhaps another surprise as most Malawians know him as Manganya a character he created in Tikuferanji soap opera. 
Usi, aka Manganya, has two master's degrees. The first is in international development and was obtained from the USA, the other is in strategic management from Derby University in the United Kingdom. 
In 2018, Usi successfully defended his PhD thesis on ‘The development of Malawi by investigating in the youth’ after studying at Bedfordshire University in the UK.

The Church of Central Africa Presbyterian (CCAP) Nkhoma synod has declared Monday, the day the constitutional court will make its ruling on the presidential elections result case, a holiday in all its institutions. Title: JB COURTS KARONGA BUSINESSPERSONS
Content: Former president Joyce Banda, who is also People's Party president, on Sunday addressed women at a business forum for self help groups in Karonga. Banda said in business, perseverance, respect for families and love are key to success, saying disrespectful businesswomen do not prosper as they spend precious time quarreling with their husbands over petty issues. She promised a K10 billion revolving fund that her office will set aside if she wins the presidential race in the May 21 2019 Tripartite Elections. She said that women economic empowerment is key to socio-economic and political development. About 122 small-scale business women from across Karonga attended the forum.

Title: Chakwera keen on reducing powers
Content:
However, he said he believes It was time a review was made on the merits of having the Presidents also occupy an office such as chancellor of a public university.
‘’This is a relic from a bygone era that we need to part with, for I know of no free country in which the State President is put at the helm of an educational institutional that exists to produce free thinkers.
‘’that is one example of positional powers that need to be revisited. The second category of powers a president has is executive. This has to do with certain decisions that are received for a president to make. It is my view that there are too many decisions made by a president, so I mean to reduce that,’’ Chakwera said.
He said having a presidency that makes too many decisions has created problems for the country for a long time.
‘’This is a mistake we must stop making at a national level. There must be decisions that when made by parliament are final, and even where the president has the power to veto such decisions, he should no longer be allowed to sabotage the governance framework by sitting on the decision.’’
This was in direct reference to bills in parliament but would require the president to assent to them and before the June 23 fresh presidential election, former president Peter Muntharika was accused of frustrating the amendment of some electoral laws.
‘’The third category of powers a president has is that of appointments. From the judiciary, to the legislature, to the Executive, all the way to constitutionally mandated institutions designed to operate independently, the boards of statutory corporations, foreign embassies, and traditional leaders, we have the anomaly of having all of them look to the president as the appointing authority,’’ Chakwera said.
The president said it is not possible for a President to be the appointing authority of many offices without at some point coming face to face with a conflict of interest.
Within culture change towards the presidency, Chakwera asked for a rethink on overlap between party and state functions to prevent abuse.
Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) chairperson Gift Trapence in an interview supported Chakwera’s stance to trim the presidential powers, saying too nuch powers concentrated in the presidency is the reason presidents in the past became dictatorial; hence, made grave mistakes.

Title: Atupele dares UDF to embrace democracy
Content:
Former United Democratic Front (UDF) president Atupele Muluzi has kept a tight lid on his political future and says his presence at the party’s rally in Mangochi on May 7 will deminstrate unity and maturity. 
His sentiments come against a background of some UDF members expressing fear that Atupele wants to reclaim his position and one of his strategies is through political rallies he has lined up ahead of the party’s convention. 
Atupele, son to former president Bakili Muluzi, resigned as the party’s president in May 2022, saying he was going into business for the development and progress of Malawi. The party appointed veteran politician Lilian Patel to lead the party. 
However, ahead of the Mangochi rally some party officials have expressed fear that Atupele is strategising to reclaim his position as president. 
 But UDF secretary general Kandi Padambo said in an interview yesterday that the party’s national working committee has allowed Atupele to hold the initial rally at St. Augustine Ground in Mangochi on May 7, 2023. 
He said the committee would make a decision at a later date on the proposed rallies by Atupele this year in Ndirande Township, Blantyre on May 21, Lilongwe on June 3 and Mzuzu on June 17. 
In an interview yesterday, Atupele said UDF is a united party that believes in the fundamental principles of democracy, human rights and the rule of law. 
He said: “It has an indelible place in the country’s political history. This rally in Mangochi will demonstrate to all Malawians that the UDF is united, strong party and ready to play its rightful role in the governance of the country. 
“People need not to fear, it is the people that elect their leaders and they should be free to do so, this is the purpose of democracy right?” 
Atupele said the party would soon be holding its convention to elect new office – bearers and all bona fide members are free to contest for any position, including that of the president ahead of the 2025 Tripartite Elections. 
Patel is will be the guest of honour at the rally while Atupele is the quest speaker.

Some Members of Parliament have expressed dissatisfaction for the house to be adjourning without tackling the issue regarding confirmation of acting Inspector General (IG) of Police Duncan Mwapasa. Kasungu South East legislator Khumbize Kandodo Chiponda said Malawi cannot be operating with the authority of an acting IG which is not provided for in the laws of the country. Mzimba South East legislator Ackson Kalaile Banda also expressed the same concern. But Speaker Catherine Gotani Hara says it is government that brings such agendas in the House. Mwapasa's planned confirmation has been appearing on the order paper but was not tabled in the House. Last time, Parliament also failed to confirm the IG. Parliament has been meeting for the past three weeks and adjourns sine die today Friday, 28 February 2020.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Title: Malawi computer team in global forum
Content: Malawi  Computer Emergency Response Team (mwCERT). Has been accepted into the international confederation of trusted computer incident response team, First, as a member. Speaking at the 35th First annual general conference in Montreal, Canada, the head of mwCERT Christopher Banda said one of the major challenges Malawi is meeting in its cyberspace is mobile money fraud. He said: “One of the ways we are addressing this vice is through intensive awareness for all. ICT consumers because we realized that in most cases mobile money fraud is socially engineered, meaning that users or consumers play a huge role in the scheme.” “We believe that educating ICT consumers on good cyber hygiene will go a long way in our fight against these scammers.” Banda said Malawi is implementing various initiatives to ensure a safe and resilient cyberspace for all. “These include the development of a Child Online Protection National Strategy, the review of various legislation and introduction of new laws to tackle the current cyber landscape,”he said. MwCERT is a unit within Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority. It was established pursuant to Section 6 of the Electronic Transaction and Cyber Security Act, 2016 of the Laws of Malawi and it is responsible for the national coordination and protection of critical information infrastructure in the country. The 35th First annual general conference was held in Montreal, Canda under the theme ‘Empoweering communities’
Author: Lemekezani Chisambo

Title: Chakwera to be replaced
Content:
Secretary General for Assemblies of God in Chsamba has said Reverend Dr Lazarus Chakwera who worked as the president of the church did not resign, but rather retired and will be replaced in that respect.
In an interview with Mana on Wednesday, Chisamba explained that Chakwera retired after serving 24 years as the leader of the Church.
‘’Retirement as a church leader doesn’t mean e has stopped being a pastor who is recognized in Malawi, Chisamba explained.
He said Chakwera will still and will be recognized as a minister.
Malawi Assemblies of God is conducting a four-day revival meeting which started on August 6, 2013, and is expected to end on August 9, 2013. This year’s annual general meeting (AGM) is being held under the theme ‘’rekindling the fire of prayer”.
The church is supposed to elect the new president at the end of the AGM following Chakweras Retirement.
The church will Friday convince a general council to elect the new president; Rev. Chisamba said, adding that ‘’The general counsel of the church will fill the position through nominations which will take place on Thursday.’’
Candidates for the position are not yet known because the council did not receive any nominees.
Chakwera retired and has since joined politics, he is vying to be elected Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president during this weekend’s convention in Lilongwe.
Author: Ebbelet Tembenu

Title: CHILIMA TO GRACE YOUTH DAY IN MZUZU
Content: Vice-President Saulos Chilima is expected to preside over the 2023 International Youth Day commemorations at Mzuzu Stadium on Friday, August 18, 2023. In a statement, Mzuzu City Council chief executive officer Gomezgani Nyasulu said the event's theme is green skills for youth Towards a sustainable world". Meanwhile, Mzuzu-based Youth Network in partnership with different stakeholders and partners will host different activities today It will start with hosting a Green Skills Training and Knowledge Sharing interactions at Mzuzu Stadium before proceeding to Sunbird Mzuzu for a public lecture by Mzuzu University vice-chancellor Professor Wales Singini. He will deliver a lecture on Addressing the Systematic and Social economic Barriers for Youth Participation in Emerging Changing Green Sectors. In an interview, Mzuzu Youth Network chairperson Salome Kadari said they were expecting a huge turnout.

The Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) has announced that the Lilongwe South by-election will be held on January 30, 2019. MEC spokesperson Sangwani Mwafulirwa says preparations are underway in Lilongwe, and the official campaign for the by-election will end on January 28. The official results will be announced on January 31. The Lilongwe South by-election was suspended last year due to violence perpetrated by parties involved in the elections.

Content:
Daudi Chikwanje, the Eastern Region Governor of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), has been granted bail after being accused of inciting violence.
Chikwanje was arrested on September 30 following remarks made at a rally on September 28 at Nsanama trading centre in Machinga district, which were captured on video.
A high-profile team of lawyers, comprising Cassius Chidothi, Yusuf Nthenda, and Ishmael Wesley, represented Chikwanje in court.

Title: Ericsson donates computers to ZA schools
Content:
Ericsson Limited, through the Millennium Village Project (MVP), on Wednesday gave 50 laptop computers to St Anthony and Mayera Community Day Secondary School (CDSS) during a function held at St Anthony in Zomba.
The computers are part of the connect to learn (CTL) programme which MVP is implementing in schools from Mwandama Cluster under Traditional Authority Mlumbe in the district.
Speaking when presenting the computers, Ericsson (Kenya) Limited’s Lois Mbagua said her company is participating in enhancing the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) on education.
“The purpose of MDG 3 is gender parity and universal education, we are donating computers to MVP who selects the beneficiary schools in their catchment area. I can say out of the 10 schools in Sub-Sahara Africa, we are giving at least 25 computers per school,’ she said.
MVP team leader and science coordinator Dr Andrew Daudi said 50 girls won the CTL scholarship and qualified to receive the computers.
Said Daudi; ‘’St Anthony will get 35 laptop computers whereas Mayera will receive 15. These computers will enhance communication in many other things, so, I urge parents and teachers to look after this property and nurture the gift.’’
Speaking on behalf of the students, Overton Phiri thanked MVP for the donation.
“We feel privileged for being considered because in today’s world, we cannot over emphasize the role information and communication technology (ICT) is playing in various spheres of our life. 
‘’Not only will we be able to know the basic skills of computers, but also surf the internet where we world connect with students from other parts of the world to beef up what our teachers give us in class,’ he said.
Author: Joy Khakona

Title: Atupele's motorcade raises eyebrows
Content: Political and legal minds have described as “a waste of public resources “ the allocation of a motorcade with a police escort vehicle and enhanced security to President Peter Muthalika’s running mate Atupele Muluzi. During his whistle – stop rallies in Eastern Region districts of Zomba, Machinga, Balaka and Mangochi on saturday Atupele – who is United Democratic Front (UDF) president and ministers in Muthalika’s Cabinet – was seen using a motorcade, including a police lead vehicle (sweeper) with a siren and amber lights. This development came barely two days after mutharika, who is Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) torchbearer in the July 2 presidential election return, named Atupele as his running mate.  The two parties are in an electoral alliance. In a written response yesterday, Garton Kamchezera, a professor of law at Chancellor College – a constituent college of the University of Malawi, said there is no legal basis to accord a Cabinet minister or presidential running mate such a privilege. He said; “These are the soft of privileges and benefits accorded to the President and Vice – President under the President under the Presidents [Salaries and Benefits] Act. If it has to be done, l cannot find any law that permits the use of resources. This sort of abuse of public resources and opportunity is an indication of a creeping self–centered dictatorship. “This is because the President is requiring or allowing privilege and advantage for his running mate in disregard of the Constitution and the law in general.” In a separate interview, politicians –cum – commentator Humphrey Mvula said the development can be attributed to a political attempt to raise the profile of Atupele, son to the country’s former president Bakili Muluzi. He said; “However, on a broader scheme of things, this is a serious abuse of power and an abuse of public resources by the President. His competitors will use it against him and some CSOs may consider taking the matter to court.” Speaking on condition of anonymity a retired senior police officer said while a motorcade can be assigned to anyone, priority is given to the President, Vice – President and other important visiting dignitaries, including heads of State.  “The lead vehicle acts as a warning to people ahead that anything may happen,” said the retired senior police officer. Minister of Information Civic Education and Communications Technology Mark Botomani said the arrangement does not mean anything significant. He referred the matter to National Police spokesperson James Kadadzera who could, however, not be reached on his phone. When then Ntcheu North East Legislator Everton Chimulirenji, now serving as Minister of Disaster Management Affairs and Public Events, was unveiled as Mutharika’s running mate in the disputed May 21, 2019, Tripartite Elections, he was also accorded beefed up security and a motorcade.

Title: USI MEETS APM OVER BINGU MAUSOLEUM
Content: Minister of Tourism, Culture and Wildlife Michael Usi, accompanied by senior officials from his ministry, yesterday visited Democratic Progressive Party leader and former president Peter Mutharika at his private home in Mangochi to discuss how government can take care of the mausoleum of former president Bingu wa Mutharika.  In an interview yesterday, Usi said he had fruitful discussions with Mutharika regarding the resting place of his brother known as Mpumulo wa Bata at Ndata in Thyolo. "President Professor Arthur Peter Mutharika is grateful to the President [Chakwera] for the directive to re-engage the family over the Bingu Mausoleum. There were some issues which we should be able to resolve and quickly move forward," he said. The minister's visit comes after Mutharika, through his spokesperson Shadric Namalomba, issued a statement reacting to a directive Chakwera gave to Usi to ensure the place is taken care of.
Author: Lucy Mkandawire

Content: Chakwera asserts, “I hold no grudges against anyone. I was taught by my parents and by God to not hold grudges. The DPP has made us forget our culture. This party should no longer be in government.”

When l started the ‘agenda for change’ people.

Content: Vise-president Michael Usi is today representing president Lazarus Chakwera at the inauguration of the president –elect Paul Kagame in Kigali , Rwanda . Content: A group of Malawi Congress Party supporters called Dowa Born Free has today donated assorted items to some elderly women in the areas of Traditional Authorities Mkukula, Chiwere and Msakambewa respectively in Dowa District. Chairlady for the group, Febe Jere, says they thought of presenting the donation as one way of celebrating with the elderly during the festive season. A beneficiary, Dana Zingero of T/A Chiwere in the district, applauded the group for the gesture. The donation included soap, sugar, rice, salt and pails among others.

Title: APM, NTABA RISK CRIMINAL CHARGES
Content:
Former president Peter Munthalika and his ex-aide Hetherwick Ntaba face criminal proceedings in connection with the 2018 murder in Machinga of 
MacDonald Masambuka, a 24-year-old man with albinism.  
In a letter dated July 1, 2022, addressed to the office of the inspector general of police, Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), Steve Kayuni directed Malawi Police Service to begin criminal proceedings following some testimonies during Masambuka’s case.

Title: UNDUE HITS AT APM COMEBACK
Content: Governance commentator Undale Mwakasungula has faulted former president Peter Mutharika's comeback, saying the decision warrants careful сonsideration in a statement on Saturday, he said Mutharika's pursuit of a comeback has Esas numerous consequences on Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). The statement was in reaction to Muthanika's announcement on Friday that he will lead his party in the September 2005 Tripartite Elections. Said Mwakasungula; Mutharika need to understand that there is life after the presidency and that there are various ways to contribute to Malawi whale outside the government. It is imperative, therefore, for APM to reflect on whether his candidacy aligns with the best interests of Malawians." Speaking during a press briefing in Mangochi on Friday, Mutharika sad he wants to contest in 2025 because the Lazarus Chakwera led Tonse administration has failed to govern Malawi. Mutharika lost the 2020 court-sanctioned fresh Presidential Election.
Author: Lloyd Chitsulo

Title: Chakwera keen on clean cities
Content:
’The city rates themselves are not diligently collected or paid, even though the money is desperately needed; and even the trash of our cities is not properly disposed of, which is both a health hazard and an eye sore.
‘’We can not blame city authorities or street vendors alone for this mess. We all use and need our cities in one way or another, we are not all pulling together in the same direction to create for our country the kind of cities that can be said to be modern, or organised, or beautiful,’’ Chakwera said.
On Friday, Lilongwe city Council vowed to remove all illegal vendors plying their trade in the streets of the capital, saying the decision is final.
Lilongwe City Council mayor Juliana Kaduya said in an interview following a protect by some vendors who marched to Civic Offers in City centre on Friday to force the city fathers to rescind plans to conduct the clean up exercise.
On Thursday, Kaduya, who was escorted by police officers and other stakeholders, toured part of Old Town where illegal vending has been worsening over the years and the mayor’s visit gave a signal to the vendors that the new administration was planning to remove them from the streets; hence, the protest.
According to Kaduya, the vendors who stormed Lilongwe City Council premises acknowledged that they were trading in undesignated places but pleaded for more time before being removed.
The mayor, however, observed that the council would not rescind its plans because it wants to deal with lawlessness that has now characterised the capital city.
Said Kaduya: ‘’Imagine we now have people openly selling ‘zigege’ and fresh vegetables right on the streets? Where in the world do such things happen? I know others would like to politicise this clean up but this new government will not relent and we will ensure that our town is admirable.’’
She said the exercise of removing the vendors ought to have been executed a few days ago but the council has gone back to the drawing board to restrategise with its stakeholders such as police on how best to carry out the exercise.
In an interview, one vendor Cathy Bokosi from Area 36, who sells bananas, said the only ideal place to do her business is in the central business district, adding that once vendors are removed, she will struggle to feed her family.
She said: ‘’At least I make K5 000 on a good day and it is enough to keep us going at home, who can buy my bananas in our township? We rely on these well-to-do people who come into town.’’
But a governance expert Makhumbo Munthali in an interview last night attributed the problem to politicians, who in their attempt to win votes, have let vendors trade in unauthorised spaces in the cities.
‘’You actually see authorities slowing down in moving out street vendors that ply their trade in unauthorised spaces, especially when we’re going towards elections.
‘’I hope the Tonse Alliance administration is serious about this and will push vendors to the designated areas they belong to, they need not be apologetic about it,’’ Munthali said.
The streets in the cities are filthy and apart from selling vegetables along some pavements of some city buildings, some streets vendors are, at worst, roasting meats, sausage and green maize right in the middle of the cities.

Content: DPP President Peter Mutharika plans to appeal the Constitutional Court's verdict, which declared him not duly elected, as confirmed by the State House Press Secretary. The court nullified Mutharika’s reelection and mandated a fresh poll within 150 days.

The interparte hearing of the Zomba Magistrate Court order on Thom Mpinganjira's cancelled warrant of arrest has been shifted to Tuesday at 2 PM. Judiciary spokesperson Agnes Patemba said Mpinganjira's lawyers were not available at the court. But one of Mpinganjira's lawyers, Patrice Nkhono, says there was a communication mix-up between the judge's office and the lawyers on the date. Zomba Magistrate Ben Chitsakamire cancelled Mpinganjira's warrant of arrest which was obtained at Lilongwe Magistrate Court, a decision which Patemba described as irregular. Mpinganjira was arrested last week on allegations that he planned to bribe judges hearing the presidential elections case.

Title: Embrace digital, minister urges local accountants
Content:
Minister of Finance and Economic Affair Sosten Gwengwe has urged local accountants to move with modern times and embrace digital in their operations, saying a digital economy is a precursor to socio-economic development.
He said this on Thursday evening in Mangochi during the opening of the three-day 2022 Institute of Chartered Accountants in Malawi (Icam) Annual Lakeshore Conference in Mangochi.
Gwengwe said as the country is heading towards a robust digital economy, accounting professionals should be the first to embrace the digital philosophy.
"Embrace digital payments.Embrace online transactions.Allow investments in information and communications technology infrastructure," said the minister. "Let the training of accountants flourish through virtual models. It is high time the curriculum embraces digital financing models." Speaking at the conference themed 'Digitising the Malawi Economy: Stepping Into the New Future, Gwengwe said a robust digital economy starts with its being embraced by the citizenry.
But he rued what he called "clandestine dealing mindset" that is not open to transparent models  of doing things.
"As a result, our embracing of digital solutions is looked upon with scepticism as we fear that we might be exposed. This ought to change. This digital revolution is meant to steer our country into a new direction of progress," said Gwengwe.
He said the government system is slowly embracing a digital economy which is key to processing of financial transactions, thereby reducing risks as it is easy to follow the movement of money. “Digital transactions have trails that can easily be followed at the click of a button,”said Gwengwe. In her remarks, outgoing Icam president Phales Kachingwe said there is no denying that the accounting profession cannot be left behind. She said  “Digital revolution is taking over. As accountants, we have an opportunity to change with the times or we will remain behind.””We have to embrace technology, master technology and make it part and parcel of the profession.” Kachingwe said digitization brings efficiency, adding that in the education sector, for instance, digital economy provides hope to those residing in hard-to-reach areas. Icam acting chief executive officer Charles Chimpeni said the group's membership has grown to nearly 3 000, and their plan is to hit 3 500 by the end of this year and 4 000 by 2023.
Author: Chikondi Chiyembekeza

Content: The EU Electoral Observer Mission to Malawi, which on Wednesday decided against releasing its final report on the May 21 Tripartite Election, says it will only issue the document after the Constitutional Court has delivered its ruling on the presidential election results case. The mission, whose representatives arrived in Malawi Wednesday afternoon, has since urged Malawians to remain calm and foster peace while awaiting the court outcome, set to be delivered in mid-February.

The Malawi Law Society (MLS) has implored the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) to act with a sense of urgency on the matter reported to the bureau by Chief Justice Andrew Nyirenda regarding attempts to bribe judges handling the presidential election results case. MLS has commended the Chief Justice for reporting the attempted bribe and expressed its trust in the ACB, saying the graft-busting body will act accordingly considering the importance of the matter.

Title: CHILIMA’S BODY ARRIVES HOME FOR BURIAL
Content: A sombre mood engulfed Mbirimtengenji Village at Nsipe in Ntcheu yesterday evening as they welcomed the body of the departed Vice-President Saulos Klaus Chilima. Hundreds of people, including traditional leaders, politicians and religious leaders could not hold back their tears as reality sunk in that Chilima was gone. The vehicle carrying the remains of the fallen Vice-President was welcomed by loud cries to St. Peter Clover Nsipe Parish for mass. The Vice-President and eight others died in a plane crash on Monday last week in Viphya Highlands as they were flying on Malawi Defence Force (MDF) plone to attend the burial of former Attorney General Ralph Kasambara in Nkhata Bay. Others on board were former first lady Shanil Dzimbiri, Lukas Kapheni, Chisomo Chimaneni, Gloria Mtukule, Dan Kanyemba and Abdul Lapukeni. The flight was operated by Colonel Owen Sambalopa, Major Flora Selemani and Major Wallace Aidin from MDF, In the picture, people at around 5pm wait for Chilima's body to arrive.
Author: Haneeph Maulana

Title: NDITHANDIZENI KUTI CHOONADI CHIDZIWIKE PA IMFA YA A CHILIMA | MARY CHILIMA
Content:
Mai Mary Chilima, amene anali mkazi wa malemu a Saulos Chilima, apempha Amalawi kuwathandizira kuti pakhale kafukufuku wina wapadera pa ngozi ya ndege yomwe idapha amuna awo ndi anthu ena asanu ndi atatu. 
Iwo alemba izi pa tsamba lawo la Facebook pomwe lero akukumbukira tsiku lomwe adalowa m'banja ndi a Chilima. 
Pempheroli ladza pomwe magulu ena kuphatikizapo CDEDI, Public Affairs Committee komanso chipani cha UTM akhala akupemphanso kuti pakhale kafukufuku wina.
Maguluwa akukhulupilira kuti lipoti la akatswiri aku Germany silingabweretse poyera mayankho ena monga chomwe chidachedwetsa kufufuza ndegeyi itasowa.
Koma m'mbuyomu, nduna yofalitsa nkhani a Moses Kunkuyu idati boma laika chikhulupiliro chake pa akatswiriwa.

Title: UN CHIEF OFFERS CONDOLENCES ON CHILIMA, 8 OTHERS’ DEATHS
Content: United Nations (UN) Secretary General Antonio Guterres has conveyed his condolences to deceased families and the people of Malawi for the loss of Vice- President Saulos Chilima and eight others. Deputy spokesperson for the Secretary General Farhan Haq said in a statement that Gutes was deeply saddened by the tragic death of the nine in an airplane crash in Mzimba on June 10, 2024. Reads the statement in part: "The United Nations stands in solidarity with Malawians in this difficult period,". Meanwhile, Malawi Government has opened condolence books in Mzužu, Zomba, Lilongwe and Blantyre city councils for members of the public to pay tribute to Chilima. Apart from the Vice-President, the plane crash also claimed the lives of former first lady Patricia Shanil Dziarlats, Major Flora Selemani, Major Wales Aidin, Colonel Oren Sambalopa, Dan Kanyemba, Lucas Kapheni, Chisomo Chimaneni and Abdul Lapken.

Title: Govt tips colleges to escalate research
Content:
Government has challenged higher education institutions to support its digitalisation drive which seeks to enhance access to education, increase research output and data for effective decision-making.
Ministry of Education director of science, technology and innovation chomora Mikaela made the call in Mangochi on Friday during the Malawi Research and Education Network (Maren) consultative meeting for the Southern Region. He said : “Government has intensified its drive to digitalis’s the education sector and it is important that higher institutions take a leading role in supporting us realize this goal.” Mikaela started the ministry is currently implementing a number of digitalisation initiatives, including the Higher Education Management Information Systems, education broadcasting radio and providing Internet access without financial cost for educational websites. The workshop, which was preceded by similar workshops in the Northern and Central regions, drew students, librarians, university network and system engineers and finance and administration personnel from at least 18 higher education institutions from the South. Maren chief executive officer Solomon Dindi said they are committed to improving service delivery, describing the consultative meetings as important for the network’s strategic planning.
Author: Hastings Ndebvu

Title: Atupele to abolish Unima chancellorship
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi says he will abolish the position of chancellor of the University of Malawi (Unima) if he wins the May 20 elections to make the university independent. Atupele made the pledge on Friday during a public lecture held at Chancellor College, a Unima constituent college, centred around the youths and political leadership. He said the current situation where the sitting president is chancellor of the university has created problems for the institution whenever lecturers, students and government have differed. In 2011, Unima lecturers were locked in a protracted eight months battle with government over academic freedom after former inspector general of police Peter Mukhito summoned Dr Blessings Chinsinga of Chancellor College to explain remarks he made in a policy class. Former president the late Bingu wa Mutharika defended Mukhito to the end, saying the police chief would not apologise to the lecturers for his actions. The battle grounded Chancellor College, the University’s main campus, which remained closed throughout the duration of the dispute after lecturers boycotted classes. “I dont think it will be wisw for me to cling to the position when history has shown that academic freedom is affected. Furthermore, funds channelled to the entity are abused,” said Atupele.

Richard Chimwendo Banda, Secretary General of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP), has highlighted the government’s infrastructure development achievements, citing them as crucial to the country’s sustainable growth.
Speaking at a rally in Mgona, Lilongwe City, Chimwendo emphasized the significance of infrastructure in achieving development goals.
“Infrastructure is central to the achievement of our development goals. It’s an enormous economic multiplier, providing dividends for the economy,” he said.

Title: TEMBO TAKES GRACCEFULL BOW
Content:
Former Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president John Tembo yesterday hailed the party’s convention which barred him from standing for third term, said democracy triumphed.
Tembo, one of the longest serving politicians in MCP as well as in the country’s said in an interview the convention decided on the sticky issue of too many presidential aspirants.
Delegates to the MCP convention held at Natural resources College (NRC) in Lilongwe elected former Malawi Assemblies of God president the Reverend Dr Lazarous Chakwera to be the party’s torchbearer in the 2014 presidential elections.
He said, “I am delighted with the process. Democracy has triumphed.’’
Tembo said he offered to retire from the national executive committee (NEC) and from standing as a presidential candidate.
‘’the convention agreed [to request].’’ Said Tembo, who told delegates to decide whether he could content for a third term.
He added; ‘’I could not stand if the constitution was not amended. Delegates said they could not amend the constitution, so the convention agreed with my request to retire.’’
But Tembo dodged questions on what lies ahead in his political career.
Tembo first contested for a parliamentary seat in the first multiparty general elections in 1961.
He rose through the ranks while holding some of the key positions in government, including that of minister of Finance and minister of state as well as governor of the Reserve Bank of Malawi (RBM).
Tembo was one of the key figures in MCP throughout the party’s 31-year rule under the late Hastings Kamuzu Banda which ended in May 1994.
Political scientists have said MCP convention delegates rejection of Tembo from standing is a manifestation that constitutionalism was taking root in the party.
On how the delegates decision could impact on Tembo’s political career as leader of opposition In Parliament, political scientist Ernest Thindwa is quoted as having said Tembo is a safe on his position
Author: EMMANUEL MUWAMBA

Title: Mandalas Legacy can move Malawi forward – Chakwera
Content:
Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president Reverend Lazarus Chakwera yesterday said departed South Africa icon Nelson Mandales legacy can help move Malawi forward if its leaders and servants can embrace his selflessness, peacemaking forgiveness, discipline and honest among others.
Chakwera said this at press briefing at Kamuzu International Airport (KIA) on his arrival from South Africa where he had gone to pay his last respects to Mandale.
Before landing, there was a scaring moment as the plane Chakwera boarded aborted landing after already touching the KIA runway and stayed air for about 20 minutes.
Said Chakwera; ‘’ Nelson Mandale maybe buried, but his ideals resonate with human struggle. The discipline with which he led his life and South Africa people to give them freedom is one which we can learn from. We can make Malawi a country for all people and where everybody is valued regardless of region where one is coming from.
‘’He has taught us that you we can conquer hatred with love and have a society with inclusiveness. As a nation that is seeking to rebuild its foundations, it is possible that we can disciple ourselves and take the obstacles we are facing at steppingstones to the future we all want,’’ said Chakwera.
He said he views Mandales body on Friday at the Union Building in Pretoria where it lay in state for three days before burial on Sunday.
He said it is against the spirit of reconciliation, forgiveness and love to deny business opportunities who have fallen out of favor with the incumbent leadership.
‘’Nobody should be victimized because of change of leadership in government. In terms of development, it is critical that business should shrive regardless of who is in government. What we need Is to embrace integrity, honesty and faithfulness as characteristics of selfless leadership,’’ he said.
Author: Phillip Pemba

Title: Can Usi fulfill his political philosophy?
Content:
Bofore Usi joined active politics in 2018, he had radical ideas . 
His ideas, which he shared through his movement called Odya Zake Alibe Mlandu, focused mainly on how to empower marginalised masses to live fulfilled lives. 
To him, a fulfilled life include having the means to generate  income , being politically conscious to understand or to descern politic rhetoric and become agents of change in society. 
Thus, he did not tire to speak against what he percieved as injustice when people, especially those from underprivileged backgrounds, were failing to get basic necessities such as food, shelter and clothing. In his many radio and television interviews, Usi condemned some government policies which, he said, were not helping the poor become economically independent. 
Usi continued to speak on the behalf of the poor, fighting for their rights to economic prosperity through his Tikuferanji soap opera, aired on malawi Broadcasting corporation (MBC) Due to its criticism of government’s policies and decisions, MBC stopped airing the soap. 
But that did not stop him from preaching his ideas of justice and fairness for all. He started addressing people at rallies, expounding his Odya Zake Alibe , Mlandu philosophy. 
Usi established branches Nationwide. He criss – crossed the country, telling people not to lay their hopes in the politicians’ hands because they could not save them from their poverty. 
During his trips to Nsanje Boma, Madziabango in Blantyre and Mulanje, Usi talked about the importance of people finding means to generate income and stop patronising politicians for handouts. 
In July, he told people in Nsanje that only empowered people can make sound decisions. He said only people who depends on themselves sleep peacefully, without having to worry about being arrested or bullied by their benefactors. 
In his speech, Usi gave an analogy  of a married couple that decides to hug in a bush. 
He said; “ munthu woti watenga mkazi wamwini kupita naye ku loji amayenda mwamantha kuti akugwira. Koma munthu oti watenga mkazi wako, olo utamuhaga pa tchire akakuona, angonena kuti musiyeni akudza zake ( if you take somebody’s wife to a lodge, you will be afraid of being caught, but when you are with your wife,you can even hug her in the bush and people will not cast stone at you). 
Throuhg this analogy, Usi drove a very important lesson home that there is joy and dignity in one’s labour. 
His philosophy challenged the notion that government or politicians are the solutions to people's problems. To the contrary, politicians, according to Usi, were the source of people's problems. 
When john F. Kennedy was sworn in as American president, he told people not to think about what the government can do for them, but what they can do for the government. 
Oftentimes, people have looked to government or politicians to solve their problems, only to get disappointed in the end, urgued Usi.  
“He who feeds you controls you, handouts from politicians create Beggars out of people. Handouts reduce you to mere objects and gives politicians opportunity to exploit you,” he said 
His message, comes at a time poverty levels were escalating, resonated with the masses.Some of this people were surviving on relief food almost every year. Hunger caused by climate change shocks and poverty exercarbated by limited employment and business opportunities almost made many people lose hope and start thinking that handouts were the only way to earn a living.  
The situation was not what the nationalist leaders envisaged during the struggle for independence for the nationalist leaders were fighting for the country to achieve freedom and economic emancipation. 
Yet, according to Tiyambe Zeleza’s Smouldering Charcoal, Politicians that took over power from the British colonial administration betrayed those dreams. 
Zeleza argued that the leaders enriched themselves at the expense of the people they wre supposed to empower socio – economically. 
This is what Usi condemned and swore to change through his movement. 
Ironically, Usi joined active politics in 2018 to rub shoulders with the very politicians he criticised of betraying the masses. 
In July 2018, he attended the launch of a political party founded by former vise – president Saulos Chilima at Nyamba Freedom Park in Blantyre. 
 In his short speech, Usi reminded Chilima and other politicians who joined Chilima’s UTM party not to betray the throng that has gathered at the park. 
That afternoon, Usi said; “ Panotu babwera anthu ambiri. Koma choti mudxiwe ndi chakuti inu siwoyamba kudxadzitsa anthu pa Njamba pano. Mbuyomu enatu andale anatera koma mapeto ake adakhumudwitsa anthu (you are not the first politicians to attract a huge gathering at Njamba. Some poiticians have done it before but they ended up betraying the...... once ... into power). 
Usi eventually joined UTM party to work with Chilima, and together form a ....... to take over power from the Democratic Progressive Party. Their campaign ...................  
He said; “ Ine ndili mwana, kwathu ndimadya mkute mawamawa. Koma lero ndi angati m’midzimu womwe amadya mkute?  (when l was young, i used to eat nsima left the previous night, but there days, children rarely eat such leftovers because thay dont have enough to eat). 
However, chilima and Usi did not win the presidency in 2019. When the court ordered for a fresh presidential election. Chilima became Chakwera’s running mate in the 2020 fresh presidential elections. 
The situation deprived Usi of a chance to fulfill his political beliefs through a UTM and government. 
However, last week, Chakwera appointed him Vice- President following the death of Chilima in a plane crash.

Title: Muluzi's ambitious pledge for Karonga
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential hopeful Atupele Muluzi and running mate Frank Mwenifumbo have promised to revamp Kalonga’s business culture if elected next Tuesday. They said this during a Rally at Balaka Community Day Secondary School in the shoreline border district on Saturday. Muluzi stated that the district bordening Tanzania is best – placed to be the hub of business that can spur Malawi’s economic growth and regional integration in the line with the 16 – nation Southern African Development Community (Sadc) treaty. He pledged to end regionalism and form an inclusive administration that will “share the national cake equally and equitably”. Muluzi said he demonstrated his new agenda for change by picking Karonga Central ex – legislator Mwenifumbo, who he described as “the most hardworking and experienced politician”. He stated; “If you elect us on May 21, we will continue where UDF stopped in 2004. For starters, it is UDF that brought cellphones, free primary school education, TV station and more radio stations. The UDF – led government will bring more innovations that will also bring job opportunities to the youth. “If the Northern Region registered meaningful developments, it was during the UDF era. Talk of Mzuzu Courthouse, Mzuzu Centra Hospital.” Mwenefumbo said only Muluzi can restore economic activities in Karonga. He promised that the UDF administration will exempt salaries workers earning less thanK150 000 a month from tax, up front K35 000. He also promised to raise the minimum wage from K25 000 to K70 000.
APM and the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) have filed grounds of appeal against the Constitutional Court’s ruling that nullified the presidential election results.

Member of Parliament for Nkhata Bay West, Chrispine Mphande, has brought another motion in the house that seeks to amend the Electoral Commission Act to, among others, give powers to the Public Appointments Committee (PAC) on the appointment of Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) top officials. However, Mulanje Bale MP, Victor Musowa, argues that the country should not have laws aimed at firing people.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Title: Experts warn Chakwera on new laws
Content:
Law experts have warned that any attempts by the new Tonse Alliance administration to formulate legislations or amend existing laws targeting people that committed crimes in the past regime would not pass the constitutionality base.
The legal experts have said if the ideas is to criminalise some thing that was not criminal or to make criminal laws to apply on crime committed in the past; it would be illegal and unacceptable.
President Chakwera, in his national address on July 25 2020, said his administration had resolved to forgo amnesty that could be offered to looters of public funds but would instead in consultation with minister of justice and constitutional affairs, initiate a process to come up with new legislations to help his government deal with politicians or public servants that plundered the public purse during the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.
The Minister of Justice said no meeting has taken place yet on the issue of new legislation the president spoke about.
Mvalo said such issues that require the attention of the Cabinet remain confidential until at a time such issues are laid before the parliament.
Attorney General (AG) Chikosa silungwe, on the other hand, said in an interview on Wednesday that he was aware of the president’s intentions to have the new legislation but said a planned meeting between the president and other relevant officials was yet to take place.
Silungwe said he was not in a position to discuss more before that meeting takes place.
‘’Give us some time, I will be able to furnish you with more information after that meeting,’’ the AG said.
However, Chakwera’s spokesperson Sean Kampondeni said in a response to a questionnaire gaps in the current legislation are to do with stiffer punishments for looters and protections for whistle blowers.
‘’Other gaps have to do with the need for a legislative framework for the creation for special courts to deal with corruption cases and dispose of them expeditiously.
‘’Another gap has to do with legislation related to lifestyle audits and the seizure of inexplicable wealth owned by both public servants and their proxies behind whom they may attempt to hide their ill-gotten wealth,’’ Kampondeni said.
He further said there are legislative gaps related to holding financial institutions accountable for being complicit in the movement of illicit funds, including banks that fail to do their part in ensuring that their accountants are not conduits for harboring stolen taxes.
Chakwera’s spokesperson admitted laws do not apply retrospectively, but said the biggest problem in Malawi was that even existing laws have not been enforced at all, resulting in a culture of stealing and looting public funds with impunity.
‘’His Excellency Dr. Lazarus Chakwera has made it abundantly clear that such impunity will be countenanced no longer,’’ he said. Chakwera in his address to the nation on July 25 warned people that stole public funds that they should avoid seeking public sympathy but return what they stole as the law is going to take its course on them.
In the address, the president referred to the recent auditor’s genera’s report in demonstrating that the culture of corruption has permeated every structure in government.chakwera said it would be up to the courts to exercise leniency on people who would not waste their time by ‘’confessing’’ their signs and return what they stole.
‘’Other people think we choose who to arrest; that’s not our style. We’ll allow the responsible authorities to do their job. State agents would operate depending on what evidence thay have, but we’ll not push them to do something,’’ Chakwera said.
The president said the plunder under the DPP administration was pervasive as about K1.3 million was lost, but asked Malawians to be calm as the Tonse Alliance administration drains the swamp.Chakwera hinted he considered taking this route after their discovery that the fraud, corruption and theft committed during the DPP administration was unimaginable and worse that the infamous cash gate, with a system rotten to the core.
But law expert Justin Dzonzi warned in an interview yesterday that coming up with new legislations or amending criminal laws to target a particular group of people that supposedly committed what were not offences in the past would be a process in futility as such would easily be challenged.
‘’But we do have sufficient laws to achieve desires of the president even without coming up with new legislations. To amend the laws, in theory it is possible, but chances are high that it cannot pass constitutionality base.
‘’Retrospectively will be one issue to make it illegal. That process, if indeed that’s the intention, is not necessary. We’ve penal code, Corrupt Practices Act and Financial Crimes Act, enough to adequately deal with all the issues at hand,’’ Dzonzi said.
Garton Kamchedzera, a professor of law at University of Malawi’s Chancellor College, said in an interview yesterday that it depends on what Chakwera’s administration wants to do with changes they want to make.
‘’If it’s to do with fine-tuning procedures to make a particular law efficient and effective, that’s fine. But if it’s creating offences where there was none, it will be a challenge,’’ Kamchedzera said.
He said any new law start applying from the date it has been enacted.
Kamchedzera said there can only be exceptions in other laws than criminal where parliament can expressly state that a particular law would apply retrospectively and proceed to have it backdated.
He said in criminal law, courts presume that an act of parliament does not apply retrospectively unless parliament expressly states so.
‘’When it comes to criminal law, the issues of rights come in. If something was not an offence, it means the person affected was not guided rightly and you cannot punish that person,’’ he said.
Kamchedzera said so, too, is the case of amending the law to bring stiffer punishment would only start applying from the time an amendment is made, not retrospectively.
But Titus Mvalo, who is minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs in the Tonse Alliance administration ushered into power through the court-sanctioned June 23 2020 fresh presidential election, said in an interview yesterday that what the president hinted on are issues that have processed that begin at Cabinet level.
Author: FRANK NAMANGALE

Title: DPP VISIT CHILIMA PLANE CRASH SITE
Content:
DPP publicity secretary Hon Suleman and Director of Women Hon Mary Navicha while coming from Mzuzu City visited the site where the plane of Late Hon Dr Saulos Klaus Chilima crashed.
According to Suleman; they thought it  wise to pay the respect to the fallen hero Dr Chilima who died in a very tragic death at the site. Accompanying him was the director of women Mary Navicha and others 
At the rally in Mzuzu Hon Suleman called upon Prof Peter Muthalika that once ushered into power he should consider building a memorial tower at the site for historical purposes. He also asked the current government to stop selling the site sitting that it's against Malawi ls wish.

Title: Usi replaces Chilima as country’s Vice – President
Content:
Minister of Natural Resources and Climate Change Michael Usi will this afternoon be sworn in as the country’s Vice – President replacing Saulos Chilima who died in a plane crash on June 10 alongside eight others. 
This follows President Lazarus Chakwera’s exercise of his office’s powers under Section 84 (2) of the constitution to “appoint a person to fill the vacancy in the Office of First Vice – President within seven days from the date the vacancy arose”.  
Secretary to the President and Cabinet Colleen Zamba said in a statement last evening that Usi’s appointment is with immediate effect. 
Reads the statement “His Excellency Dr Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera, President of the Republic of Malawi, in exercise of his powers under Section 84 of Constitution of the Republic of Malawi, has appointed Dr Michael Bizwick Usi, as Vice – President of the Republic of Malawi. 
“The Vice – President Designate, the Right Honourable Dr Michael Bizwick Usi, shall take his oath of office on Friday, 21 June 2024, at the Parliament Building [in Lilongwe] at 15:00 hours.” 
Ironically, in the 2019 Tripartite Elections he paired with Chilima as his running mate on the maiden UTM Party ticket in the disputed presidential election that was nullified in February 2020 after Chilima and Malawi Congress Party (MCP) candidate Chakwera petitioned the courts. In the court sanctioned presidential vote in June 2020, Chakwera teamed up with Chilima and triumphed. 
Usi last evening declined to comment on his appointment and suggested that he be interviewed at a later date. 
On the other hand, UTM Party spokesperson Felix Njawala said he would react later to the appointment . However, by press time at 10,30pm he was yet to revert. 
However, the political pundits have hailed Chakwera for the choice of new Vice – President, saying it shows his respect to the partnership between MCP and UTM in the Tonse Alliance and a perfect honour to Chilima’s soul. 
But the pundits differ on Usi’s ability to help Chakwera garner more votes in the September 16, 2025, General elections. 
In an interview, University of Malawi associate professor of political science Boniface Dulani said the appointment will cement relations between MCP and UTM. 
He said it is inevitable that there will be some pockets of resistance in UTM Party, especially as some members do not perceive Usi as the party’s loyal member’ 
Said Dulani; “It’s a safe appointment to the extent that Dr, Chilima and this shows the president has appointed the most senior person in UTM Party. It also shows some commitment to the alliance and honours Chilima. 
“Of course, there will be some people within UTM who will ne unhappy because there have been romours about the loyalty of Dr, Michael Usi to UTM. But if the president had overlooked this appointment and picked someone else from UTM, it could also have put him in a very awkward position,” 
He said there are also people within the  MCP who could have wanted one of their own to be appointed but that could not have held the alliance together. 
Political Science Association spokesperson Mavuto Bamusi urged Usi to continue, among others, publishing for public sector reforms that the late Chilima championed. 
He said; “Malawi has been lacking in corporate governance and public sector accountability, which all need public sector reforms. So, Usi has to push for this. He should also advance the anti–corruption agenda which Chilima used to champion. 
“Further, the VP should advance the unity card because Malawi is in dire need for unity because this is key to development. Finally, he should not be bent pleasing the MCP or shy party supporters but put interest of Malawians at heart. 
Unlike Dulani, Bamusi noted that the choice of Usi could be repositioning political dynamics towards running mates in the September 2025 elections where parties are looking at gaining votes from other region. 
Chilima. Who died alongside eight others in a military plane crash in Chikangawa Forest on June 10, was laid to rest at Nsipe in Ntcheu District last Monday.
MCP’s Lazarus Chakwera and UTM’s Saulos Chilima have exited the courtroom.
Author: Alessio Banda

Content: Malawi Electoral commission has declared Peter Dimba winner of the Lilongwe South Constituency  by-election that took place on Thursday. Announcing the results in Blantyre on Friday, Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson Jane Ansah said Dimba got 11,230 votes, Frank Mazizi of DPP got 1,663 votes while Patson Kachingwe    (Independent) got 1800 votes. Samson Phinifolo (Independent) got 295 votes and Julius Chombwe (MMD) had 50 votes. The election had 32,459 registered voters and 15,207 turned out to vote. The by-elections were postponed last year due to reported cases of violence during the campaign period after Mazizi complained to Mec over violence in the area.
Author: Isaac Salima

Title: Malawians deserve better leadership- Atupele
Content:
Former United Democratic Front (UDF) leader Atupele Muluzi says he is championing a reset button for a new Malawi to save lives of Malawians, suffering due to current poor governance and bad leadership. 
He said this yesterday at St Augustine III Primary School ground in Mangochi District during the party’s mega rally held to commemorate its 30th anniversary. 
Atupele told thousands of suppoters that gathered at the venue that Malawians are getting poorer and are wallowing in poverty under the Tonse Aliiance administration led by President Lazarus Chakwera. 
He said Tonse leadership has failed to take care of them and they deserve better leadership come 2025. 
Atupele said; “Malawi chose democracy 30 ago to choose leaders of their choice to run the country while improving people’s welfare. We call this power to the people. This means you have power. 
“But it is unfortunate that there is nothing that is progressing in the country. But, if you want chane, it is possible if you can decide it [in 2025].” 
He further said it is unfortunate that the once blessed Malawi is now enveloped with corruption which is affecting the development of the country. 
“Malawi is engulfed with corruption. However, l have a hope that it is only UDF that an end all this.” he said attracting applause from the party supporters. 
The former UDF leader, who is also son to former president and party,s founder Bakili Muluzi, said he has hope that UDF, which ruled the country from the dawn of multiparty democracy in 1994 to 2005, could bounce back to power in 2025. 
“All we need is to join hands and make the party strong again. 
We need to reclaim our glory and serve Malawians from the current problems,” said Atupele. 
Taking her turn, the party’s interim president Lilian Patel said UDF is rebulding and remains a strong party. She said the party is poised to rise again and reclaim government. 
She said; “We need to join hands. Lets tighten our seet belts until we go to convention to elect leaders who can steer the country. In 1994 we were a force to reckon with that crounced Malawi Congress Party (MCP). So, in the same vein, let’s join hands to take back the government. “ 
Speaking earlier, the party’s nation organising secretary, Abubakar M’baka urged the party supporters to unite if they are to help the party to achieve it’s dream to take back the government. 
During the rally, the party recognised its veterans by giving them medals.

Timothy Mtambo, Chairperson of the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), calls for MEC Chairperson Jane Ansah and other commissioners to resign following the Constitutional Court's order for fresh elections. Mtambo insists that Ansah must apologize to Malawians for previously claiming that she managed the May 21, 2019 Tripartite Elections effectively. The HRDC condemns former MPs seeking to review the parliamentary elections, arguing that their actions are ill-timed and should have been pursued immediately after the elections.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Title: Atupele resignation shakes UDF
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) has called for an emergency national executive committee meeting (NEC) meeting this week to discuss the way forward following the resignation of its leader  Atupele Muluzi. UDF secretary general  Kandi Padambo said in an interview yesterday that Atupele’s resignation come as a shock to party members from top to the grassroots. His sentiments come a day some after some UDF members in the Northern Region wrote his office, expressing their disappointment over Atupele’s move. In the latter, the members from the North asked Atupele, son to the country’s former president and UDF founding leader Bakili Muluzi, to reverse his decision, saying he is a “ capable leader” who can lead the party to form the next government. Padambo said his office is expecting more letters from other regions as Atupele’s resignation come as a surprise as he did not consult MEC.  He said; “Many members from all the regions have expressed disappointment and would like the president to reverse that decision. “So, we have to meet as a party and formulate a collective response to the president’s decision.” On whether Atupele’s resignation will affect the party’s alliance with the Democratic progressive party, Padambo said their alliance was only for the June 23 2020 court – sanctioned Fresh Presidential Elections and that each party is now working on its own. In a letter dated May 29 2022 addressed to Padambo, the Northern Region members said they understand that UDF is a party, but at the same time Atupele is the brand that the party has groomed over the years. Reads the letter in part; “In view of the foregoing, members, through you our Secretary General, would like to sincerely appeal and request the honourable president to consider rescinding his decision.” But in separate interviews yesterday, UDF leadership in the Southern, Central and Eastern regions said they will respect Atupele’s decision. UDF regional governor for the East Alhaj Abdul Nkata said no one can challenge Atupele’s decision because nobody forced him to join politics. He said; “He [Atupele] hasn’t argued with anyone, but he has just decided to quit active politics and concentrate on other personal issues. So, as the Easten Region, we welcome his decision because he joined politics himself and has also resigned himself.” While welcoming Atupele’s resignation. UDF acting regional governor for the South Charles Chikuwo said the party was an institution, as such a leader’s departure would not mean the end of it. On his part, UDF vice – president (centra) Michael Antoine also accepted Atupele’s decision. He said Atupele had always wanted to serve Malawians, but being a president in the opposition was frustrating his attempts to contribute to the betterment of Malawians. But writing on his Facebook page yesterday, Atupele said he had left politics to transition into a Pan – African business executive. He said with global business partners, he intended to immediately lead in a mini – industrial and economic revolution for the progress and development of Malawi. Commenting on the matter, political analyst Ernest Thindwa said he was not suprised that some UDF supporters were disappointed by Atupele’s decision. He said that for so long, the party has ridden on the Muluzi brand and the resignation marks the end of the UDF/Muluzi marriage. Said Thindwa; “Perhaps this is an opportunity to rebuild the party. The party should not be dependent on an individual and personalised. It’s high time the party moved without the Muluzi brand.” On his part, political commentator Humphrey Mvula expressed suprise at the way Atupele handled his resignation, saying he was supposed to make his announcement at the NEC meeting. However, he said the resignation will give an opportunity to transform UDF from being a regional party to a national party. Said Mvula; “It is a defining moment for the party to retrace its roots. It’s a positive development as the party will not be associated with a family (muluzi). At least for the first time the next leader will not be a Muluzi.” Atupele took over the party’sleadership in 2012 at theexpertisee of Friday Jumbe, George Nga Mtafu (now deceased) and Moses Dossi during the party’s convention succeeding his father former president Bakili Muluzi who was the party’s chairperson. According to UDF spokesperson Yusuf Mwawa, the former president now the party patron as there is no chairmanship role in the UDF constitution. Atupele become a second high ranking UDF official to quit after first vice – president Lance Mbwewe . UDF performance in elections has been dwindling since 1999 general elections when it amassed 91 parliamentary seats after it got 85 in the 1994 elections. In 2004, the party had 49 legislators 16 in 2009 and 14 in 2014. As of now, UDF has 10 parliamentarians.

One of the country’s nongovernmental organizations, Centre for Democracy and Economic Development Initiatives (Cidedi), has hailed the country’s judges hearing the #PresidentialElectionsCase for reporting attempts by some unscrupulous individuals to bribe them to the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB). This follows revelations on Monday that the Chief Justice reported the attempted bribery to ACB. Cidedi Acting Executive Director, Sylvester Namiwa, has since urged the ACB to arrest the culprits.
