Title: Usi dares councils to be creative on funding
Content:
Vice- President Michael Usi has urged local councils in the country to put extra effort to mobilise resources for their respective projects to supplement allocations from central government. 
Speaking at Chikwawa District Hospital on Wesdnesday, he noted that some government ministries, departments and agencies (MDA’s) solely rely on government funding. 
Usi's sentiment follows concern by some district councils that low levels of government funding are one of the major challenges affecting service delivery. 
He said; “Let us not get used to problems. It is us who change . Write a proposal and identify a donor who can help us because the government cannot do everything on its own. So many people are just sitting blaming  government. Let's blame our thinking.” 
In May this year. Ministry of Local Government, National Unity and Culture indicated that the K3.2 billion councils were due to receive  in the last financial year remains estimates, not arrears as it was due to resource constraints. 
Secretary for Local Government Richard Hara said this in the awake of councils’ concerns that 20 councils were still owed about K3.2 billion for the 2023/24 fiscal year despite several queries to the Treasury. 
He said authorities were aware of the problem and will be addressing the issue as time goes, insisting that councils should know that the government budget is only an estimate. 
During his visit to Bangwe, Chilomoni, Nthukwa and Chirimba markets in Blantyre yesterday, Usi said his office is working with the Ministry of Local Government, unity and Culture to find a lasting solution for resource constraints most councils are facing.  
He also said government has removed collateral as a required for small- scale businesspeople to access National Economic Empowerment Funds (Neef) loans to enable them to get the loan. 
Usi further emphasis that Neef loans will benefit every small- scale businesspeople regardless of their political affiliation. 
He said; “From July [This month] to August you will get Neef loans without collateral. 
These loans applicants shouldn’t be politicians because Malawi Congress Party, DPP [Democratic progress part], UTM and UDF [United Democratic Front] supporters are Malawians even those without political parties should also benefit, but there is need for discipline,” 
In an interview after the Vice President’s tour, one of the vendors at Chilomoni Market. Kondwani Kaonga, expressed excitement with government’s decision to remove collateral as a requirement to access loans. 
He said collateral has been a major challenge for most small- scale businesspeople to access Neef loans. 
Usi is touring public institutions in the Southern Region and today he is scheduled to visit Mulanje District.    Usi dares councils to be creative on funding

Title: I’m not in a hurry, says Chakwera
Content:
President Lazarus Chakwera says he is not in a hurry to make public appointments or changes, saying everything needs to be done in an orderly manner and in accordance with the dictates of the law.
In an interview on Tiuzeni Zoona talk show on privately-owned Zodiak Broadcasting station (ZBS) radio, the president also said he was taking into consideration feedback from people; hence, the delays in making some appointments.
Said Chakwera: ‘’If it is about delays in removing and replacing a specific individual, then that is not right in a number of ways. One of it [the reasons] is that we should not appoint someone in contrast to what the law says.
‘’when we are fixing thins or when we are changing positions, there should be tolerance and respect for incumbent position holders so that proper handover are made even when there are issues.’’
The president, who was head of the Malawi Assemblies of God Church before joining front-line politics in2023, said there was need to abolish a culture where a change of regime means disregarding necessary procedures, including handover.
He said he believes that regardless of situations, there should be a proper way of doing things and procedures to be followed.
Chakwera who teamed up with UTM party president and the country’s then estranged Vice-President Saulos Chilima as his running mate in the June 23 fresh presidential elections, said it would not be proper to talk about his intention to stand again in the next election.
He said the focus now should be on how the country would be rebuilt, saying the issue of his candidacy in the next election would be tackled ‘’when we get to that bridge’’.
Chilima is on record as having hinted that the presidency or presidential ticket of Tonse Alliance would be rotational among partner parties.
During yesterday’s interview, Chakwera also started that his relationship with Chilima as his Vice-President will not at any point be complicated, emphasising that their main agenda is to rebuild the country.
Since 1994 when the country adopted a new constitution that created the Office of the Vice-President, the relationship between the president and Veep has often been strained, with the Vice-President been sidelined in the course of the tenure of office.
Reacting to Chakwera’s interview, governance commentator Makhumbo Munthali yesterday said the need to follow procedures and the law was the way to go.
But he said the Tonse Alliance administration should not be too slow to act as time is not on their side because Malawians are eagerly waiting for them to begin fulfilling their manifestos; hence, there is need for human resource to implement the pledges.
On whether Chakwera will represent the nine-party alliance again in the next election, he said that was some thing parties in the alliance may have already agreed upon before signing their agreement.
During the interview, Chakwera also defended his appointments of retired individuals back into the public service, saying they have been recalled to perform specific functions and would not be there for long as stipulated in their respective contracts.
He also backed the arrest of several officials under the ousted Democratic Progressive Party, saying the law is taking its course and not necessarily being selective.
While stressing his commitment to trim presidential powers, Chakwera said Tonse alliance will work strongly to rebuild the country as everyone in the alliance has a role to play.
Author: LLOYD CHITSULO

Content:
Chimwendo advises political stakeholders to avoid inflammatory rhetoric; police calls for peace, tolerance
Richard Chimwendo Banda has urged political parties and other stakeholders in the political arena to aim at fostering an enabling environment for peaceful assembly and coexistence which are charted pillars for democracy and stop inflammatory language that may torpedo peace and tranquillity that Malawians are enjoying today.
He was speaking at a press briefing that he conducted at the party's headquarters in Lilongwe where he reacted to alleged remarks that were uttered by DPP's Regional Governor for the Eastern region, Daud Chikwanje.
Franked by several MCP high ranking party members, Chimwendo said political violence is poses a threat to social cohesion and economic development therefore it is imperative that political leaders must refrain from provoking youths to indulge in brutality and victimisation.
He has therefore, condemned Chikwanje remarks describing them as retrogressive and ant- democratic.
Meanwhile, Malawi Police has urged politicians to avoid inciting violence ahead of elections.
Reyneck Matemba: "This is our chance to demonstrate to the people of Malawi that they can trust us; we can deliver...if we miss this opportunity, we might never get another chance."

Title: Chakwera, Chilima meet at Umhangano
Content: Some of the major political players in the country yesterday put aside politics and spoke and acted differently. The occasion was none other than Umhlangano, the Ngoni Maseko annual cultural festival which takes place at Nkolimbo, the  loyal ground of Inkosi Gamoni V Ntcheu. Among notable figures ot the ceremony were Malawi Congress Party (MCP) preside Lazuras Chokwera and Vice President Saulos Chilima, who is leading United Transformation Movement (UTM) while the only senior figure from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Minister of Civic Education Grace Chiumia, who represented President Peter Mutharika on the function. Title: Atupele faults long – term development
Content:
Former United Development Front (UDF) president Atupele Muluzi has said Malawi has all it takes to become an upper middle-income economy within 10 years, but what is lacking is good leadership. 
Speaking yesterday at Masintha Ground in Lilongwe where the party was celebrating its 30 years unnivesary, he said 2063 is too far from a projection for the country, which is rich in resources such as gas, oil,water and precious stones that can spur development. 
Said Muluzi; “With good leadership, the country can develop in a very short period. The big problem we have is corruption. Leaders do not think about the nation. They think of how much they will steal with corruption we cannot make progress.” 
He stressed that UDF holds the key to developing this country, “within 10 years, can reach level of Dubai, Kuwait and Qatar. We need to join hands to develop this country, Malawi is a very rich,” said Muluzi. 
On her part, UDF President Lilian Patel said the goal of UDF is to get back into government by 2025 and develop the country. 
She called for unity within the party if it is to make it in 2025. 
Through the MW2063 Agenda, Malawi envisions to become a self – reliant nation by 2063. 
The national development blueprint is promoting agriculture commercialization, industrialization and information communication technology among other concepts as pillars of development.” Atupele faults long – term development

Title: EU, Worlds Bank dismiss Atupele
Content: The European Union (EU) and the World Bank yesterday distanced development partners fromremarks by United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi purporting that donors will only resume budget support if there will be regime change in the May 20 Tripartite Elections. Atupele, the youngest of the 12 presidential candidates, told a rally in Mzuzu on Sunday that alongside his running mate Godfrey Chaponda they met representatives of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank and other development partners last Friday. He claimed the development partners told opposition leaders they would only support the budget if there is change of government. Said Atupele; “On Friday, Dr Godfrey Chaponda and l met with World Bank, International Monetary Fund [IMF] and Malawi’s donor partners who told us openly that if we don’t change government this year, then will reserve to zero – deficit budget. “Today, the Government of Malawi has already started to put in place zero- deficit budget and you all know what this means, the problem we encountered will come back to haunt us if we continue with this government. They [donors] have told us openly that because of Cashgate, issues of theft and economic mismanagement, they will not inject any money if things don’t change.” But in a written response to a questionnaire from The Nation to authenticate Atupele’s claims, EU head of delegation Alexander Baum said whereas he did not personally listen to Atupele’s address, disbursement of budget support is based on macro – economic stability as assessed by the IMF and the public finance management – related assessments of fiduciary risks. Said Baum; “[The Malawi] government has implemented a number of action, but many actions necessary to fix the public finances are still work in progress. Each partner assesses its fiduciary risks and takes decision on this basis. “There are no political criteria linked to budget support in Malawi other than what we call the ‘fundamental principles ‘, i.e. human rights, democracy etc. There is consequently not a link to a specific government that any colleague from the international partners would have said something different. I hope this clarifies it.” In an earlier interview, Zeria Banda, who is responsible for communications at the World Bank African Regional Office, said when the World Bank met with members, nothing was said regarding elections. She said; “We met with leaders of various political parties, including PP [ People’s Party], MCP [ Malawi Congress Party] and UDF to share our perspectives on the state of the economy and how to sustain reforms for more meaningful economic development. We also discussed agricultural reforms. We did not touch elections or results thereof.” Malawi's national budget is financed 40 percent by donors on the recurrent expenditures and 80 percent on development expenditure. Last November, the country’s major donors under the common Approach to Budget Support (Cabs), to which Baum is to co- chairperson, announced the withholding of $150 million in budget support in protest over plunder of public resources at Capital Hill widely known as Cashgate. Last week, an IMF mission from Washington led by Tsidi Tsikata said the IMF will wait for the election before it releases a $20 million (about K8.4 billion) disbursement into the government purse as part of the Extended Credit Facility programme. Tsikata also said the mission had proposed to return to Lilongwe in June to confirm the recommendation agreed before submitting a report to the IMF management and Executive Board.

Title: Malawi, others at risk of widening digital divide
Content:
The United Nations says Malawi and other leastdeveloped countries (LDC) are at risk of falling further behind on the use and uptake of digital services as the share of information and communications technology (ICT) imports continues to drop across all regions.
Figures from the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad) show that for some time, ICT imports for LCDs and Africa were at 3.5 percent for LCDs and 5.3 percent for Africa.
Unctad says the increases in other regions were larger and the extent to which LCDs and Africa trail other regions in the world is huge.
ICT imports in Asia stood at 28 percent, 16 percent for developed regions and 13 percent for Latin America and the Caribbean.
In a statement, Unctad director of technology and logistics Shamika Sirimanne said the Covid-19 pandemic has made affordable ICT goods imports even more important for countries at early stages of the digital transformation.
These are the same countries that saw the biggest falls in ICT goods imports in 2020.
She said: "In this context, adopting trade facilitation and customs automation measures to smooth import processes will be important to improve access to the equipment needed in the digital economy."
Globally, imports of ICT goods grew by 1.1 percent, rising $27 billion to almost $2.5 trillion.
The report further said that the pandemic-related acceleration in digitalisation risks further exacerbating digital divides, with LDCs being left further behind.
"It is now more urgent than ever to ensure that those trailing in digital readiness can catch-up," said Unctad in its technical note on the pandemic's impact on trade in the digital economy.
Unctad figures show that in 2020, computers and peripheral equipment overtook communication equipment as the second largest component of ICT imports, after electronic components, for the first time since 2013, increasing by three percent while imports of communication and consumer electronic equipment fell by around 10 percent.
In an interview on Tuesday, ICT Association of Malawi president Bram Fudzulani observed that the demand for ICT services in the country is suppressed by high cost of ICT equipment.
He said: "We need to revise taxes and fees levied on smartphone devices and Internet for an ordinary Malawian to afford.
"The numbers accessing
ICT are worrying when looking at the largest population with access to Internet and smartphones."
Through the Malawi Digital Economy Strategy, the Malawi Government targets to increase network access for Internet usage to 80 percent of the population from the current 13.8 percent and increasing device ownership from 51 percent to 80 percent by 2026.
The strategy, which notes that affordability is the largest barrier to uptake of mobile services in Malawi with device costs contributing. significantly to this, says to address the barriers, it will phase out the 10 percent excise on data and text package purchases and phase out Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority's 3.5 percent tax on ICT provider turnover.
Author: Grace Phiri

Title: Usi warns errant civil servants
Content:
Vice – President Michael Usi has warned civil servants  against reporting rate for duties, saying the government will not hesitate to dismiss such employees.  
Speaking in an interview after making a surprise visit at Chikwawa District Council offices and Chikwawa District Hospital yesterday, he said most civil servants report late for duties as they wish, defying the official Malawi Government working hours from 7.30am to 4.30pm. 
Usi said some civil servants’ tendency of reporting for duties late is one of the factors hindering the country’s development. 
He said; “So, this time around, we will go after them [civil servants] and make sure that those that deserve to be booted out; they have been booted out. We need to serve Malawians better.” 
During his visit, Usi expressed satisfaction that Chikwawa district commissioner Nardin Kamba and director of health and social services Grace Momba were executing their duties as they were in office by 7.30am. 
In his remarks Kamba decried low funding, saying it was compromising public service delivery in the district. 
He said; “But as a district, we are trying our best to maximise our local revenue generation. We are working with other partners to fill in the gaps that we have in delivery of public service. 
“One of the examples is we wrote a proposal to EU [ European Union] and they are about to grant us 1 million euro [ about K1,2 billion] to use for environmental management,” 
At Chikwawa District Hospital the Vice – President bumped into a nurse who reported for work at 8am. 
He quizzed her why she was late, and she said she had had a problem with her child. 
Commenting on the Vice – President's move, Malawi University of Business and Applied Sciences development scholar Andrew Kaponya and Catholic University of Malawi development studies senior lecturer Justine Mangulama separately said the surprise visit was aligned with Malawi 2063, the country's long – term development strategy which calls for mindset change in pursuit of the aspiration to transform the economy  middle income status. 
But Kaponya said while presence and punctuality is important, the government should ensure that its staff are given necessary resources to execute their tasks. 
Mangulama, on the other hand, urged Usi and senior government ministries, departments and agencies to appreciate the actual situation on the ground. 
He said; “If civil servants know that they can be visited anytime, they will be vigilant, and we can improve the service delivery. 
“But this should also be accompanied by better working conditions. 
This can help to boost the morale of the civil servants.” 
President Lazarus Chakwera, the late Saulos Chilima and former president Bakili Muluzi previously conducted similar surprise visits to state agencies.

Title: Man arrested for insulting minister Kamtukule
Content: Police in Lilongwe have arrested businessperson Dauka Manondo, 51, on allegations that he insulted Minister of Labour Vera Kamtukule. In a statement released yesterday, Lilongwe Police public relations officer, Hastings Chigalu, said Manondo is alleged to have insulted the minister through a social media post on April 24 2022 when President Lazarus Chakwera was coming from Mozambique. "Kamtukule was among the dignitaries who were at the airport welcoming the Head of State. The suspect, Manondo, posted a picture of the said minister taken at the airport, on a WhatsApp platform and captioned it with insulting words." Chigalu said upon seeing the post, some members of the group lodged a complaint with the police. Manondo has since been charged with Cyber Harassment, a case which contravenes Section 86 of Cyber Crimes Act. He will appear in court soon.

Title: Atupele says not an opportunist
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) Atupele Muluzi says his acceptance of a Cabinet position as Minister of Natural Resources,Energy and Mining does not make him an opportunist. Atupele, who has been roped in President Peter Muthalika’s first Cabinet, said in an interview in Lilongwe he is in Cabinet to serve and deliver the transformation agenda to Malawians. On whether he is an opportunist by accepting the post, Atupele, who finished fourth in the presidential Elections, said; “How is this making me an opportunist? You can serve in Cabinet and serve Malawians, just the same way as you can serve any position. “There are some synergies between Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) manifesto and UDF manifesto and we saw this even during the debates, where it was all about exchanging ideas to the cause. “It’s about Malawi, and whatever capacities and positions we serve it’s really about Malawians at heart and this is a necessity to the need for unity of purpose and making sure it’s about Malawi and putting Malawi forward.” Atupele said his Cabinet appointment will not disorient UDF and that he is in consultation with his members. “I think what is important is that this [decision] is about making sure that we deliver our transformation agenda for Malawians and, of course, the consultation process are still underway and will be able to communicate what that process will be,” he said. This is the second time Atupele has accepted a Cabinet posting from a governing party. In 2012, Atipele and several UDF members of Parliament (MPs) were in the first Cabinet hired by former president Joyce Banda of People’s Party (PP). On Monday, UDF sources indicated that after his appointment, Atupele summoned his party’s senior members to a meeting in Lilongwe where he pleaded with them not to disintegrate. Atupele reportedly told his party members that he knew some were against his appointment and his decision could create problems, but he said he needed their support. The sources claimed that there was a minor feud within UDF’s rank and file following Atupele’s appointment to Cabinet. But UDF spokesperson Ken Ndanga yesterday said it is impossible with human nature to make a decision that satisfies every person despite its motives. Said Ndanga; “Our president has not gone in government to serve the interest of any political party, but to serve Malawians regardless of their affiliation, religion, tribe or status in society. He is above partisan politics.” UDF won 14 parliamentary seats in the May 20 Tripartite Elections.

Title: Chakwera's revolting Job
Content:
He was second best to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate, President Peter Mutharika, in the May 20 2014 Tripartite Elections. This sealed his place as Leader of Opposition in Parliament.
Malawi Congress Party (MCP) president Lazarus Chakwera faces a daunting task to fill the boots left by John Tembo whom many revere as an enlightened and unyielding politician.
Chakwera's job was cut out for him.
According to Parliamentary Standing Orders, the job description of the Leader of Opposition includes "presenting alternative policies to those of the government". Still feeling that he was robbed of victory three years after the cut-throat polls, Chakwera has to keep Mutharika's administration in check.
Oftentimes, the ruling party and chiefs that defends its infamous policies still accuse the MCP leader of just criticising government and failing to offer solutions.
"He has never given solutions to problems Malawians are facing. As Leader of Opposition, he was supposed to be giving solutions and not just criticising government," says Minister of Information and Communication Technology Nicholas Dausi who speaks for government.
Outspoken writer and social media activist Stanley Onjezani Kenani disputes this reasoning "one propaganda line" the ruling party has successfully sold Malawians.
He writes: "Does this mean we elected robots incapable of formulating solutions? If you tell me my weakness-say for example, you drink too much, in the end, you might lose your job,'-do I need anyone to tell me that the solution is to stop drinking?" he writes on his Facebook page.
"In his most recent speech, for instance, Chakwera pointed out to the President: Sir, this is what you put in your manifesto but you are not doing what you promised Malawians you would do."
Lazarus Chakwera, his wife Monica, and MCP Vice President Sidik Mia attended a rally in Msundwe.
Author: Sharon Chirwa

Title: UDF promises Chakufwa Chihana mausoleum
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) presidential candidate Atupele Muluzi has promised to build a mausoleum for one of Malawi’s freedom fighters Chakufwa Tom Chihana  he wins the May 21 2019 Tripartite Elections. Speaking at the rally in Mzuzu on Sunday, he said it was said it was sad that the place the Malawi hero is resting in bush. He said his administration would by all means remember to respect Chihana for being instrumental in securing the democracy the country is enjoying today. “We cannot forget our heroes who fought for the country to attain the democracy we are enjoying today. “I will construct a mausoleum for the departed hero within the first year of my leadership,” he said.  Commenting on Muluzi’s pledge, University of Livingstonia political scientist George Phiri said he is not surprised scientist George Phiri said he is not surprised to hear such promises, considering that it is campaign period. In July 2018, President Peter Mutharika also announced similar plans at Bolero Trading Centre in Rumphi during a groundbreaking ceremony for Rumphi – Nyika – Chitipa Road. Chihana, one of the people who fought for multiparty democracy under the banner of Alliance for Democracy (Aford), died on June 12, 2006.

Title: JB HAILED FOR TRANSFORMING GIRL CHILD EDUCATION
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has been honored for shaping the future of girls through her charity Joyce Banda Foundation schools. Speaking on Friday in Lilongwe when women of influence in society honored her. Lilongwe Wildlife Trust director of programmes Dorothy Tembo Nhiema said the former president's charity work has uplifted the lives of young girls to the country. She said she is who she is today because she was given a scholarship to study at Joyce Tanda Foundation School. Said Tembo: "We are what we are today because of her support, just like many of us today, I came from a poor family. I became an orphan at a very young age "But Joyce Banda took care of my education at her school and adopted me. She supported me through my secondary education from 1998 and through tertiary education until I became independent and got married." Other beneficiaries of the bursaries include Francis Nkhoma, Lyphert Cement, Bernadette Chimungu. Emmanuel Ndiche, Gift Longwe and Hezel Chimangeni and many more. In her speech Banda who was accompanied by her husband retired Chied Justice of Malawi and Eswatini Richard Banda said a community or country can only develop if its people, especially the girl child, are educated. The former president said. "It is the responsibility of the community to educate a child, not necessarily the parents alone. When you have something, share and help those in need). "When I established the school, we discovered that some students though bright but could not afford the fees. So I offered free bursaries to them to help realise their dream. Banda said she established the school after receiving $50 000 in prize money for the Africa Leadership Award she won alongside former Mozambican president Joachim Cussano. The Joyce Banda Foundation is a primary and secondary school in Malawi founded in 1997 whose primary focus is education sustainable development.

Title: MEC updates Chakwera on assignment, future
Content:
Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson Chifundo Kachale yesterday led his team of commissioner to Kamuzu Palace in Lilongwe where they updated president Lazarus Chakwera on their assignments, including the court-ordered June 23 Fresh Presidential Election.
Briefing journalists after the meeting, Kachale-who alongside six commissioners were appointed on June 7 by Chakwera’s predecessor Peter Muntharika-said one of the biggest assignments highlighted in the report was the election that ushered in Chakwera. 
The fresh election following the nullification of the May 21 2019 presidential election by a five-judge panel of the High Court of Malawi sitting as the Constitutional court on February 3 this year.
Kachale, who was widely hailed for conducting an election within the shortest period, mentioned delayed disbursement of funding and a tight work schedule as some of the challenges encountered.
He said: ‘’During the meeting, we indicated all those challenges and also indicated that in spite of the challenges, we were able to deliver.’’
Kachale, a judge of the High Court of Malawi appointed to fill the gap after the resignation of them embattled MEC chairperson Jane Ansah, said it is the presidents prerogative to raise any issue he may find in the report.
He said the commission will now proceed to prepare and conduct by elections in five constituencies and undertake ward demarcations.
Vacancies in three of the five constituencies Mangochi North East and Phalombe North followed the court’s nullification of the May 21 2029 parliamentary elections following petitions claiming irregularities.
Kalonga central, on the other band, fell vacant following the death of its legislator cornelius Mwakwanda while Lilongwe North West become vacant after Chakwera resigned to contest for the presidency.
Commenting on the ward demarcation exercise. Kachale said the exercise will be conducted nation wide and will involve extensive consultations.
Besides Kachale, other MEC commissioner are Jean Mathanga and Linda Kunje retained from the previous commission, Arthur Nankhuru, Steven Duwa, Anthony Mukumbwa and Olivia Liwewe.
Author: JACOB NANKHONYA

Title: Chakwera delivers maiden Sadc Summit address
Content:
Moeketsi Majoro was also congratulated on his appointment as the new Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho.
But the summit did not make mention of the political crisis in Zimbabwe, only acknowledging a report from outgoing chairperson of the organ on politics, Defend and Security Cooperation, president Emmerson Mnangagwa, who was commanded ‘’for his outstanding leadership during his tenure.’’
While there are tensions and conflicts in some countries, including Zimbabwe, the summit, in its communique, only said: summit received an Assessment report on Emerging Security Threats in the Region, commended the secretariat for the detailed report, and directed the secretariat to prepare an action plan for its implementation, that will among others, prioritise measures to combat terrorism, violet attacks and cyber crime; and to address adverse effects of climate change.’’
The summit also urged member State to take proactice measures to mitigate external interference, the impact of fake news and the abuse of social media, especially in electoral processes.
In his acceptance speech, Nyusi said he will ensure that Sadc achieves economic development through creation of competitive hubs in the region.
He said: ‘’We are going to have competitive hubs in the Sadc region. We are also going to make sure that we avoid unnecessary competition [among ourselves] in the economy.’’
Nyusi has taken over from Tanzania president John Pombe Magufuli who said that during his term of office, the region registered positive strides despite the Covid-19 pandemic which has disrupted the world economy.
Responding to a question during a press briefing after the summit’s closing ceremony, Chakwera said the most important area on the abuse of social media and fake news lies in the hands of individuals.
He said if people can take an initiative to verify whatever they post or forward on social media, most of the challenges can be addressed.
Chakwera said: ‘’We can’t stay without social media, but we need to be vigilant and ensure that we verify facts about what we post on social media, that way we are going to reduce the abuse of social media.’’
In his address, Chakwera said the combination of strengths and shared values between Sadc member States represents a unique opportunity to achieve full integration within the next years.
He said: ‘’I also believed that it is a divine opportunity, for it is by the providence of God that we are bound to one another by history, culture and a shared journey of liberation.
‘’For us as Malawians, we feel this undeniable bond whenever we travel beyond our borders we travel beyond our borders which is why I have never accepted that Malawi is land-locked, but rather land-linked to our Sadc brothers on all sides and a can assure you that we would not have it any other way.
‘’From this perspective, I humbly request you, the in-coming chairman, my brother and neighbour, Your Excellency Filipe Nyusi, to give us all no rest during your tunure until we join hands in honouring the late Benjamin Mkapa by fully liberalising trade across the Sadc religion and unlock the economic possibilities that our peoples dream of.’’
The summit also approved the sadc Vision 2050 which is based on the foundation of peace, security and democratic governance, and premised on three interrelated pillars of industrial development and market integration; and social and human capital development.
The three pillars also recognise gender, youth, environment and climate change as well as disaster risk management as important cross-cutting components.
The summit also endorsed a five-years sustainable self financing plan for Sadc Electoral observation Missions covering the period 2021 to 2025.
The summit has since planned a face-to-face meet in Maputo, Mozambique in March 2021 depending on the Covid-19 pandemic situation.

Title: Atupele, Chapola not related- UDF
Content: United Democratic Front (UDF) has refuted allegations that the party’s president Atupele Muluzi and his running mate in the 20 May tripartite elections, Dr Godfrey Chapola, are related by blood. Muluzi become the first presidential candidate to unveil his running mate last saturday, but following the announcement, the social media has been awash with allegations that Chapola is a cousin to Muluzi’s mother, Annie Muluzi, who hails from Malingunde in Lilongwe. But UDF spokesperson Ken Ndanga told Weekend Nation in an interview that the allegations are baseless as the two are not blood – related. “What is being spread on social media that honourable Atupele Muluzi and Dr Godfrey Chapola are related by blood and that the letter is an uncle to the former is not true. This is not even close to the truth because even a distant relationship does not exist between them. “People are just scared with the success story of UDF because of the support we have that will enable us triumph in the coming elections. Many politicians are afraid of Muluzi and Chapola because it is a winning pair,” said Ndanga. Ndanga said if there is a relationship between Muluzi and Chapola, “it is that the two belong to the UDF family”. “Our president [Muluzi] chose Dr Chapola because he is a man of integrity and he shares same vision with Muluzi, so the two can complement well to develop this country and rescue citizens from problems they are facing,” said ndanga.

Title: I'm encouraged by Church, chief's Support-Chakwera
Content:
Malavi Congress Party (MCP) president Lazarus Chakwera Saturday led a fundraising for M zizq CCAP in Kasungu where hailed the support from the church and traditional leaders, saying it encourages him and proves that Malawians want change.
"I am really encouraged by the support from the church and traditional leaders evident that Malawians want change. I am ready to spearhead that diange. I am grateful for the support I am getting from the church and chiefs.chiefs.We are all for clean politics, clean Iradership not tainted by corruption," he said. 
The leader of opposition in Parliament said the economic situation in the country has also affected the church.
"When a country is fairing badly economically because of poor policies and corruption, the backlash is huge that even the church is affected. Let us work together to change things next year" he said.
During the event, which  was also attended by 20 MCP Iegislators, Chakwera donated 50 bags of cement and an undisclosed cash towards the construction of a fence.
In his remarks, the Reverend Bosco Katsala of Mziza CCAP thanked the MCP leader for accepting to lead the event.
"We wanted to raise 2.5 million for our project but it seems we have exceeded the target. We thank Chakwera for responding to our request. He has shown that he is a good leader," he said

Later in the day, Chakwera held a political rally at Mziza Headquarters in the area of Traditional Authority Njombwa where he told MCP supporters that once elected as a President, he will restore the dignity of chiefs in the country.

Title: PPPC, contractor tout Internet connectivity project
Content: Public Private Partnership Commission (PPPC) chief executive officer Patrick Kabambe has described the Digital Malawi Project as a game-changer for the country, saying it will enhance government's efficiency in service delivery. He said this in an interview on. Wednesday when he commented on the progress of the 574 million (K77 billion) World Bank-funded project. Said Kabambe: “The project will help in the country’s digital development. Government offices need good and reliable In tenet connectivity to effectively implement things such as the Integrated Financial Management Information System and procurement systems. ”. “Through this project, government has identified 500 sites nationwide. These are education, health, agriculture and other public facilities that will be connected to free Internet.” He said the project is on track and will be completed by December this year. Speaking in separate interview, one of the contractors bengal. Net Limited managing director Mohammad Zafar Abdullah said works to connect over 300 government facilities in the Northern and Southern through the project is progressing well. He said government has contracted Bengal. Net limited for 10 years to connect and maintain Internet in public offices in the Northern and Southern regions. Said Abdullah: “Through this project, government offices, hospitals, schools, the most important places, will be connected to the district council through fiber from there, they will be connected to capital hill main data Centre.” . “In Malawi, 90 percent of people live in rural areas where Internet access is only through mobile data.” He said the firm has completed 95 percent of sites in Blantyre and 80 percent in Mzuzu.
Author: McDonald Bamusi

Content: Bishop Mary Nkosi appears before the Public Appointments Committee (PAC) in an inquiry into the capacity and competence of the commissioners to manage the fresh elections. PAC is meeting the commissioners following a constitutional court directive after five judges found MEC incompetent in managing the May 21, 2019 elections. The committee plans to meet with the commissioners individually.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Content: Justice Ansah requests that her secretary assist her in organizing her documents, as she has brought a large volume of paperwork. PAC Chairperson Collins Kajawa grants her request, noting that breaks will be allowed due to the anticipated length of the inquiry.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Content: Khumbo Soko, lawyer for Saulos Chilima, maintains his objection, despite MEC filing another sworn statement by a different lawyer. He contends that MEC did not adhere to the proper sequence of filing documents and urges the court to reject the stay application, stating that AG Kaphale had been ruled against representing MEC in this case, leaving him without grounds to file a stay.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Content:
Muchanakwaye Mpuluka, Board Chairperson of Mulhakho wa Alhomwe, has issued a stern warning to the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) against the ongoing persecution of Lhomwes in the country.
Speaking at the Mulhakho Wa Alhomwe annual festival in Chonde, Mulanje, Mpuluka accused MCP of seeking to eradicate Mulhako wa Alhomwe, citing the government’s decision to distribute maize in Lhomwe areas today, coinciding with the festival’s climax.
“This is a direct attack on our festival, and we will revenge next year,” Mpuluka declared.
Mpuluka highlighted the long-standing suffering of Lhomwes under MCP rule, including dismissals and arrests solely based on their ethnicity.
“We will not tolerate this mistreatment anymore,” he emphasized.
The festival, attended by hundreds, including Mulhakho wa Alhomwe patron Professor Peter Mutharika, serves as a rallying cry against MCP’s alleged persecution.
Notably, MCP was excluded from participating in the festival, further straining relations between the party and Mulhakho wa Alhomwe.
The tensions underscore the complex ethnic dynamics in Malawi, with Lhomwes seeking greater recognition and protection.

Title: Malawi improves on Internet connectivity
Content: Malawi has recorded a 10 percent performance improvement towards adoption of mobile Internet, according to a periodic review by a London-based Groupe Speciale Mobile Association (GSMA). GSMA has published the mobile connectivity index, which analyses the performance of 170 countries against key enablers of mobile Internet adoption.’ Under this, Malawi has registered the 10 percent performance improvement following the review which looks at key enablersthat include information and communications technology (ICT) infrastructure, affordability, consumer readiness and content and services. Commenting on the ranking, Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority director general Daud Suleman said in an interview on Wednesday that he was not surprised with the country’s improvement towards adoption of mobile Internet. He said authorities have worked hard to make the cost of data one of the cheapest in the region. “We are moving towards a digital economy and one of the key enablers of a vibrant digital ecosystem is Internet access and affordability, with such strides Malawi is moving towards the right direction,”said Suleman. He said the improvement comes at a time Macra is implementing various initiatives such as Community Internet Broadband Service branded Yathu Yathu Data to ensure an increase in accessibility and update of ICT services for all. GSMA is the global organization unifying the mobile ecosystem to discover, develope and deliver innovation foundational to positive business environments and societal change.
Author: Frank Namangale

Title: JB PLEASED WITH HER FARMING INITIATIVE
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has expressed satisfaction with the outlook of maize crop cultivated under Community Development Initiative she established in 2021 in consultation with President Lazarus Chakwera.  Speaking on Monday when she toured farms in Traditional Authority (T/A) Mnyanja in Kasungu District, she said it was important to help Malawians to become food secure. Banda said the initiative seeks to address socio- economic challenges people in rural areas face. She said. "We provide She said. We and money to venture into farming to ensure they improve their crop production. "The initiative also seeks to transform rural communities through the construction of houses, schools, markets, provision of clean water and one stop centers. Banda urged her fellow politicians to help Malawians transform their lives. "We must ensure we go and seek support to help these poor people. We must not just think about votes and ourselves said. On his part, T/A Minyunjа thanked the former president for introducing the initiative area, saying his subjects had challenges in accessing farm inputs under the Affordable Inputs Programme (AIP). He asked the beneficiaries not to sell their maize but to keep it for food. One of the beneficiaries, group village bead Chinjolka also thanked Barda for the initiative. "The initiative will help vulnerable communities to get bumper harvests in a season when other farmers are not expected to get better yields due to lack of farm inputs," he said At least 1050 households received free fertilizer and maize seeds and cultivated about 10 000 hectares of mate, beans and soyabeans includes a monthly 25 000 allowance.

Title: APM CHEERS THE CYCLONE SURVIVORS IN MANGOCHI
Content: Former president Peter Mutharika has encouraged Tropic Cyclone Freddy survivors not to lose hope but believe in God that their situation will get better. He expressed the sentiments on Saturday when he visited survivors at Samama and Mponda evacuation camps in Mangochi District.During the visit, Mutharika donated bags of maize flour, beans and money to the survivors. The Democratic Progress Party (DPP) leader bemoaned the plight of the survivors. "I am not here for politics, but I have come to tell you that I am deeply concerned about your condition following the tragedy of Cyclone Fredly, Please, do not to despair, but have faith in God, said Mutharika, who now resides in mangochi. He asked the government to ensure that it reaches all people affected by the disaster. Mutharika took advantage of the event to request Tonse Alliance administration to resuscitate the Malata and Cement Subsidy Programme his government introduced to ensure that. people build resilient houses that can withstand disasters. He said: "I have observed that most of the structures that have been damaged are those that were constructed with cheap materials. It's now time to move away from cheap structures and construct resilient houses. "This is the reason we introduced the programme to address the disaster, but It was scrapped by Tonse Alliance administration." Mangochi Central legislator Victoria Kingstone (DPP) said her constituency was one of the most affected areas by the disaster.  "We have over 10 000 families in my area who were affected by the cyclone," she said. Group village head Matunda thanked Mutharika for visiting his subjects.
Author: Ayamba Kandodo

Content: Kachali further emphasizes, “The people of Malawi will never forget you people of Msundwe. I would like to inform you all that the battle has just started. It will end when Lazarus Chakwera wins the forthcoming presidential election.”
Author: MacDonald Thom

Title: Usi sworn – in
Content:
Majority of senior UTM Party officials stayed away from the swearing – in of the newly – appointed Vice President Michael Bizwick Usi at parliament in Lilongwe yesterday. 
The party’s secretary general Patricia Kaliati, publicity secretary Felix Njawala and other heavy weights such as Newton Kambala were conspicuously missing from the function. 
But senior party member Noel Masangwi who attended the event, was quoted as saying his colleagues did not turn up because they were busy with Vice – President Saulos Chilima’s post – burial tasks. 
Chilima, alongside eight others, died on June 10 in a military plane crash in Chikangawa Forest in Mzimba. He was buried on 17 at his home village in Nsipe, Ntcheu. 
When contacted yesterday on her absence as well as that of senior party officials, Kaliati told Weekend Nation to talk to party spokesperson Felix  Njawala who. When contacted by WhatsApp, only blue – ticked our inquiry. 
In his acceptance speech after taking the oath before Chief Justice Rizine Mzikamanda, Usi admitted that he faces a tough task filling the shoes of Chilima. 
He proclaimed that he would work hard to ensure that the Tonse Alliance administration delivers its agenda. 
“Even though SKC’s shoes are too big for me to fill, l will work hard to ensure that we deliver the agenda. And, l know that under your leadership, your excellency [Dr Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera], l will try and succeed,” he said amid applause 
Usi, 55, further said it was Chilima who first believed that he can become the Vice – President, tracing back to the 2019 Tripartite Election build – up when he chose him as his running – mate. 
The new veep also seemed to take a swipe at his potential distractors, asserting that “ Ine musandichenjeneke (loosely translated as don't mislead me), l want to deliver for my country,” 
Turning to UTM amid a seeming leadership stand – off following Chilima’s death, Usi, who is party’s vice – president, said he will build the party “ to uphold our shared values to keep alive the dream of Tsogolo Lathu Lowala (the party’s slogan which loosely translates to ‘Our Bright Future’) 
The new Vice – President entered Parliament donning a black suit complete with shirt and black necktie amid sporadic roars of boma ilo! 
“I solemnly swear that i will well and truly perform the function of the high of the Vice – President of the Republic of Malawi and that l will preserve and defend the Constitution ...” Usi, flanked by his wife Ella, vowed. 
Meanwhile, Mzuzu University based political analyst Chrispin Mphande has urged Usi to his own man.  
“He won’t be like Chilima. He needs to be himself. In fact, his success will depend on how the President will be delegating him since his office operates through delegation from the president,” he said. 
On his bid to build the UTM party, which has since congratulated him on his appointment, Mphande urged Usi not to work in isolation, warning that “it will not be a soft sailing task”.

Leader of the House Kondwani Nankhumwa has announced that during the course of today's parliamentary proceedings, standing orders will be waived to allow the house to discuss motions in consideration of the judgment made by the Constitutional Court. The Constitutional Court, among other things, gave Parliament a number of consequential orders, one of which was to amend the Constitution to accommodate the fresh elections.
Author: Faith Kadzanja

Content: Former Speaker of Parliament Louis Chimango and Kasungu legislator Kenny Kandodo arrived at the MCP headquarters, where Lazarus Chakwera is set to address supporters.
Author: Sharon Chirwa

Title: BOTOMANI, JOOMA THROW WEIGHT BEHIND APM
Content: Two democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Mark Botomani and Ralph Jooma have thrown their weight behind the party's leader Peter Mutharika. The two declared their stand on Saturday during a football and netball bonanza at Sekwee Primary School Ground in Zomba District. Speaking after the matches, Botomani, who is Zomba Chisi parliamentarian, urged DPP followers to support Mutharika. "The party is one and intact. There are no longer divisions in the party and our president still Professor Arthur Peter Mutharika," he said. Botomani said he was aware of DPP follower's challenges, but as an opposition party they are trying their best to ensure that there are checks and balances to press government to implement the promises made during the campaign. Jooma, who is Mangochi Monkey Bay Iegislator and was the guest of honour at the bonanza echoed Botoman's sentiments that the party has resolved its differences. The sentiments come three weeks after Matrika and former DPP vice-president (South) Kondwani Nankhumwa embraced during a rally in Mangochi, gesture political analysts said was a sign of reconciliation. Botomani and Jooma were in the Nankhumwa camp. DPP spokesperson Shadric Namalomba is on record as having said the DPP has never been divided, saying it was united under Mutharika's leadership.
Author: Johnathan pasungwi

Content:
Former Malawi President Bakili Muluzi made a surprise declaration of interest in competing for the United Democratic Front (UDF) presidency at the party’s elective convention, but quickly retreated, citing his age and the “sharp” young leaders.
Speaking at Comesa Hall in Blantyre on Wednesday, Muluzi said, “I called the secretary-general yesterday telling him that I want to compete as president for UDF at the convention… but I realize that this fresh blood will boot me out easily, I can’t compete with the young ones, they are sharp.”
MALAWI ELECTORAL COMMISSION, PUBLIC APPOINTMENTS COMMITTEE MEET

Title: Transform Malawi through technology-Minister
Content:
Deputy Minister of Education Monica Chang’anamuno has challenged ICT students in the country to leverage on the power of technological innovation to provide solutions that could help the country achieve Malawi 2063 goals.
She said this in Lilongwe on Friday at the graduation of 100 university students who completed a week-long training in information and. communications technology (ICT) under Huawei Technologies corporate social responsibility program called Seeds of the Future.
Chang'anamuno urged the students to expand on what they have learned to support government efforts in leveraging the power of ICT to improve their well-being, create new sources of wealth and accelerate economic diversification.
Said the deputy minister: "As detailed in the Malawi Digital Economy Strategy 2021-2026, we have identified three priority areas in which we believable ICT can  have the greatest impact. First, in agriculture, we want to use ICT to increase farmer earning by supporting productivity and commercialisation.
"Second, in health, we want 10 use ICT to improve health outcomes by ensuring that patients are correctly diagnosed and treated.
Third is in digital traded services, we want to enable Malawians to deliver services remotely and support both local and foreign business operation."
One of the students from Malawi University of Business and Applied Sciences, Freedom Msombera, said the training, which was under the theme Inspiring the Youth, Shaping The Future', has changed the way they think.
"Previously, we were looking at ICT as just a mere subject in college, but now we are thinking of it as a tool for providing solutions, accelerating development,entrepreneurship,  and job creation.
As we go out, we will try to use the knowledge to bring solutions," she said Huawei ICT trainer Ghassan Nassar said, among other things, the students were trained in Artificial Intelligence, 5G network, cloud computing, coding  and database and how these technologies can be used to bring solutions that can have a big impact on challenges the world is facing. Seeds of the Future is Huawei's flagship corporate social responsibility programme. It started in 2016.
Author: Kandani  Ngwira

Content: UTM party has announced it will not participate in the forthcoming parliamentary by-elections. The Malawi Congress Party, however, says it will participate under protest.
Author: Mathews Kasanda

Mkaka issues a message to the police, stating, “When Malawians are tired, they are not scared of guns.”
Author: Sharon Chirwa

Title: State ordered to do more on Mbele evidence
Content:
The Senior Resident Magistrate (SRM) Court in Lilongwe has ordered the State to provide gadgets used to extract posts by social media influencer Joshua Chisa Mbele who is accused of flouting bail conditions.
The State last week asked the court to revoke bail granted to Mbele in a case he is accused of posting on facebook page a list of people who benefited from United Kingdom-based business person Zuneth Sattar who allegedly is accused of corruption. Among the bail conditions was that Mbewe should not make such posts again. In application to have Maele’s bail revoked, the State argued that he has continued making such posts. The State further provided printed screenshots of the posts. But defense lawyer Gilbert Khonyongwa challenged the bail revocation request and made a counter application to dismiss the case, saying the document that the State presented was not primary evidence and therefore, can no be used in court. However, State prosecutor Levinson mangani told the court that the State was ready to demonstrate how the evidence was sourced and that the posts in question exist. In his ruling on the application, SRM Wanagwa Nyirenda said he could not find enough reason to dismiss the case the case as the State was ready to demonstrate how the evidence was obtained. However, he asked the state to make available gadgets that were used to extract the evidence contested by the defense. 
“The  State should make available the gadgets so that the defence can check them," said Nyirenda.
The magistrate adjourned the case to Friday when the court will hear the bail revocation application.
Mbele is currently on court bail. He is answering criminal libel and publication of offensive communication charges following his posts on Facebook.
Author: George Singini

Title: CDEDI WANTS SEPARATE AIR CRASH PROBE
Content: Centre for Democracy and Economic Development has called on President Lazarus Chakwera to institute in independent commission of inquiry into the place crash that claimed the lives of vice-president Saulos Chilima and eight others on June 10. Cdedi executive director Sylvester Namiwa said in a statement yesterday that the work of German experts, who are in the country to investigate causes of the tragic accident, needs to be complemented by an independent and inclusive commission of inquiry. Reads the statement: ‘The experts work will help Malawians get answers to their many unanswered questions towards healing their broken hearts only if the investigators have credible reports of the sequence of events that happened before, during and after the tragic accident, hence our call for the formation of an independent and inclusive commission of inquiry. During Chilima's funeral service at Bingu National Stadium in Lilongwe on June 16, 2024, his brother Ben Chilinga at called for a thorough investigation to understand what exactly happened.
Author: Macmillan Mhone

Content:
We are getting reports that the guy who is seen in MCP attire blandishing panga knife, threatening people,  is son to honourable Uladi Mussa from his second wife. And that the guy stays at Lifidzi.
This behaviour has to be condemned at all cost and it is our understanding that police will net this one as well as they did with DPP, Deputy Secretary General, honourable Daud Chikwanje. We can not go like this as a nation.
Over to you police!
An inquiry with Commissioner Elvey Mtafu ends abruptly when the committee expresses dissatisfaction with her responses.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Title: APM UNDER PRESSURE
Content:
Pressure is mounting for former president Peter Munthalika to state his position on whether he will run for office again amid endorsements from regional leaders of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). In written response yesterday, DPP Vice President (South) Kondwani Nankhumwa said much as he would not comment on the matter, Mutharika, 81, needs to come out and clearly state his position. He said; “First, ask APM to come out clear on the matter and express himself That is the only time some of us can comment,”  Convention remains ultimate decider - Msaka.In a separate written response, the party's vice-president (East) Bright Msaka said while there are numerous platforms for electing leadership, a convention remains the ultimate decider. “There are various mobilizations for leadership that take place within a political party. Ultimately, the convention decides, he said. But when contacted yesterday, Mutharika’s spokesperson Shadric Namalomba said the immediate past president is still consulting on the matter and he will state his position in due course.  His Excellency APM is taking note of the ongoing endorsements. He (Mutharika] Is currently consulting and at the right time Malawians will be informed, he said. When asked if the endorsement reflect the party’s position in general, Namalomba said Mutharika believes it is citizens' right and freedom to express themselves as enshrined in Malawi’s Constitution. He said the endorsements also tell a story about Mutharika's  Mutharika's capabilities, hence, those endorsing have trust in him to lead the party during the 2025 general election. In recent months, some DPP top officials have been convincing party followers to allow Mutharika to contest in 2025. DPP regional governor (North) Patrick Ackim Mwanza and his counterpart in the South, Charles Mchacha, told our sister paper Nation on Sunday of May 8, 2022, that they want Mutharika to contest in the forthcoming elections to end squabbles that have rocked the former governing party.  They called on those aspiring to contest for the party's presidency to challenge him as the convention. But our efforts to re-engage them yesterday proved futile as they could not be reached on numerous attempts.  On Friday last week a religious body, Public Affairs Committee (PAC) with Mutharika at Mangochi Private residence where his candidature was discussed.  PAC Executive Director Robert Phiri confirmed in an interview yesterday that they discussed Mutharika's candidature but asked for a more comprehensive response. When asked on Mutharika's response pertaining is the discussion on his candidature amid the endorsements.  Mutharika asked to come out clear 
 Namalomba referred the matter back to PAC. In an earlier interview, governance commentator Makhumbo Munthali said if the DPP's constitution will allow Mutharika to contest again, there should be a level playing field so that other aspirants can compete with him without being barred or persecuted.  He said the current attempts where some candidates are not allowed to campaign are a clear signal that the environment is not conducive. Cracks in the DPP came to light in August 2020 when secretary general Greselder Jeffrey told The Nation that there was need for new leadership. Mutharika lost the court-sanctioned June 23, 2020, presidential election to President Lazarus Chakwera. The former president took over the party's leadership after the death of his brother Bingu wa Mutharika in April 2012 propelling it to victory in the 2014 Tripartite Flections.
Author: Lloyd Chitsulo

Content: Lilongwe Senior Resident Magistrate Shyreen Chirwa has granted bail to activist and UTM politician Jessie Kabwila. The bail conditions are that Kabwila should pay a cash bond of K20,000, produce two reliable sureties with a non-cash bond of K200,000 each, and report to the central region police once every fortnight.
Author: Audrey Kapalamula

Author: Sharon Chirwa

Content:
Malawi Congress Party (MCP) has been told to keep its distance from the upcoming United Democratic Front (UDF) convention, following protests from UDF supporters.
Aisha Adams, Second Deputy Speaker of Parliament and UDF convention chairperson, revealed that the decision was made to avoid conflicts between the two parties.
“We have agreed that MCP should not come to our convention to avoid problems with our supporters,” Adams stated.

Road to September 2025
Straight from police cell, DPP Regional Governor for the Eastern region and Member of Parliament for Machinga Central East Hon Daud Chikwanje, met with DPP members in Jali, Zomba district. This meeting was part of his efforts to strengthen the party in the region.
In his remarks, Chikwanje assured the blue family that they would win the 2025 elections under the leadership of Prof. Arthur Peter Mutharika with a land slide. He emphasized the importance of loyalty and urged everyone to support Mutharika, the party's candidate.
Chikwanje also visited Mangochi boma and Malindi on October 4, where he interacted with local DPP structures.

Title: JB CALLS FOR INCREASED ACCESS TO ENERGY
Content: Former president Joyce Banda has called for urgent investment in renewable energy access to provide electricity to millions in sub-Saharan Africa. She said this yesterday when she joined other campaigners in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in making the call as the world enters the last five years of Sustainable Development Goals. Said Banda: "Around 630 million people in the region lack electricity and almost a billion still use solid biomass for cooking and heating, making sub-Saharan Africa the most energy-impoverished part of the world. The absence of modern energy services perpetuates poverty and limits economic opportunities. She further said she recently launched a campaign called Six30 which seeks to spur public and private donors to increase investments in the renewable energy sector across the continent.

Title: CHILIMA’S BIRTHDAY GOLF TARGETS 120 PLAYERS
Content:
Vice President Saulos Chilima’s 51 Birthday Golf Tournament scheduled for Lilongwe Golf Club (LGC) Sunday has attracted a field of 120 golfers. LGC captain Duncan Chidrankula said in an Interview yesterday registration of golfers is still 
He said: "We are expecting a field of 120 golfers, and they will play on individual Staford format. We are ready to host this tournament Preparations on the golf course are going on well to make this day more memorable for the Vice- President 
The Office of the Vice-President has since appreciated LGC for offering to host the birthday event 
"The Vice President is looking forward to the tournament He is thankful to Lilongwe Golf Club for hosting this tournament in honor of his birthday. He is turning 51," the Veep's spokesperson Pilirani Phiri said Chillma's caddie Chris Kachiguma said despite organizing the event, the Veep will compete to win 
He said. "We are geared to play well and win the tournament despite being his own event. Besides his limited time to practice on the golf course, his game is coming up nicely and we want to be on the podium for the prize" Chilima is an avid golfer and on multiple occasions has helped charity organizations raise funds through golf tournaments.

Title: Ministry of Labour advocates for improved technology skills
Content:
Ministry of Labour has embarked on a project dubbed Celestial City to advocate for improved technological skills among
Malawin youths.
Speaking after presenting the project proposal to Ministry of Labour, recently, Celestial City Malawi representative Penjani Kalua said he was happy that government has seen the importance of the proposal by accepting to partner them.
He said: "I feel we all have a part to play, we need to be counted and be a light in the dark.
"I am looking forward to the implementation of this project and to see youths benefiting."
In her remarks, Minister of Labour Vera Kamtukule said her ministry recognises the potential of  the creative sector in job creation and was hopeful that a lot of youths in the country would benefit from the project. She  said the proposal is  in line with the job creation strategy that is focusing on the impact of the youth in achieving the respective objectives. She said:”The youth are an integral part in the building of a nation. As long as they have the skills and they are well trained, you are assured of great things.”
“This proposal I feel will enable youths to be employed remotely thus providing Labouring compensation inflows in line with the government’s job creation strategy MIP1 and MW2063.”
Celestial City is a song offering platform headed by former Vodafone executive Nkechi Newton and industry veterans, including Netflix global creative marketing executive Tamara Johnson.
According to the proposal, the platform also plans on hosting concerts for major and independent artists globally, physically and on the metaverse.

Content: German Ambassador Ralph Timmermann on Monday met Vice-President Saulos Chilima at Capital Hill in Lilongwe to bid farewell after winding up his tenure in Malawi, according to communication from the Offices of the Vice-president. During the meeting, the two discussed areas their countries should further cooperate on to strengthen their relations in the picture, Chilima(L) and Timmermann exchange pleasentries.

Title: North UTM  members supports Usi
Content:
Members of UTM party in the northern region yesterday met party president and the country's vice-president Mchael Usi and assured him of their support. 
Clad in the party's red regalia, the group of about 80 comprising ward councilors, regional, district and women representatives as well as delegations and UTM Youth Achievers, took turns to met Usi. The meetings held at Mzuzu lasted for about four hours , but Usi refused to grant media interviews after the engagement. Officials from the office of the vice-president described the meeting as private. During his closed door meeting with the women representatives ,Usi was overhead speaking about his relationship with departed UTM party leaders Saulos Chilima. He said “ I am very close to the former Vice- president the late Chilima. And if there was anything , l would have been the first to know” UTM party councilor for Chiputula ward Hiweti Wiseman Mkandawire, who is also North-South region organizing secretary, said the agenda was about uniting the party and its future.  Mzimba Luwerezi Legister Sam Chirwa , who is the party's national deputy operations director , said there is no reason for division as the law is clear on succession matters .  “ I support him 100 percent. He has our full support ,” he said. Commenting on the development and state of affairs in UTM, renowned political analyst said the party was always going  struggle without its Chilima. On the other hand , political commentator Wonderful Nkhutche said Usi remains party president but his future as a leader is under threat with supporters actively looking for a new face and name to lead. Chilima alongside eight other died in a military plane clash in Viphya Highlands in Mzimba on June 10 2024.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Vice President Goodal Gondwe has stamped his authority in the North by among others executing changes at party's level as one way of bringing sanity in the party.
Gondwe has recommended the firing of Joyce Chikukula and Kelvin Chirambo for insubordination, sources say.
Chikulula was Regional Director of Women while Chirambo was Regional Director of Youth.
The Party has therefore appointed Constance Mwanyongo as new Regional Director for Women while Christopher Mtambo is new Regional Director for Youth.

Title: Chakwera makes new appointments
Content:
President Lazarus Chakwera yesterday made new appointments to State House and identified the appointees by district of origin, a strategy political analysts have faulted as not necessary.
State House director of communication and executive assistant to the president, Sean Kampondeni, in an interview defended the strategy of identifying which districts the appointees come from.
He said president Chakwera is leading a Tonse Alliance administration and when making appointments, he has to look across the nation.
‘’By disclosing which districts the appointees are coming from, it’s for transparency sake. People have to knoww where the appointees are coming from and if it’s inclusive in nature,’’ said Kampondeni.
But a political scientist at University of Malawi’s Chancellor Collage Mustafa Hussein dismissed Chakwera’s reasoning, arguing people have to be appointed on merit, should have the technical know how and be capable to deliver.
‘’Geographical spreading of positions should not be the first thing, actually what the president wants to do may have ethnicity undertones. While he may have good intentions, people would surely misinterpret this, it’s not necessary to refer appointees to their home of origin,’’ Hussein said.
Humphrey Mvula, another political analyst, said in an interview referring to appointees by districts they come from should not be encouraged.
‘’If people want to find out at some point where appointees are from, they can do that on their own. I understanding the intentions of the President, this is coming after he was widely criticised on how he appointed his Cabinet, but again this is not the way to do,’’ Mvula said.
The political analyst said the Tonse Alliance with Chakwera and his running mate Saulos Chilima, now the vice president, strongly campaigned on the Malawi one nation principle, fearing this new strategy of identifying where appointees come from may defeat this philosophy.
‘’they told Malawians they don’t believe in tribalism or regionalism, we should be getting rid of this, inherently, at an administration level, they should work on it to ensure appointments are not concentrated to two or three districts,’’ he said.
Mvula said the Tonse Alliance team promised during their campaign rallies that they would not be asking people where they come from when making appointments, but said it is clear that the appointing authority of the new appointments had to do a research about which districts the appointees are from, which he said is a bad a thing.
State House yesterday announced appointments of seven individuals to the various positions at the state house, disclosing that they come from Nkhotakota, Ntcheu, Zomba, Mzimba, Blantyre, Thyolo and Kasungu districts.
Chakwera appointed Overstone Kondowe as special adviser on people Living with Albinism and Disability and Reverend Brian Kamwendo as special adviser on religions affairs, with Sheikh Hashim Abbas as his deputy.
The president also appointed Major Precious Muhara Gausi as assistant aide-de camp, Brian Banda as press secretary, Martha Chikuni as head of media and marketing and Solomon Kavuta as director of ICT.
Author: FRANK NAMANGALE

So, as NPC, we thought it wise to recognise the work she has been doing the recognition is also made to motivate other Malawians in playing aboclute roles in championing the MW2063 Banda said she was overwhelmed by honouring for her endless passion and towards the realisstion of MW2063."

Title: Chakwera for intra party democracy
Content:
Newly elected Malawi congress party (MCP) president the Reverend Dr Lazarus Chakwera has urged the party to embrace democratic principle, observing that good governance withing a party is also reflected at national level.
In his acceptance speech to his new post at the close of the MCP convention in Lilongwe also said for Malawi to move forward and develop, political parties should embrace policy-based politics rather than politics only meant to deal with political enemies.
He said, ‘’if we practice good intra party politics, it means we will also have good politic at national level reflects the practices in the political parties. If things are will in a political party, even government can perform better.
Chakwera said Malawi as a county already has structures to develop, but what is need is a change of the mindset on how politicians behave.
‘’We need policy-based politics. When I announced that I have joined politics, people wondered how, as a church pastor who does not know politics, I wll do politics just because there is a misconception about politics. However, the politics I am talking about is policy based which is able to deal with issues,’’ he added.
Chakwera asked MCP members t start practicing clean policies and said it was time Malawil started respecting laid down policies as well as respecting its people instead of victimizing individuals based   on their political affiliation.
Outlining his vision for the party, Chakwera said 2014 is the year that MCP would get back into government, but said to achieve that, he needs support from God as well as from both the newly elected executive members and the outgoing national executive committee (NEC) members and the entire party membership.
He declared that with his election, the party has now started its joinery towards forming the next government.
He also said this was time that Malawian should start being independent.
He his handover speech, former party president John Tembo called on the entire party to rally their support behind the new president Chakwera became the party’s new president after bearing 10 other contestants during the elections held on Saturday.
Yesterday, MCP elected former Cabinet minister Richard Msowoya as first vice president with Macdonald Lombola as second vice president and Chris Daza retained his position as secretary general.
Former broadcaster and diplomat Tony Kandiero became the party’s treasurer general while Chitonda Kaunda was named deputy secretary general after a resolution was made for the Northern Region to Nominate someone to that position.
The Southern Region was giving preference to nominate an individual for the position of deputy treasurer general, but its leadership said would propose the name later.
