Title: Chakwera leads MCP
Content:
The moment MCP delegates yesterday bid for another term as party leader, it was clear that the groupings rank, and file wanted a new era.
And they got their wish, dramatically electing the 58-year-old politically in experienced former Assemblies of God President Reverend Dr Lazarus Chakwera, a cleric throughout his adult life, to lead the party and be its torch bearer in the May 2014 Tripartite Elections.
Chakwera amassed 287 votes out of the 652 cast. Former Chief Justice Lovemore Munlo came second with 169 votes whereas former secretary general Chris Daza cane second with 90 votes followed by former parliamentarian Lytton Dzombe with 24 votes, former Cabinet minister Jodder Kanjere with 21, former farmers union of Malawi (FUM) president Felix Jumbe with 19 and Nkhotakota Central legislator Edwin Banda got 14.
Lilongwe Mpenu Member of Parliament (MP) Watson Makala Ngozo garnered eight votes. Former secretary general Betson Majoni and MP Joseph Njobvuyalemea (Lilongwe Mapuyu south) had seven each whereas former directors of political affairs Eston Kakhome came last with sixth votes. Seven votes were null and void.
As the presiding officer form the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) announced the results in alphabetical order, supporters of Chakwera, who was called second, had to wait for Munlos name before they burst into Jubilation.
Thereafter it was uncontrollable singing and shouting in the hall as well wishers rushed in to congratulate Chakwera who did not immediately react or join in Jubilation, saying in a brief interview later that he was too shocked to react.
Chakwera could not immediately talk to the press, only saying he was overjoyed to say anything.
Soon after the results were announced and before the delegates could go into another round of voting for other positions, the president elect had to be excused from the hall amid heavy security escort.
As we went to press, voting was continuing for the other positions.
In his opening speech earlier before the election, long time MCP president John Tembo, whose candidature was against the party’s constitution that only allows a two-term tenure of office, said he was seeking re-election.
Author: Bright Sonani

Content:
On Tuesday, Minister of Finance Sosten Gwengwe has pronounced some adjustments to the 2023/2024 budget plan as measure to help cushion effects of Cyclone Freddy.
Speaking during his winding up statement on the budget motion before members goes jnto committee of supply, the Finance Minister pointed out that macro-economic assumptions used to prepare the budget have been shifted because of the devastation that happened mainly in southern region of the country.
Gwengwe told the house, “The GDP of 2.7% in 2023/24 may not be obtainable as we speak. But only prudent thing that we can do is to reduce the budget in tandem with expectations, otherwise then our projected debts will just skyrocket.”
“And that might create inflation and all sorts of evils that come along with such kind of policies. So, only bold thing we had to do is be realistic and see what is on us, what is on the ground and see how best we can respond,” elaborated Gwengwe.
He has also explained that government has reduced the budget by K80 to K100 billion pegging the budget at K3.7 trillion, rather than K3. 8 trillion pronounced earlier in February.

Title: VP USI ATTENDS KAGAME INAUGURATION
Content: Vice-President Michael Usi is today representing President Lazarus Chakwera at the inauguration of President-elect Paul Kagame in Kigali Rwanda. Chakwera delegated Usi, who departed yesterday through Kamuzu International Airport (KIA) Lilongwe, upon Kagome's Invitation. In a statement on Friday the Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that the Vice-President's trip to Rwanda also avails on opportunity for strengthening the cordial bilateral relations between the two countries. This is Usi's first official trip as Vice President after assuming the office in June this year. The Vice President is expected to arrive back in the country tomorrow.

Title: Maliwichi converted Usi to drama
Content:
A minute part of his role at the international NGO. 
They know him more as manganya in the radio and television soap, Tikuferanji. 
Manganya exploits are also evident on the small screen in films like ‘ Dr Manga.’ 
His side-splitting drama in several theatrical acts including an impersonation of Malawi’s first President Hastings Kamuzu Banda, surrounded by his mbumba and in an open Land Rover .  
During the Bingu wa Muthalika regime he also brought the hard hitting ‘Loto la Farao’ and when Peter Muthalika was president, he ignited fire at the Comes Hall in Blantyre with ‘ Ulalikiwu Ngwatonse.’ 
Before his appointment little was said about his education. Very few cared that the man behind Manganya held two masters’ degrees and, in fact, a Doctor of Philosophy. That is not including his professional genesis of medical assistant. 
Much as he walked through the corridors of universities of Bedfordshire and Derby in the United Kingdom, Andrews university in the United States of America and the Malamulo Medical College at home, Usi recalls that it was Mulange secondary School where his interest in drama was ignited.  
In a 2016 interview, Usi paid homage to one teacher at the school who introduced him to drama. 
He said; “It all started with with a Mrs. Malawichi, my English Literature teacher at the school who spotted and motivated me and made me what i am today. Although l need to be quiet, observant had always commenting on issues when they need arose, my teacher saw the acting potential in me.” 
Usi who hails from Golden Village in T/A Chikumbu’s area in the district, recalled that the teacher first featured him as Ikemefuna a character in Chinua Achebe’s Things Fall Apart . ............... first theatre group which was carrying out campaigns against non – communicable diseases, “ said Usi after Usi was sworn in as Veep, society sought out the teacher who directed him into acting. Eve Maliwichi (nee kunkwezu) a retired teacher and former Register of Malawi College of Health Sciences (MCHS) gave out a heavy laugh when when we introduced our subject. She agrred to have given Usi the difficult part during the Literature lesson when he was in form 3. 
 I found his character to be strong. He ws fluent in English. That was just what i needed to bring out Ikemefuna, the beloved child of Okonkwo as compared to Nwoye, a weakling. Dr Usi handled the character so well. I encourage him to join our club or something else,” says the mother of four.  
In 1983, when she joined Musescho, as the school is fondly called by students and the alumni, there was no drama club at the school, unlike her previous posting at Likuni Girls Secondary school. In fact, she was patron of the drama club when the school lifted the coveted Atern drama contest for secondary schools with a play titled ‘The Banana Tree’. But how did she feel that one of her students was now Vise – President of the Republic? Maliwichi laughed, again, and said; “I feel so blessed. As teachers, our students take up great positions. It is a lesson in my my life that even teacher must treat their learners perfectly well. You don’t even know what they will become later in life.” 
Citing Usi’s example Maliwichi feels drama increases one’s chances to progrss in other careers. That, she says, because theatre makes you more ‘industrious and idependent.’ 
She feels Manganya as a character, is strong and avoids laziness and weakness just like Usi. 
“As far as l see, the Manganya character earns respect from those around him in the acts because he doesn't pretend. The scripts flow naturally like water,” she observes. 
For her, drama is a vehicle for transitioning from harmful cultures and educating on social issues, apart from merely entertaining. 
“I encourage students, especially girls to do and join drama. It boosts their self-esteem, public speaking and presentation skills get better with drama. Even as a retired teacher, l always encourages girls to go to school. Sometimes l sees girls in the village being sent from school having failed to pay fees, l assist where l can,” she says. 
Maliwichi's life is an interesting and dramatic ‘plot.’ her past intertwines with the present in a not – so – familiar manner. 
Maliwichi studied for a Bachelor of Arts degree at the University of Malawi, chancellor College whwre she graduated in 1977 coincidentally, president Chakwera was one of her classmates. 
‘I was taking several units in English, and others in public administration and political science. The President was a classmate in one of the English units l was taking,” she beams. 
Having taught at several secondary schools across the country, an opportunity arose to study for a master’s degree in the United Kingdom and, thereafter , she briefly taught at lilongwe teachers College before being appointed principal of Blantyre Teachers College. 
Since the family and ger husband Harry, an educationist and medical physiologist, was a lecturer at Kamuzu College of Nursing and later Lilongwe University of Agriculture and Natural Resources resided in Lilongwe then, she decided to retire and join MCHS as college Registrar to be with the family.

Title: Mithi challenges interdiction over social media posts
Content:
Mzuzu-based social media influencer and civil servant Julius Mithihas challenged the Account General’s decision to suspend hi from duty over his social media posts deemed critical of government and is seeking court redress.
Mithi, who was interdicted last month for writing on social media platforms allegedly castigating government and other senior government officials, works as a senior accounts assistant at the Regional Irrigation and Water Development Office in the Northen Region.
In a letter dated November 25 2022, Accountant General Henry Mphasa accused Mithi of making “unfounded, impolite and discourteous castigations”.
Reads the letter in part: “I write to inform you that these allegations constitute a serious act of misconduct in terms of the Malawi Public Service regulations”
“In view of this and in accordance with the Malawi Public Service Commission regulations 42 (3) as read by regulation  I am prohibiting you from exercising the powers and functions of your office as Senior Accounts Assistant (Grade L) with pay with immediate effect." Mphasa further ordered Mithi to cease to exercise any power and functions in the civil service and not leave Malawi without written permission from the Accountant General's office.
"Please note that the interdiction order shall remain in force until you are cleared on the charges levelled against you or a decision is reached by the government. This interdiction is intended to pave the way for investigation into allegations levelled against you," he said.
But responding to the letter, Mithi through lawyer Davie Lameck requested the Accountant General to immediately lift the interdiction order as it breaches his constitutional right to freedoms and opinion, expression and political rights as enshrined under sections 14,
35 and 40, respectively, of the constitution.
He said: "Your accusations are void ab initio per Section 5 of the Constitution. It constitutes unfair labour practice and violets his rights to be heard.
"We wish to put it on record that since you have not thus provided
particulars of the allegations against our client, it reasonably means that the said particulars do not exist and any later production of particulars will reasonably be taken as manufacturing of evidence." The lawyer also reminded the government that civil servants are not excluded in all the provisions of the Constitution.
Author: Precious Kumbani

Title: Manganya: Chakwera’s secret weapon?
Content:
In appointing Michael Usi as the country’s Vice – President after the tragic loss of Saulos Chilima, President Lazarus Chakwera has demonstrated a maturity that the beginning of a transformation are made of. 
The questions of the vice – presidency often emerges from the shadow immediately before general elections. This is when presidential candidates must submit their papers to the Malawi Electoral Commission, a requirement of which is that each aspiring candidate must name a running mate. 
In this period, the choice of vise –presidential candidates becomes a focus of intense speculation and bargaining . I can even remember one contestant who picked his running – mate at a roadside roundabout while on the way to submit his papers. He had no idea was going to be his running – mate until it suddenly come to him at breakfast. Thanks God for sausage and baked beans! 
What makes this hoopla even more intriguing is that in Malawi, just as in many countries around the world, the vice – presidency has always had such a bad reputation. 
In America, for instance, it has been decided for nearly 200 years, especially by those who have held the office. John Adams called it “the most insignificant office that ever the invention of man contrived, or his imagination conceived,” Garner declared with some feeling, that the job was “hardly worth a pitcher of warm spit.”  
The choice of vice – presidential candidate has traditionally been viewed as having more symbolic than substantive significance. Consequently, the selection has typically been made based on political considerations, be they matters of intraparty import ( the desire to propitiate a rival faction) or electoral strategy ( the hope of balancing a ticket in an advantageous way). 
It is a fact that the appointment od Usi cannot bring any of these perceived advantages that makes Chakwera’s choice powerfully mature. As Sherlock Holmes has always sought to teach us, when  you eliminate all the  other possibilities, whenever is left, however improbable, must be your answer. 
Regardless of the many qualities and abilities that the late Chilima brought to the office , the bottom line was always that held the office by virtue of his being the leader of the UTM party. He was a representative of the other block of the alliance. 
The same cannot really be said about Usi. Reports in the media indicate that his continued presence in UTM may be at risk and there are indications to careful observers that the UTM, as party has not necessarily acknowledged a leadership succession from Chilima to Usi. His (Usi) precarious standing cannot be considered as something of value that Chakwera saw in appointing him because there are no political advantages pr any kind of political balancing advantages in the appointment. It must have been made for some other reason. 
But we also know that chakwera appointed Chilima because of professional reasons and for his track- record as a leader and an achiever. These are the very reasons that the president considered and gave us when he justified his appointment as already pointed out – the fact that Chilima was a lot more politically too. 
In this regard, the only possibility that remains is that Chakwera has appointed Usi beacause of professional reasons.he wants a Vise – President who will gelp him achieve what he set out to do, which is to develop this country. 
I can hear you asking : But how can Usi succeed where the very talented Chikuma seemingly failed for three years? After all, was it not Usi himself admited that Chilima’s boots are too large for him to fill? This is a good question. Keep reading .  
Is Chakwera right in producing Usi from his back pocket as his secret weapon? Does Usi now fit this now spotlit bill of Chakwera’s knight in shining ammon? 
The answer is yes and no. Yes, because just like the late Chilima. Usi has a track- record of top service delivery and has pristine leadership qualities. While as Chilima earned his spurs in the private commercial sector, Usi earned his credentials in leading a top international non- governmental organisation, winning many awards for top leadership perfomance in terms 0f experience and the ability that a president can need from his Vice- President in the huge task of leading the nation. Usi  he has as good a pesron as any well educated and well experienced person can be. His crowd – pulling potential as a comedian of some repute in his other life cannot be a bad bonus either! 
No beacuse the vice- presidency is not an easy office from which one can influence the direction of the country. Thus, if the President does not take the lead of empowering and including the wisdom and abilities of the Vice-president, then all the positive will be lost and all that will remain wii be politicking which does not develop the country. 
For Usi to be Chakwera’s secret weapon,and for him to help Chakwera convince those that still doubt his right to the presidency based on their evaluation of his perfomance. It is crucial that the president should regularly consult the Vice- president job depends on the President’s commitment to their relationship. Each hour that the presidents spends in private conference with the vice – president is an hour not to spend with someone else. That is why what the Vice –President can bring to those conservation in the way of knowledge and experience is so important. 
As for the newly appointed Vice – President Usi, my advice is very simple – there are four basic rules for Vice- President to follow to build trust with the president and ensure harmony in the working relationship. 
        (1)  Never complain to the press, establish a channel of communication that is open so that if you are unhappy with something you, can speak freely about it to the president rather than complaining to the media or to party officials who then spread rumours. 
       (2) Never take credit from the president. The Vice- President must constantly be mindful of who is president and who is not. You are not president. All credit must go go to the president. 
       (3) Fall in line. No matter how much the vice – president opposes a presidential decisions  he or she must support the final policy. The Vice – President does not have to become a vocal supporter or lobbyist on the particular issue, but must fall in line like any other staffer. 
       (4) Share the dirty work without complainig. Through the Vice – President may not like endless travel comes with the territory . It is part of being a team player. 
        In the final analysis, although the answer to the question  of whether picking Usi will be moment of triumph or not for President Chakwera depends on himself. If he recognises that it is time to take the Vise- presidency seriously, as a major source and asset that must be included and utilised to the full, then Usi will indeed , be his secret weapon. 
      But iy means that Chakwera will be the first president ever in this country to make a determined effort to find and then utilise talented and seasoned Vice- President who can help to make their administrations more effective, and then empower them to do so.

Title: Atupele seeks return to UDF
Content:
Two years after announcing his departure from active politics and subsequently relinquishing the United Democratic Front (UDF) presidency, former president Bakili Muluzi’s son, Atupele has expressed interest to vie for the post. 
On the other hand, UDF interim president Lilian Patel has said she will not contest for any position at the party’s convention slated for August 3 2024 ahead of the September 16 2024 General Elections. 
UDF spokesperson Yusuf Mwawa in an interview last week said Atupele is among the UDF members who have already collected nomination forms. 
But he refused to disclose names of the other hopefuls, saying the party will give more information during a media briefing in Blantyre on a date to be set. 
Said Mwawa; “The nominations were opened last month (June) and will be closed on 17th of July before the convention on August 3. honourable Atupele Muluzi will stand for the presidency. 
“Our constitution is open – ended and does not give a time period for one to hold a particular position in the party.” 
Atupele could not be drawn on the development as he did not respond to The Nation phone calls. 
Patel, on the other, in an interview on Thursday said she will not contest for any position in the party as she would like to focus her energy on retaining her Mangochi South parliamentary seat. 
She said she has sarved UDF in various positions since 1993 and felt it is time to give others a chance to run the affairs. 
“But if the party wish to give me something honorary, that is okay. Otherwise, i am not contesting . But i am available for any advise or service they (UDF) want from me, "said Patel.  
Commenting on the matter, political analyst Chimwemwe Kandodo, Nandin Patel and Victor Chipofya, a lecturer at Blantyre Internationa University noted that Atupele has the right to contest for the UDF presidency. 
However, the observed that his return has both positive and Negative sides. 
Said Kandodo, a lecturer at Catholic University of Malawi; “Sometimes it can bring confusion because for the past two years, he hasn’t been around as UDF president and Madam Patel was acting as the president. 
“So together with her team, maybe she had put in place other strategies in order to win in the next year’s general elections, and now that Atupele wants to come back won’t it disturb the strategy?” 
On her part, Nandin Patel, a member of Political science Association, said Atupele has the quality and capabilities of a leader, but needed to prove his consistency. 
“Let’s hope that there will be competition for the president at the convention,” she said . 
Atupele has led UDF in two presidential elections, first in 2014 and in the nullified 2019 vote. In the June 23 2020 court sactioned fresh presidential election, he featured as running mate to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) president Peter Muthalika. 
However, the pair lost to a combination of incumbent President Lazarus Chakwera of Malawi Cogress Party who have teamed up with former UTM party president and the country’s vice – president Saulos Chilima. 
In his resignation letter to UDF secretary general Kandi Padambo dated May 28 2022, Atupele said he was “going into business for the development and progress of Malawi”. 
Read the latter in part: “In view of this decision and pursuant with the party constitution, I appoint Patel, party vice – president Eastern Region, to lead the party as acting president until the next national convention where my successor will be elected.”

Reports indicate that the United Democratic Front (UDF) has agreed to work with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the forthcoming fresh elections. Delegates at the UDF National Executive Committee meeting agreed on this in Blantyre. However, the party’s Secretary General Kandi Padambo insists that the party has not chosen a partner yet.

Title: Usi for mindset change among HR professionals
Content:
Vise –President Michael Usi has challenged human resources professionals to embrace mindset change to help develop the country. 
He said this on Thursday at sunbird Nkopola in Mangochi during this year's Human resource Society of Malawi (HRSM) annual conference being held under the theme ‘Actualising HRSM’s vision: Promoting Excellence in HR practice’. 
Usi described the human resource profession as a catalyst for the country's economy; hence, embracing mindset change can help the country achieve Malawi 2063 with ease. 
He said: I am happy with this conference because it is in line with the MW2063, the country's development blueprint, which has mindset change and human capital development. 
“The Vise-President tressed that a growth mindset helps individuals believe they can improve their circumstances, saying this leads to self-investment in education and health. 
To this effect, Usi implored the human resource practitioners to capitalise on their existence to implement interventions that bring positive change to the country. 
“Be impactful to the country and strive to be models of excellence to give your profession relevance "he advised. 
In his remarks, HRSM vice – President Benson Jackson said as professional they are committed to bringing positive impact through their work. 
“As a society and, of course, as HR professionals, we exist to provide solutions to many problems befalling the country in areas of human capital and development. 
“This is the reason we always gather here to share knowledge and skills that can develop the country. We are, therefore, committed to helping bring change,” he said. 
During the conference, the HRSM also launched its first five-year (2024-2029) strategic plan.

Title: UDF disowns freiends of Atupele, calls group illegal.
Content: A parallel strucure has emerged in the aestwhile governing United Democratic Front (UDF) following the resurfacing on the political front of its former president Atupele Muluzi. The Party’s secretary general Kandi Padambo said in an interview on Wedsnday the party is aware of the parallel structure, which is calling itself friends of Atupele Muluzi.  The grouping is campaigning for the party’s former leader to contest in the 2025 Election on the party’s ticket without being sanctioned. Before resurfacing, Atupele, who is the son to the party’s founder Bakili Muluzi, resigned on May 20 2022 as UDF president to transition into a pan – African business executive. The parallel group has been holding meeting across the country and campaigning for Atupele, describing him as a clean and honest politician without any involvement in corruption- related scandals. When contacted yesterday, Atupele confirmed that they are people who would like him to serve. He said; “I am listening to the discussion with keen interest. However, what l must point out is that Atupele is a team player, I am not a divider but unifier.” Atupele said he was willing to serve the country as the country is going through the great pain. “My message is a message of hope for Malawians that a new nation will come out of this pain. However, it will have to take some sacrifices and bold decisions. “We are at a time that requires more statesmen and women who can rise above divisive party politics in service of our nation. We need a reset button for a new Malawi,” he said. Atupele said he is willing to serve in any capacity, as a servant of the people of Malawi. “If the nation calls me to serve l am willing to serve, whether as a street sweeper or a president. It is a service.” However, Padambo said the grouping is illegal. He said; “The group [Friends of Atupele Muluzi] can make those calls, l am sure it’s their right to do so. But when Right Honourable Atupele Muluzi decides to contest, he will have to abide by the rules and procedures of the party. “He will not contest because the grouping of Friends of Atupele Muluzi is making calls for him to contest but because he remains a member of the party, and he will follow procedures that are in place for any member to contest for any position in the party.” Atupele announced his resignation in a Facebook post on May 30, 2022, in which he said he is embarking on an industrial and economic revolution together with his business partners. Governance expert Boniface Chibwana said in a separate interview. Atupele is likely to retain UDF presidency due to the founder syndrome. “The founder syndrome is also associated with the financial muscle of the individuals and families that are founded those political parties and some supporters align themselves to that family or individuals. This is what is happening in the UDF,” he said. UDF was the first political party to form government after Malawi returned to multiparty democracy in 1994. But its popularity started to decline, especially after the 2004 General Elections when former president Bingu wa Muthalika left the party to form Democratic Progressive party. Apart from popularity, its parliamentary seats have also been on the decline since 1999 in 2014, it got 10 seats.

Title: Malawi, Tanzania sign pact on diplomatic data corridor.
Content:
Malawi and Tanzanian governments last week signed a commercial agreement to lower the cost of Internet. The agreement was in Tanzania signed by State-owned entities, Tanzania Telecommunications Corporation Limited (TTCL) and the Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi (Escom). Speaking after signing the agreement, Minister of Information and Digitisation Moses Kunkuyu said the agreement will enable Malawi through Escom to purchase Internet connectivity capacity from TTCL at affordable cost, thereby bringing down the cost of Internet.
"Our diplomatic relations with Tanzania have, therefore, facilitated this critical milestone for Malawi to achieve our flagship connectivity intervention, the Diplomatic Data Corridor," he said. On his part, Tanzania Minister of Information, Communication and Information Technology Nape Nauye said the strengthening of the information and communications technology sector in the region, will facilitate economic development and increase digital use. "Our goal is to ensure that all Southern African Development Community and East African Community member States are linked to the National ICT Broadband Backbone (NICTBB) ," he said. The connection between NICTBB and Malawi's Communication Backbone will happen at Tanzania-Malawi border in Kasumulo.
Author: Wezzie Nkhoma Somba

Title: UIP president faults Muluzi on hospitals donation
Content:
United Independence Party (UIP) president Helen Singh has hailed Ministry of Health for rejecting United Democratic Front (UDF) president Atupele Muluzi’s donation to referal’s hospitals, saying the donation was a mere campaign gimmick. 
Government rejected Muluzi’s three cheques worth K3 million to  Mzuzu, Kamuzu and Queen Elizabeth Central hospitals, claiming it was acting under instruction from the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) to pend the donation until elections an assertion officer Willie Kalonga disputed . But Singh in an interview at the weekend said Muluzi was taking advantage of people’s suffering to campaign. She said Muluzi should have made the donation long time ago if he was concerned about drug shortage in hospitals. “You do not campaign when people are suffering . The problems have been there for a long time. He should also have made the donations silently and not going on the podium so that people know he has made a donation. This also goes to every politician even the President [Joyce Banda]. 
She should  not be allowed to donate cows, house, ambulances and so on during the campaign time because those are handouts,” she said. However, Muluzi said he was touched by problems people are facing in hospitals and that doctors are contributing money for patients’ medication. He said by donating, he was setting an example to others. However, Chancellor College associate professor of political science Dr Blessings Chinsinga treated Muluzi’s donation as handouts during elections which would affect free and fair elections. He said issues of handouts should not apply to one person, hence, there is need for a law to bar everyone, including the President who has just procured ambulances.

Title: HANDS OFF OUR LIKOMA ISLAND | ANGLICAN CHURCH
Content:
Malawi Anglican church through Northern Diocese have called upon Anglicans and faiths leaders to stand strong to protect Likoma Island. In a Pastoral letter dated 26th September the church has come publicly to challenge the ownership of three islands namely Likoma, Chidzumulu and Mbamba.
Anglican church claims that it obtained three islands from Mozambique's chief Chiteji in 1881 and allign it with Nyasaland in 1893 stating that government of Malawi has no hand over the islands. The church says part of the land was handed over to the local people for them to utilize as customary land.
Anglican has quoted Matthew 18 vs 20 from the holly book Bible called upon all faithful leaders to stand strong to safeguard God's convenant at the Island.
This comes after Malawi government reportedly planned to sell islands to international investors to develop them into largest world's class Casino which would attract tourists. The move has met with resistance from Malawians including faith leaders and civil societies.

Title: MUTHARIKA CONSOLES CYCLONE VICTIMS
Content: Former president Peter Mutharika yesterday endured heavy showers and chilly conditions in Blantyre to cheer survivors of Cyclone Freddy and console families that have lost loved ones. The leader of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) visited the affected people being accommodated at Matope Primary School in Ndirande Township and Good Samaritan Camp at Green Corner where he also presented assorted items. In his address, Mutharika urged the victims not to lose hope, but keep praying to God. He said: "When God does something He does for a reason, so let us not despair. He gave us and he has taken. However, Mutharika attributed the calamity to lack of a National Disaster Policy which he said his administration already approved in 2019. The former president, who was accompanied by several party officials, further urged fellow politicians to desist from politicizing the disaster, saying “this is sombre period and let us focus on how best we can help these people” Ironically, Mutharika immediately contradicted his call when he turned his visit into a mini political rally reminding the people in Ndirande that they stoned him during campaign for the court-sanctioned fresh presidential election on June 23, 2020, which he lost. At Green Corner, he told the survivors that failure to appreciate the DPP administration's contribution is what had resulted in the numerous problems the country is facing. He said: "But I believe you have now learnt a lesson that you do not just put somebody in government because he is eloquent. You need to analyze the capability"  Mutharika said Malawians across the country were complaining and regretting voting the DPP out of government and assured the people that his party would bounce back into power in 2025 the way it did in 2024. Speaking on behalf of the victims at Green Corner, Yohane Chamveka, 28, from Chatha in Chilobwe thanked Mutharika for the visit and donation.
Author: Lucky Mkandawire

Title: Assemblies to contribute for Chakwera cause.
Content:
The Malawi Assemblies of God Church has asked its members across the country to contribute a minimum of K200 to buy a gift for the churches former president, Lazarus Chakwera, who is now the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) torch- bearer in the 2014 Tripartite Elections.
According to information the nation has gathered, the gift will be a token of appreciation for the services Chakwera rendered to the church in his 24 years of service.
The newly elected churches president, the Reverend Edward Chitsonga, yesterday confirmed that the church wants to thank Chakwera in a special way.
‘’its true. We have asked our church members to contribute at least k200 per member so that the church should buy a gift for him. This is normal and not strange; that’s what we do when the leader is retiring form any position in the church. This will be his gratuity for Gods work he has performed for 24 years of service to the church,’’ said Chitsonga.
Asked on the type of gift the church is going to give the 58-year-old Chakwera, Chitsonga said they will buy him a ‘good vehicle’ and the rest of the money will be given to him in cash.
‘’We want our former president to have a good vehicle and use the rest of the money for his personal wish so that he can have comfortable retirement,’’ said Chitsongs
Chikhwawa-based Malawi Assemblies of God Reverend Francis Kapheni said many members of the church have welcomed the request.
‘’Our members are much willing to contribute the money because that’s the  only way they can take apart in appreciating the services Reverend Chakwera offered to the church,’’ said Kaphani.
According to Chitsonga, the church a membership of 500 000.
This means if all the members contribute a minimum of K200, K100 million will be raised.
Author: Dyson Nthawanji

Title: UDF says no pact with DPP
Content: Opposition United Democratic Front (UDF) says the appointment if its president Atupele Muluzi into President Peter Mutharika’s Cabinet does not translate into a working alliance with the governing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Mutharika appointed Atupele, who was one of the 12 presidential candidate in the May 20 Tripartite Elections, as Minister of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining at midnight on Sunday to complete his promised 20 – members Cabinet. But UDF secretary general Kandi Padambo, in an interview with The Nation yesterday, said the appointment has not changed his party’s status as it remains un the opposition bloc. Said Padambo; “As a party, we have not gone into any political alliance with DPP. The appointment of our president does not change our stand and does not make UDF cease to be an opposition party. We will continue discharging our duties as an opposition party to the expectation of all Malawians.” He said as an opposition party, UDF will continue opposing all laws and policies that are not in the best interest of the majority of Malawians. However, Padambo paid his party will support all policies DPP and its administration will come up with a long as Malawians do not have problems with them. He said; “As a party, we have made our position clear that we will remain a responsible party inside and outside Parliament. The fact that our president has joined government will not compromise our position.” On whether the party does not think DPP was merely after using its president to increase its numerical strength in Parliament, Padambo said; “We think the appointment is in good faith, but if somewhere along the way we see it is not sustainable, we will see what to do then.” Muluzi was also among the first Cabinet ministers appointed by former president Joyce Banda when she ascended to the presidency in line with constitutional order in April 2012 following the death of president Bingu wa Mutharika. However, a few months later, Atupele quit following what Padambo described as misunderstandings between UDF and Banda’s People’s Party (PP) on issues to do with Government of National Unity (GNU). “Last time, we wanted to help, and we thought the Government of National of National Unity (GNU) would be in the best interests of all the parties, but he resigned because certain developments turned out which we thought were not in the best interests of the party as well as Malawians, “ Padambo said. Meanwhile, as we went to press, the UDF executive committee was meeting to discuss the recent developments, which some members said they only heard about from the radio.

Title: ACB to quiz on Sattar – linked plots
Content: The Anti – Corruption Bureau (ACB) has summoned former minister of Land Atupele Muluzi for the questioning over the allocation of some plots in Lilongwe linked to United Kingdom – based businessperson Zuneth Sattar.According to a notice from ACB director general Martha Chizuma dated November 9, Atupele, who served in the ministry from 2015 to 2017 during the Peter Muthalika administration, will appear at ACB head office in Lilongwe today. Reads the notice in part; “Whereas you are the former minister of the Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development, in Republic of Malawi, take notice that l require you, to appear before officers of the Anti – Corruption Bureau at Anti – Corruption Bureau offices, Mulanje House in City Centre, Lilongwe on 10th November 2022, at 2:00 o’clock in the afternoon to answer questions in connection with allocation of Plot Numbers Bwaila 13/127 and 13/128.” The plots in question appear on the list of properties linked to Sattar which the graft – busting body issued on restriction order on December 23 2021.  In an interview yesterday, Atupele, Son to former president Bakili Muluzi, confirmed being summoned, but feigned ignorance of the details of the ACB investigation. He said; “The only details l gave received are the ones on the summons. You may wish to contact the ACB for further details.” But writing on his Facebook wall, Atupele pledged to avail himself to the ACB for questioning to aid the bureau in its investigations. He wrote; “As a firm believer in the rule of law and due process, of the law, l take this a routine process of the work of the bureau and no cause for worry for me or my supporters as all things become clear after the process.”In its December 23 2021 restriction notice, ACB stopped the ministry of lands from dealing with properties which it believed Sattar, who is under probe over some procurement contracts with Malawi Government ministries, departments and agencies, has beneficial interest. The restriction order reads in part; “The restriction notice has been issued as part of investigation by the bureau following allegations that Zuneth Sattar and his agent Ashok Kumar Sreedharan aka Ashok Nair have been giving bribes to politically exposed persons with the aim of influencing Various Malawi Government Departments to corruptly award contracts to companies belonging to Zuneth Sattar.” On whether he knew that the plots were linked to Sattar, Atupele said, “No, i am not aware.[I have ] no idea about the facts. Will wait to hear tomorrow [today],” ACB principal public relation officer Egritta Ndala yesterday refused to comment the  matter, saying, they do not make such summons public. On December 31 2021, another former minister of Lands Kezzie Msukwa was arrested alongside Nair on corruption allegations relating the land deals with Sattar, but the ACB is awaiting the determination of the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal to move with the case. The supreme Court is expected to determine on  the admissibility of the foreign obtained evidence. Msukwa also wants the court to rule on whether the ACB is legally mandated to enter into formal of informal cooperation arrangements with the purpose of exchanging information or evidence in criminal matters without going through the Attorney General.
